INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (1, 3, N'ASP.NET MVC Overview', N'<p><strong>ASP.NET MVC Overview</strong></p>

<p>The Model-View-Controller (MVC) architectural pattern separates an application into three main components: the model, the view, and the controller. The ASP.NET MVC framework is a lightweight, highly testable presentation framework that (as with Web Forms-based applications) is integrated with existing ASP.NET features, such as master pages and membership-based authentication. The MVC framework is defined in the System.Web.Mvc namespace and is a fundamental, supported part of the System. Web namespace.</p>

<p>MVC is a standard design pattern that many developers are familiar with.</p>

<p>The MVC framework includes the following components:</p>

<p><strong>Models. </strong></p>

<p>Model objects are the parts of the application that implement the logic for the applications data domain. Often, model objects retrieve and store model state in a database. For example, a Product object might retrieve information from a database, operate on it, and then write updated information back to a Products table in SQL Server.</p>

<p>In small applications, the model is often a conceptual separation instead of a physical one. For example, if the application only reads a data set and sends it to the view, the application does not have a physical model layer and associated classes. In that case, the data set takes on the role of a model object.</p>

<p><strong>Views</strong>.</p>

<p>Views are the components that display the applications user interface (UI). Typically, this UI is created from the model data. An example would be an edit view of a Products table that displays text boxes, drop-down lists, and check boxes based on the current state of a Products object.</p>

<p><strong>Controllers</strong>.</p>

<p>Controllers are the components that handle user interaction, work with the model, and ultimately select a view to render that displays UI. In an MVC application, the view only displays information; the controller handles and responds to user input and interaction. For example, the controller handles query-string values, and passes these values to the model, which in turn queries the database by using the values.</p>

<p>The MVC pattern helps you create applications that separate the different aspects of the application (input logic, business logic, and UI logic), while providing a loose coupling between these elements. The pattern specifies where each kind of logic should be located in the application. The UI logic belongs in the view. Input logic belongs in the controller. Business logic belongs in the model. This separation helps you manage complexity when you build an application, because it enables you to focus on one aspect of the implementation at a time. For example, you can focus on the view without depending on the business logic.</p>

<p>In addition to managing complexity, the MVC pattern makes it easier to test applications than it is to test a Web Forms-based ASP.NET Web application. For example, in a Web Forms-based ASP.NET Web application, a single class is used both to display output and to respond to user input. Writing automated tests for Web Forms-based ASP.NET applications can be complex, because to test an individual page, you must instantiate the page class, all its child controls, and additional dependent classes in the application. Because so many classes are instantiated to run the page, it can be hard to write tests that focus exclusively on individual parts of the application. Tests for Web Forms-based ASP.NET applications can therefore be more difficult to implement than tests in an MVC application. Moreover, tests in a Web Forms-based ASP.NET application require a Web server. The MVC framework decouples the components and makes heavy use of interfaces, which makes it possible to test individual components in isolation from the rest of the framework.</p>

<p>The loose coupling between the three main components of an MVC application also promotes parallel development. For instance, one developer can work on the view, a second developer can work on the controller logic, and a third developer can focus on the business logic in the model.</p>

<p><strong>Features of the ASP.NET MVC Framework</strong></p>

<p>The ASP.NET MVC framework provides the following features:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Separation of application tasks (input logic, business logic, and UI logic), testability, and test-driven development (TDD) by default. All core contracts in the MVC framework are interface-based and can be tested by using mock objects, which are simulated objects that imitate the behavior of actual objects in the application. You can unit-test the application without having to run the controllers in an ASP.NET process, which makes unit testing fast and flexible. You can use any unit-testing framework that is compatible with the .NET Framework.</li>
	<li>An extensible and pluggable framework. The components of the ASP.NET MVC framework are designed so that they can be easily replaced or customized. You can plug in your own view engine, URL routing policy, action-method parameter serialization, and other components. The ASP.NET MVC framework also supports the use of Dependency Injection (DI) and Inversion of Control (IOC) container models. DI allows you to inject objects into a class, instead of relying on the class to create the object itself. IOC specifies that if an object requires another object, the first objects should get the second object from an outside source such as a configuration file. This makes testing easier.</li>
	<li>A powerful URL-mapping component that lets you build applications that have comprehensible and searchable URLs. URLs do not have to include file-name extensions, and are designed to support URL naming patterns that work well for search engine optimization (SEO) and representational state transfer (REST) addressing.</li>
	<li>Support for using the markup in existing ASP.NET page (.aspx files), user control (.ascx files), and master page (.master files) markup files as view templates. You can use existing ASP.NET features with the ASP.NET MVC framework, such as nested master pages, in-line expressions (&lt;%= %&gt;), declarative server controls, templates, data-binding, localization, and so on.</li>
	<li>Support for existing ASP.NET features. ASP.NET MVC lets you use features such as forms authentication and Windows authentication, URL authorization, membership and roles, output and data caching, session and profile state management, health monitoring, the configuration system, and the provider architecture.</li>
</ul>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A000805DB9 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (2, 3, N'MVC Execution Process', N'<p><strong>Understanding the ASP.NET MVC Execution Process</strong></p>

<p>Requests to an ASP.NET MVC-based Web application first pass through the <strong>UrlRoutingModule</strong> object, which is an HTTP module. This module parses the request and performs route selection. The <strong>UrlRoutingModule</strong> object selects the first route object that matches the current request. (A route object is a class that implements <strong>RouteBase</strong>, and is typically an instance of the Route class.) If no routes match, the UrlRoutingModule object does nothing and lets the request fall back to the regular ASP.NET or IIS request processing.</p>

<p>From the selected Route object, the UrlRoutingModule object obtains the <strong>IRouteHandler</strong> object that is associated with the Route object. Typically, in an MVC application, this will be an instance of <strong>MvcRouteHandler</strong>. The IRouteHandler instance creates an <strong>IHttpHandler</strong> object and passes it the <strong>IHttpContext</strong> object. By default, the <strong>IHttpHandler</strong> instance for MVC is the <strong>MvcHandler</strong> object. The <strong>MvcHandler</strong> object then selects the controller that will ultimately handle the request.</p>

<p><strong>Note:</strong> When an ASP.NET MVC Web application runs in IIS 7.0, no file name extension is required for MVC projects. However, in IIS 6.0, the handler requires that you map the .mvc file name extension to the ASP.NET ISAPI DLL.</p>

<p>The module and handler are the entry points to the ASP.NET MVC framework. They perform the following actions:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Select the appropriate controller in an MVC Web application.</li>
	<li>Obtain a specific controller instance.</li>
	<li>Call the controllers Execute method.</li>
</ol>

<p>The following table lists the stages of execution for an MVC Web project.</p>

<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="height:559px; width:909px">
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Stage</strong></p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Details</strong></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Receive first request for the application</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>In the Global.asax file, <strong>Route</strong> objects are added to the <strong>RouteTable</strong> object.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Perform routing</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>The <strong>UrlRoutingModule</strong> module uses the first matching <strong>Route</strong> object in the <strong>RouteTable</strong> collection to create the <strong>Route Data</strong> object, which it then uses to create a <strong>Request Context</strong> (<strong>IHttpContext</strong>) object.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Create MVC request handler</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>The <strong>MvcRouteHandler</strong> object creates an instance of the <strong>MvcHandler</strong> class and passes it the <strong>RequestContext</strong> instance.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Create controller</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>The <strong>MvcHandler</strong> object uses the <strong>RequestContext</strong> instance to identify the <strong>IControllerFactory</strong> object (typically an instance of the <strong>DefaultControllerFactory</strong> class) to create the controller instance with.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Execute controller</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>The <strong>MvcHandler</strong> instance calls the controllers <strong>Execute</strong> method.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Invoke action</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>Most controllers inherit from the <strong>Controller</strong> base class. For controllers that do so, the <strong>ControllerActionInvoker</strong> object that is associated with the controller determines which action method of the controller class to call, and then calls that method.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Execute result</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>A typical action method might receive user input, prepare the appropriate response data, and then execute the result by returning a result type. The built-in result types that can be executed include the following: <strong>ViewResult</strong> (which renders a view and is the most-often used result type), <strong>RedirectToRouteResult</strong>, <strong>RedirectResult</strong>, <strong>ContentResult</strong>, <strong>JsonResult</strong>, and <strong>EmptyResult</strong>.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A00080EF1B AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (3, 8, N'Clustered & Non-Clustered Index', N'<p><strong>What is Clustered &amp; Non-Clustered Index?</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Clustered Index:</strong> Clustered index physically rearrange the data that users inserts in your tables. It is nothing but a dictionary type data where actual data remains.</p>

<p><br />
<strong>Non-Clustered Index:</strong> It Non-Clustered Index contains pointers to the data that is stored in the data page. It is a kind of index backside of the book where you see only the reference of a kind of data.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A20146F680 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (4, 8, N'Primary Key & Unique Key', N'<p><span style="font-size:16px"><strong>What&#39;s the difference between a primary key and a unique key?</strong></span></p>

<p>Both primary key and unique enforce uniqueness of the column on which they are defined. But by default primary key creates a clustered index on the column, where are unique creates a nonclustered index by default. Another major difference is that, primary key doesn&#39;t allow NULLs, but unique key allows one NULL only.</p>

<p>In SQL Server, we have two keys which distinctively or uniquely identify a record in the database. Both the keys seems identical, but actually both are different in features and behaviours. In this article, I would like to share the key difference between primary key and unique key.</p>

<p style="text-align:center"><strong>Difference between Primary Key &amp; Unique Key</strong></p>

<table border="1" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" style="height:194px; width:936px">
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td style="text-align:center"><span style="color:#800000"><strong>Primary Key</strong></span></td>
			<td style="text-align:center"><strong><span style="color:#800000">Unique Key</span></strong></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="text-align:justify">&nbsp;Primary Key can&#39;t accept null values.</td>
			<td>&nbsp;Unique key can accept only one null value.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>&nbsp;By default, Primary key is clustered index and data in the database</p>

			<p>&nbsp;table is physically organized in the sequence of clustered index.</p>
			</td>
			<td>&nbsp;By default, Unique key is a unique non-clustered index.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>&nbsp;We can have only one Primary key in a table.</td>
			<td>&nbsp;We can have more than one unique key in a table.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>&nbsp;Primary key can be made foreign key into another table.</td>
			<td>&nbsp;In SQL Server, Unique key can be made foreign key into another table.</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Define Primary Key &amp; Unique Key</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; CREATE TABLE Employee<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; EmpID int PRIMARY KEY, --define primary key<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Name varchar (50) NOT NULL,<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; MobileNo int UNIQUE, --define unique key<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Salary int NULL<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; )</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A30180D62E AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (5, 8, N'Types of SQL Keys', N'<p><strong>Types of SQL Keys</strong></p>

<p>We have following types of keys in SQL which are used to fetch records from tables and to make relationship among tables or views.</p>

<p><strong>Super Key</strong></p>

<p>Super key is a set of one or more than one keys that can be used to identify a record uniquely in a table.Example : Primary key, Unique key, Alternate key are subset of Super Keys.</p>

<p><strong>Candidate Key</strong></p>

<p>A Candidate Key is a set of one or more fields/columns that can identify a record uniquely in a table. There can be multiple Candidate Keys in one table. Each Candidate Key can work as Primary Key.</p>

<p><strong>Primary Key</strong></p>

<p>Primary key is a set of one or more fields/columns of a table that uniquely identify a record in database table. It can not accept null, duplicate values. Only one Candidate Key can be Primary Key.</p>

<p><strong>Alternate key</strong></p>

<p>A Alternate key is a key that can be work as a primary key. Basically it is a candidate key that currently is not primary key.</p>

<p><strong>Composite/Compound Key</strong></p>

<p>Composite Key is a combination of more than one fields/columns of a table. It can be a Candidate key, Primary key.</p>

<p><strong>Unique Key</strong></p>

<p>Uniquekey is a set of one or more fields/columns of a table that uniquely identify a record in database table. It is like Primary key but it can accept only one null value and it can not have duplicate values. For more help refer the article Difference between primary key and unique key.</p>

<p><strong>Foreign Key</strong></p>

<p>Foreign Key is a field in database table that is Primary key in another table. It can accept multiple null, duplicate values. For more help refer the article Difference between primary key and foreign key.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A30182D8E5 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (6, 8, N'Stored Procedure and Function', N'<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="font-size:26px"><strong>Stored Procedure and Function</strong></span></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Stored Procedures are pre-compile objects which are compiled for first time and its compiled format is saved which executes (compiled code) whenever it is called. But Function is compiled and executed every time when it is called.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">A stored procedure is a named group of SQL statements that have been previously created and stored in the server database. Stored procedures accept input parameters so that a single procedure can be used over the network by several clients using different input data. And when the procedure is modified, all clients automatically get the new version. Stored procedures reduce network traffic and improve performance. Stored procedures can be used to help ensure the integrity of the database.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>e.g. sp_helpdb, sp_renamedb, sp_depends etc.</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="font-size:18px"><strong><span style="color:rgb(178, 34, 34)">Basic Difference</span></strong></span></p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Function must return a value but in Stored Procedure it is optional( Procedure can return zero or n values).</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Functions can have only input parameters for it whereas Procedures can have input/output parameters .</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Functions can be called from Procedure whereas Procedures cannot be called from Function.</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="color:#B22222"><strong><span style="font-size:18px">Advance Difference</span></strong></span></p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Procedure allows SELECT as well as DML(INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE) statement in it whereas Function allows only SELECT statement in it.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Procedures can not be utilized in a SELECT statement whereas Function can be embedded in a SELECT statement.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Stored Procedures cannot be used in the SQL statements anywhere in the WHERE/HAVING/SELECT section whereas Function can be.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">The most important feature of stored procedures over function is to retention and reuse the execution plan while in case of function it will be compiled every time.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Functions that return tables can be treated as another rowset. This can be used in JOINs with other tables.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Inline Function can be though of as views that take parameters and can be used in JOINs and other Rowset operations.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Exception can be handled by try-catch block in a Procedure whereas try-catch block cannot be used in a Function.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">We can go for Transaction Management in Procedure whereas we can&#39;t go in Function.</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="color:#800000"><span style="font-size:18px"><strong>Advantages of stored procedures</strong></span></span></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Better Performance:</strong> Stored procedures are precompiled and hence run much faster than adhoc queries</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Better Security:</strong> Applications making use of dynamically built adhoc sql queries are highly susceptible to sql injection attacks, where as Stored Procedures can avoid SQL injection attacks completely.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Reduced Network Traffic:</strong> Stored procedures can reduce network traffic to a very great extent when compared with adhoc sql queries. With stored procedures, you only need to send the name of the procedure between client and server. Imagine the amount of network bandwith that can be saved especially if the stored procedure contains 1000 to 2000 lines of SQL.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Better Maintainance and Reusability:</strong> Stored procedures can be used any where in the application. It is easier to maintain a stored procedure that is used on several pages as the modfifcations just need to be changed at one place where the stored procedure is defined. On the other hand, maintaining an adhoc sql query that&#39;s used on several pages is tedious and error prone, as we have to make modifications on each and every page.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A401542F3E AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (7, 8, N'CTE - Common Table Expression', N'<p><span style="font-size:20px"><strong>CTE</strong></span></p>

<p>CTE stands for <span style="color:#B22222"><strong>Common Table expressions</strong></span>. It was introduced with SQL Server 2005. It is a temporary result set and typically it may be a result of complex sub-query. Unlike temporary table its life is limited to the current query. It is defined by using WITH statement. CTE improves readability and ease in maintenance of complex queries and sub-queries. Always begin CTE with semicolon.</p>

<p>A sub query without CTE is given below :</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; SELECT * FROM (<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; SELECT Addr.Address, Emp.Name, Emp.Age From Address Addr<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Inner join Employee Emp on Emp.EID = Addr.EID) Temp<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; WHERE Temp.Age &gt; 50<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ORDER BY Temp.NAME</p>

<p><strong>By using CTE above query can be re-written as follows :</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ;With CTE1(Address, Name, Age)--Column names for CTE, which are optional<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; AS<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; SELECT Addr.Address, Emp.Name, Emp.Age from Address Addr<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; INNER JOIN EMP Emp ON Emp.EID = Addr.EID<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; )<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; SELECT * FROM CTE1 --Using CTE<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; WHERE CTE1.Age &gt; 50<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ORDER BY CTE1.NAME</p>

<p><strong>When to use CTE</strong></p>

<ol>
	<li>This is used to store result of a complex sub query for further use.</li>
	<li>This is also used to create a recursive query.</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A4017C8BDE AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (8, 8, N'Temporary Tables', N'<p><span style="color:#800000"><span style="font-size:16px"><strong>Temporary Tables</strong></span></span></p>

<p>In SQL Server, temporary tables are created at run-time and you can do all the operations which you can do on a normal table. These tables are created inside Tempdb database. Based on the scope and behavior temporary tables are of two types as given below.</p>

<ol>
	<li>Local Temp Table</li>
	<li>Global Temp Table</li>
</ol>

<p><strong>Local Temp Table</strong></p>

<p>Local temp tables are only available to the SQL Server session or connection (means single user) that created the tables. These are automatically deleted when the session that created the tables has been closed. Local temporary table name is stared with single hash (&quot;#&quot;) sign.</p>

<p style="margin-left:80px">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; CREATE TABLE #LocalTemp<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; UserID int,<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Name varchar(50),<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Address varchar(150)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; )<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; GO<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; insert into #LocalTemp values ( 1, &#39;Shailendra&#39;,&#39;Noida&#39;);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; GO<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Select * from #LocalTemp</p>

<p>The scope of Local temp table exist to the current session of current user means to the current query window. If you will close the current query window or open a new query window and will try to find above created temp table, it will give you the error.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Global Temp Table</strong></p>

<p>Global temp tables are available to all SQL Server sessions or connections (means all the user). These can be created by any SQL Server connection user and these are automatically deleted when all the SQL Server connections have been closed. Global temporary table name is stared with double hash (&quot;##&quot;) sign.</p>

<p style="margin-left: 80px;">CREATE TABLE ##GlobalTemp<br />
(<br />
&nbsp;UserID int,<br />
&nbsp;Name varchar(50),<br />
&nbsp;Address varchar(150)<br />
)<br />
GO<br />
insert into ##GlobalTemp values ( 1, &#39;Shailendra&#39;,&#39;Noida&#39;);<br />
GO<br />
Select * from ##GlobalTemp</p>

<p>Global temporary tables are visible to all SQL Server connections while Local temporary tables are visible to only current SQL Server connection.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A7016E5CFA AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (9, 8, N'Table Variable', N'<p><span style="color:#A52A2A"><span style="font-size:16px"><strong>Table Variable</strong></span></span></p>

<p>This acts like a variable and exists for a particular batch of query execution. It gets dropped once it comes out of batch. This is also created in the Tempdb database but not the memory. This also allows you to create primary key, identity at the time of Table variable declaration but not non-clustered index.</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;">&nbsp;GO<br />
&nbsp;DECLARE @TProduct TABLE<br />
&nbsp;(<br />
&nbsp;SNo INT IDENTITY(1,1),<br />
&nbsp;ProductID INT,<br />
&nbsp;Qty INT<br />
&nbsp;)<br />
&nbsp;--Insert data to Table variable @Product<br />
&nbsp;INSERT INTO @TProduct(ProductID,Qty)<br />
&nbsp;SELECT DISTINCT ProductID, Qty FROM ProductsSales ORDER BY ProductID ASC<br />
&nbsp;--Select data<br />
&nbsp;Select * from @TProduct<br />
&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;--Next batch<br />
&nbsp;GO<br />
&nbsp;Select * from @TProduct --gives error in next batch</p>

<p><strong>Note:</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>Temp Tables are physically created in the Tempdb database. These tables act as the normal table and also can have constraints, index like normal tables.</li>
	<li>CTE is a named temporary result set which is used to manipulate the complex sub-queries data. This exists for the scope of statement. This is created in memory rather than Tempdb database. You cannot create any index on CTE.</li>
	<li>Table Variable acts like a variable and exists for a particular batch of query execution. It gets dropped once it comes out of batch. This is also created in the Tempdb database but not the memory.</li>
</ul>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A701744648 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (10, 8, N'Identity column in SQL Server', N'<p><strong>Identity column in SQL Server</strong></p>

<p>Identity field is usually used as a primary key. When you insert a new record into your table, this field automatically assign an incremented value from the previous entry. Usually, you can&#39;t insert your own value to this field.</p>

<p>You can alllow insert to the identity field by setting IDENTITY_INSERT ON for a particular table as shown:</p>

<p><strong>SET IDENTITY_INSERT Customer ON</strong></p>

<p>You can also disalllow insert to the identity field by setting IDENTITY_INSERT OFF for a particular table as shown:</p>

<p><strong>SET IDENTITY_INSERT Customer OFF</strong></p>

<p>Ex:</p>

<p>SET IDENTITY_INSERT Customer ON<br />
&nbsp;<br />
INSERT INTO Customer(ID,Name,Address) VALUES(3,&#39;Rahul&#39;,&#39;Noida&#39;)<br />
INSERT INTO Customer(ID,Name,Address) VALUES(4,&#39;Rahul&#39;,&#39;Noida&#39;)<br />
&nbsp;<br />
SET IDENTITY_INSERT Customer OFF</p>

<p><strong>Reseed the Identity field</strong></p>

<p>You can also reseed the identity field value. By doing so identity field values will start with a new defined value.</p>

<p>Suppose you want to reseed the Customer table ID field from 3 then the new record s will be inserted with ID 4,5,6..and so on.</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; --Reseeding the identity<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; DBCC checkident (Customer, RESEED, 3)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; INSERT INTO Customer(Name,Address) VALUES(&#39;Geeta&#39;,&#39;Noida&#39;)</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A7017898A7 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (11, 8, N'Difference between Primary Key and Foreign Key', N'<p>In SQL Server, there are two keys - primary key and foreign key which seems identical, but actually both are different in features and behaviours. In this article, I would like to share the key difference between primary key and foreign key.</p>

<p style="text-align:center"><strong>Difference between Primary Key &amp; Foreign Key</strong></p>

<table align="left" border="1" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" dir="ltr" style="height:198px; width:881px">
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th scope="col">Primary Key</th>
			<th scope="col">Foreign Key</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>&nbsp;Primary key uniquely identify a record in the table.</td>
			<td>&nbsp;Foreign key is a field in the table that is primary key in another table.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>&nbsp;Primary Key can&#39;t accept null values.</td>
			<td>&nbsp;Foreign key can accept multiple null value.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>By default, Primary key is clustered index and data in the database table is physically organized in the sequence of clustered index.</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>Foreign key do not automatically create an index, clustered or non-clustered. You can manually create an index on foreign key.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>&nbsp;We can have only one Primary key in a table.</td>
			<td>&nbsp;We can have more than one foreign key in a table.</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h2>&nbsp;</h2>

<h2>Define Primary key and Foreign key</h2>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; --Create Parent Table<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; CREATE TABLE Department<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; DeptID int PRIMARY KEY, --define primary key<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Name varchar (50) NOT NULL,<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Address varchar(100) NULL<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; )<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; GO<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; --Create Child Table<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; CREATE TABLE Employee<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; EmpID int PRIMARY KEY, --define primary key<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Name varchar (50) NOT NULL,<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Salary int NULL,<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; --define foreign key<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; DeptID int FOREIGN KEY REFERENCES Department(DeptID)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; )</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A800C3D856 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (12, 7, N'Sql Interview Questions', N'<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>What are the difference between clustered and a non-clustered index?</strong></span></p>

<p><strong>Clustered index</strong> is a special type of index that reorders the way records in the table are physically stored. Therefore table can have only one clustered index. The leaf nodes of a clustered index contain the data pages.</p>

<p><strong>Non clustered index</strong> is a special type of index in which the logical order of the index does not match the physical stored order of the rows on disk. The leaf node of a non clustered index does not consist of the data pages. Instead, the leaf nodes contain index rows.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>How do you implement one-to-one, one-to-many and many-to-many relationships while designing tables?</strong></span></p>

<ul>
	<li>One-to-One relationship can be implemented as a single table and rarely as two tables with primary and foreign key relationships.</li>
	<li>One-to-Many relationships are implemented by splitting the data into two tables with primary key and foreign key relationships.</li>
	<li>Many-to-Many relationships are implemented using a junction table with the keys from both the tables forming the composite primary key of the junction table.</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong><span style="color:#800000">What are the properties and different Types of Sub-Queries?</span></strong></p>

<p><strong>Properties of Sub-Query</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>A sub-query must be enclosed in the parenthesis.</li>
	<li>A sub-query must be put in the right hand of the comparison operator, and</li>
	<li>A sub-query cannot contain an ORDER-BY clause.</li>
	<li>A query can contain more than one sub-query.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Types of Sub-Query</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>Single-row sub-query, where the sub-query returns only one row.</li>
	<li>Multiple-row sub-query, where the sub-query returns multiple rows,. and</li>
	<li>Multiple column sub-query, where the sub-query returns multiple columns</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>What is a Scheduled Jobs or What is a Scheduled Tasks?</strong></span></p>

<p>Scheduled tasks let user automate processes that run on regular or predictable cycles. User can schedule administrative tasks, such as cube processing, to run during times of slow business activity. User can also determine the order in which tasks run by creating job steps within a SQL Server Agent job. E.g. back up database, Update Stats of Tables. Job steps give user control over flow of execution. If one job fails, user can configure SQL Server Agent to continue to run the remaining tasks or to stop execution.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>What is NOT NULL Constraint?</strong></span><br />
A NOT NULL constraint enforces that the column will not accept null values. The not null constraints are used to enforce domain integrity, as the check constraints.</p>

<p><strong><span style="color:#800000">How to get @@ERROR and @@ROWCOUNT at the same time?</span></strong></p>

<p>If @@Rowcount is checked after Error checking statement then it will have 0 as the value of @@Recordcount as it would have been reset. And if @@Recordcount is checked before the error-checking statement then @@Error would get reset. To get @@error and @@rowcount at the same time do both in same statement and store them in local variable.<br />
SELECT @RC = @@ROWCOUNT, @ER = @@ERROR</p>

<p><strong><span style="color:#800000">What are the advantages of using Stored Procedures?</span></strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>Stored procedure can reduced network traffic and latency, boosting application performance.</li>
	<li>Stored procedure execution plans can be reused, staying cached in SQL Server&#39;s memory, reducing server overhead.</li>
	<li>Stored procedures help promote code reuse.</li>
	<li>Stored procedures can encapsulate logic. You can change stored procedure code without affecting clients.</li>
	<li>Stored procedures provide better security to your data.</li>
</ul>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>What is a table called, if it has neither Cluster nor Non-cluster Index? What is it used for?</strong></span></p>

<div class="tech-answer">
<p>Unindexed table or Heap. Microsoft Press Books and Book on Line (BOL) refers it as Heap. A heap is a table that does not have a clustered index and, therefore, the pages are not linked by pointers. The IAM pages are the only structures that link the pages in a table together. Unindexed tables are good for fast storing of data. Many times it is better to drop all indexes from table and then do bulk of inserts and to restore those indexes after that.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>The Different Types of Joins in SQL Server</strong></span></p>

<ol>
	<li>Inner join or Equi join</li>
	<li>Self join</li>
	<li>Outer Join</li>
	<li>Cross join</li>
</ol>

<p><strong>Inner Join:</strong> This type of join is also known as the Equi join. This join returns all the rows from both tables where there is a match. This type of join can be used in the situation where we need to select only those rows which have values common in the columns which are specified in the ON clause.</p>

<p><strong>Self Join:</strong> Sometime we need to join a table to itself. This type of join is called Self join. It is one of the type of inner join where both the columns belong to the same table. In this Join, we need to open two copies of a same table in the memory. Since the table name is the same for both instances, we use the table aliases to make identical copies of the same table to be open in different memory locations.</p>

<p><strong>Outer Join</strong><br />
This type of join is needed when we need to select all the rows from the table on the left (or right or both) regardless of whether the other table has common values or not and it usually enter null values for the data which is missing.</p>

<p><strong>The Outer join can be of three types</strong></p>

<ol>
	<li>Left Outer Join</li>
	<li>Right Outer Join</li>
	<li>Full Outer Join</li>
</ol>

<p><strong>Cross Join:</strong> This join combines all the rows from the left table with every row from the right table. This type of join is needed when we need to select all the possible combinations of rows and columns from both the tables. This type of join is generally not preferred as it takes lot of time and gives a huge result that is not often useful.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
</div>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A800D4E9F5 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (13, 7, N'Diffrence Between Truncate & Delete', N'<p><strong>Diffrence Between Truncate &amp; Delete</strong></p>

<p>Delete command removes the rows from a table based on the condition that we provide with a WHERE clause. Truncate will actually remove all the rows from a table and there will be no data in the table after we run the truncate command.</p>

<p><strong>TRUNCATE:</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>TRUNCATE is faster and uses fewer system and transaction log resources than DELETE.</li>
	<li>TRUNCATE removes the data by deallocating the data pages used to store the table&#39;s data, and only the page deallocations are recorded in the transaction log.</li>
	<li>TRUNCATE removes all rows from a table, but the table structure, its columns, constraints, indexes and so on, remains. The counter used by an identity for new rows is reset to the seed for the column.</li>
	<li>You cannot use TRUNCATE TABLE on a table referenced by a FOREIGN KEY constraint. Because TRUNCATE TABLE is not logged, it cannot activate a trigger.</li>
	<li>TRUNCATE cannot be rolled back.</li>
	<li>TRUNCATE is DDL Command.</li>
	<li>TRUNCATE Resets identity of the table</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>DELETE:</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>DELETE removes rows one at a time and records an entry in the transaction log for each deleted row.</li>
	<li>If you want to retain the identity counter, use DELETE instead. If you want to remove table definition and its data, use the DROP TABLE statement.</li>
	<li>DELETE Can be used with or without a WHERE clause</li>
	<li>DELETE Activates Triggers.</li>
	<li>DELETE can be rolled back.</li>
	<li>DELETE is DML Command.</li>
	<li>DELETE does not reset identity of the table.</li>
</ul>

<p>DELETE and TRUNCATE both can be rolled back when surrounded by TRANSACTION if the current session is not closed. If TRUNCATE is written in Query Editor surrounded by TRANSACTION and if session is closed, it can not be rolled back but DELETE can be rolled back.</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>What is a table called, if it has neither Cluster nor Non-cluster Index? What is it used for?</strong></span></p>

<div class="tech-answer">
<p>Unindexed table or Heap. Microsoft Press Books and Book on Line (BOL) refers it as Heap. A heap is a table that does not have a clustered index and, therefore, the pages are not linked by pointers. The IAM pages are the only structures that link the pages in a table together. Unindexed tables are good for fast storing of data. Many times it is better to drop all indexes from table and then do bulk of inserts and to restore those indexes after that.</p>
</div>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A800D74B67 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (14, 7, N'Views', N'<p><strong>What is a View in SQL Server?</strong><br />
You can think of a view either as a compiled sql query or a virtual table. As a view represents a virtual table, it does not physically store any data. When you query a view, you actually retrieve the data from the underlying base tables.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>What are the advantages of using views?<br />
Or<br />
When do you usually use views?</strong><br />
1. Views can be used to implement row level and column level security.<br />
2. Simplify the database schema to the users. You can create a view based on multiple tables which join columns from all these multiple tables so that they look like a single table.<br />
3. Views can be used to present aggregated and summarized data.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Can you create a view based on other views?</strong><br />
Yes, you can create a view based on other views. Usually we create views based on tables, but it also possible to create views based on views.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Can you update views?</strong><br />
Yes, views can be updated. However, updating a view that is based on multiple tables, may not update the underlying tables correctly. To correctly update a view that is based on multiple tables you can make use INSTEAD OF triggers in SQL Server.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>What are indexed views?<br />
Or<br />
What are materialized views?</strong><br />
A view is a virtual table, it does not contain any physical data. A view is nothing more than compiled SQL query. Every time, we issue a select query against a view, we actually get the data from the underlying base tables and not from the view, as the view itself does not contain any data.<br />
When you create an index on a view, the data gets physically stored in the view. So, when we issue a select query against an indexed view, the data is retrieved from the index without having to go to the underlying table, which will make the select statement to work slightly faster. However, the disadvantage is, INSERT, UPDATE and DELETE operations will become a little slow, because every time you insert or delete a row from the underlying table, the view index needs to be updated. Inshort, DML operations will have negative impact on performance.<br />
Oracle refers to indexed views as materialized views.<br />
Only the views created with schema binding, can have an Index. Simply adding WITH SCHEMABINDING to the end of the CREATE VIEW statement will accomplish this. However, the effect is that any changes to the underlying tables which will impact the view are not allowed. Since the indexed view is stored physically, any schema changes would impact the schema of the stored results set. Therefore, SQL Server requires that schema binding be used to prevent the view&#39;s schema (and therefore the underlying tables) from changing.<br />
The first index for a view must be a UNIQUE CLUSTERED INDEX, after which, it&#39;s possible to create non-clustered indexes against the view.<br />
Indexed Views are heavily used in data warehouses and reporting databases that are not highly transactional.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>What are the limitations of a View?</strong><br />
1. You cannot pass parameters to a view.<br />
2. Rules and Defaults cannot be associated with views.<br />
3. The ORDER BY clause is invalid in views unless TOP or FOR XML is also specified.<br />
4. Views cannot be based on temporary tables.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A8011ED058 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (15, 7, N'Normalization and Normal Forms', N'<p><strong>Normalization and Normal Forms</strong></p>

<p>It is set of rules that have been established to aid in the design of tables that are meant to be connected through relationships. This set of rules is known as Normalization.</p>

<p><strong>Benefits of Normalizing your database include:</strong></p>

<ol>
	<li>Avoiding repetitive entries</li>
	<li>Reducing required storage space</li>
	<li>Preventing the need to restructure existing tables to accommodate new data</li>
	<li>Increased speed and flexibility of queries, sorts, and summaries</li>
</ol>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>First Normal Form</strong></span></p>

<p>For a table to be in first normal form, data must be broken up into the smallest units possible. In addition to breaking data up into the smallest meaningful values, tables in first normal form should not contain repetitions groups of fields.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/database/SQLInterviewQuestions/image015.png" /></p>

<p><strong>Figure 1.8: Repeating groups example</strong></p>

<p>In the above example, city1 and city2 are repeating. In order for these tables to be in First normal form, you have to modify the table structure as follows. Also note that the Customer Name is now broken down to first name and last name (First normal form data should be broken down to the smallest unit).</p>

<p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p>

<p><strong>Figure 1.9: Customer table normalized to first normal form</strong></p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>Second Normal Form</strong></span></p>

<p>The second normal form states that each field in a multiple field primary key table must be directly related to the entire primary key. In other words, each non-key field should be a fact about all the fields in the primary key.</p>

<p>In the above table of customer, city is not linked to any primary field.</p>

<p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p>

<p><strong>Figure 1.10: Normalized customer table.</strong></p>

<p><strong><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></strong></p>

<p><strong>Figure 1.11: City is now shifted to a different master table.</strong></p>

<p><br />
That takes our database to a second normal form.</p>

<p><strong>Third Normal Form</strong></p>

<p>A non-key field should not depend on another Non-key field. The field Total is dependent on Unit price and qty.</p>

<p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p>

<p><strong>Figure 1.12: Fill third normal form</strong></p>

<p>So now the Total field is removed and is the multiplication of Unit price * Qty.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A801271A08 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (16, 8, N'Advantages & Disadvantages of Sql Triggers.', N'<p><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Disadvantages:</strong></span></p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Performance</strong> - triggers have a small overhead over having the logic in the stored procedure</li>
	<li>Triggers work over tempdb, so extensive use of them needs to be taken into account when thinking about tempdb</li>
	<li>Sometimes it takes time to remember you have a trigger when something weird happens after data is updated/inserted to the table</li>
	<li>Also, triggers are a part of the transaction which triggered them - can be thought of both of an advantage and a disadvantage.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Advantages of trigger:</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>Triggers can be used as an alternative method for implementing referential integrity constraints.</li>
	<li>By using triggers, business rules and transactions are easy to store in database and can be used consistently even if there are future updates to the database.</li>
	<li>It controls on which updates are allowed in a database.</li>
	<li>When a change happens in a database a trigger can adjust the change to the entire database.</li>
	<li>Triggers are used for calling stored procedures.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Disadvantages of trigger:</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>Programmers don&rsquo;t have full control: Since business rules are hidden, programmers don&rsquo;t have full control over the database. BY this, a program can generate several actions.</li>
	<li>Increase in complexity: Triggers increase the complexity of a database as they have hard coded rules already implemented.</li>
	<li>Decrease in performance of the database: By the complex nature of the database programs take more time to execute and there can be hidden performance downtimes.</li>
</ul>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A801376A8E AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (17, 7, N'Sql Server Triggers', N'<h2 style="font-style:normal; text-align:start">What is a Trigger</h2>

<p style="text-align:start">A trigger is a special kind of a store procedure that executes in response to certain action on the table like insertion, deletion or updation of data. It is a database object which is bound to a table and is executed automatically. You can&rsquo;t explicitly invoke triggers. The only way to do this is by performing the required action no the table that they are assigned to.</p>

<h2 style="font-style:normal; text-align:start">Types Of Triggers</h2>

<p style="text-align:start">There are three action query types that you use in SQL which are INSERT, UPDATE and DELETE. So, there are three types of triggers and hybrids that come from mixing and matching the events and timings that fire them. Basically, triggers are classified into two main types:</p>

<ol>
	<li>After Triggers (For Triggers)</li>
	<li>Instead Of Triggers</li>
</ol>

<h2 style="font-style:normal; text-align:start">(i) After Triggers</h2>

<p><span style="background-color:rgb(255, 255, 255); color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">These triggers run after an insert, update or delete on a table. They are </span><strong>not supported for views.</strong><span style="background-color:rgb(255, 255, 255); color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px"> </span><br />
<span style="background-color:rgb(255, 255, 255); color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">AFTER TRIGGERS can be classified further into three types as:</span></p>

<ol>
	<li>AFTER INSERT Trigger.</li>
	<li>AFTER UPDATE Trigger.</li>
	<li>AFTER DELETE Trigger.</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:start">Let&rsquo;s create After triggers. First of all, let&rsquo;s create a table and insert some sample data. Then, on this table, I will be attaching several triggers.</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain812442" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
CREATE TABLE Employee_Test
(
Emp_ID INT Identity,
Emp_name Varchar(<span style="color:navy">100</span>),
Emp_Sal Decimal (<span style="color:navy">10</span>,<span style="color:navy">2</span>)
)

INSERT INTO Employee_Test VALUES (<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">Anees&#39;</span>,<span style="color:navy">1000</span>);
INSERT INTO Employee_Test VALUES (<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">Rick&#39;</span>,<span style="color:navy">1200</span>);
INSERT INTO Employee_Test VALUES (<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">John&#39;</span>,<span style="color:navy">1100</span>);
INSERT INTO Employee_Test VALUES (<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">Stephen&#39;</span>,<span style="color:navy">1300</span>);
INSERT INTO Employee_Test VALUES (<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">Maria&#39;</span>,<span style="color:navy">1400</span>);</pre>

<p style="text-align:start">I will be creating an AFTER INSERT TRIGGER which will insert the rows inserted into the table into another audit table. The main purpose of this audit table is to record the changes in the main table. This can be thought of as a generic audit trigger.</p>

<p style="text-align:start">Now, create the audit table as:-</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain485233" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
CREATE TABLE Employee_Test_Audit
(
Emp_ID <span style="color:blue">int</span>,
Emp_name varchar(<span style="color:navy">100</span>),
Emp_Sal decimal (<span style="color:navy">10</span>,<span style="color:navy">2</span>),
Audit_Action varchar(<span style="color:navy">100</span>),
Audit_Timestamp datetime
)</pre>

<h2 style="font-style:normal; text-align:start">(a) After Insert Trigger</h2>

<p style="text-align:start">This trigger is fired after an INSERT on the table. Let&rsquo;s create the trigger as:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain911268" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
<span style="color:blue">CREATE</span> <span style="color:blue">TRIGGER</span> trgAfterInsert <span style="color:blue">ON</span> [dbo].[Employee_Test] 
<span style="color:blue">FOR</span> <span style="color:blue">INSERT</span>
<span style="color:blue">AS</span>
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @empid int;
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @empname <span style="color:blue">varchar</span>(<span style="color:navy">100</span>);
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @empsal <span style="color:blue">decimal</span>(<span style="color:navy">10</span>,<span style="color:navy">2</span>);
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @audit_action <span style="color:blue">varchar</span>(<span style="color:navy">100</span>);

	<span style="color:blue">select</span> @empid=i.Emp_ID <span style="color:blue">from</span> inserted i;	
	<span style="color:blue">select</span> @empname=i.Emp_Name <span style="color:blue">from</span> inserted i;	
	<span style="color:blue">select</span> @empsal=i.Emp_Sal <span style="color:blue">from</span> inserted i;	
	<span style="color:blue">set</span> @audit_action=<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">Inserted Record -- After Insert Trigger.&#39;</span>;

	<span style="color:blue">insert</span> <span style="color:blue">into</span> Employee_Test_Audit
           (Emp_ID,Emp_Name,Emp_Sal,Audit_Action,Audit_Timestamp) 
	<span style="color:blue">values</span>(@empid,@empname,@empsal,@audit_action,getdate());

	<span style="color:blue">PRINT</span> <span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">AFTER INSERT trigger fired.&#39;</span>
<span style="color:blue">GO</span></pre>

<p style="text-align:start">The <code>CREATE TRIGGER</code> statement is used to create the trigger. <code>THE ON</code> clause specifies the table name on which the trigger is to be attached. The <code>FOR INSERT</code> specifies that this is an <code>AFTER INSERT</code> trigger. In place of <code>FOR INSERT</code>, <code>AFTER INSERT</code> can be used. Both of them mean the same.</p>

<p style="text-align:start">In the trigger body, table named <strong>inserted </strong>has been used. This table is a logical table and contains the row that has been inserted. I have selected the fields from the logical inserted table from the row that has been inserted into different variables, and finally inserted those values into the Audit table.</p>

<p style="text-align:start">To see the newly created trigger in action, lets insert a row into the main table as:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain59034" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
 insert into Employee_Test values(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">Chris&#39;</span>,<span style="color:navy">1500</span>);</pre>

<p style="text-align:start">Now, a record has been inserted into the Employee_Test table. The <code>AFTER INSERT</code> trigger attached to this table has inserted the record into the Employee_Test_Audit as:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain399275" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
<span style="color:navy">6</span>   Chris  <span style="color:navy">1500</span>.<span style="color:navy">00</span>   Inserted Record -- After Insert Trigger.	<span style="color:navy">2008</span>-<span style="color:navy">04</span>-<span style="color:navy">26</span> <span style="color:navy">12</span>:<span style="color:navy">00</span>:<span style="color:navy">55</span>.<span style="color:navy">700</span></pre>

<h2 style="font-style:normal; text-align:start">(b) AFTER UPDATE Trigger</h2>

<p style="text-align:start">This trigger is fired after an update on the table. Let&rsquo;s create the trigger as:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain700635" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
<span style="color:blue">CREATE</span> <span style="color:blue">TRIGGER</span> trgAfterUpdate <span style="color:blue">ON</span> [dbo].[Employee_Test] 
<span style="color:blue">FOR</span> <span style="color:blue">UPDATE</span>
<span style="color:blue">AS</span>
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @empid int;
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @empname <span style="color:blue">varchar</span>(<span style="color:navy">100</span>);
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @empsal <span style="color:blue">decimal</span>(<span style="color:navy">10</span>,<span style="color:navy">2</span>);
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @audit_action <span style="color:blue">varchar</span>(<span style="color:navy">100</span>);

	<span style="color:blue">select</span> @empid=i.Emp_ID <span style="color:blue">from</span> inserted i;	
	<span style="color:blue">select</span> @empname=i.Emp_Name <span style="color:blue">from</span> inserted i;	
	<span style="color:blue">select</span> @empsal=i.Emp_Sal <span style="color:blue">from</span> inserted i;	
	
	<span style="color:blue">if</span> <span style="color:blue">update</span>(Emp_Name)
		<span style="color:blue">set</span> @audit_action=<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">Updated Record -- After Update Trigger.&#39;</span>;
	<span style="color:blue">if</span> <span style="color:blue">update</span>(Emp_Sal)
		<span style="color:blue">set</span> @audit_action=<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">Updated Record -- After Update Trigger.&#39;</span>;

	<span style="color:blue">insert</span> <span style="color:blue">into</span> Employee_Test_Audit(Emp_ID,Emp_Name,Emp_Sal,Audit_Action,Audit_Timestamp) 
	<span style="color:blue">values</span>(@empid,@empname,@empsal,@audit_action,getdate());

	<span style="color:blue">PRINT</span> <span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">AFTER UPDATE Trigger fired.&#39;</span>
<span style="color:blue">GO</span></pre>

<p style="text-align:start">The AFTER UPDATE Trigger is created in which the updated record is inserted into the audit table. There is <strong>no logical table updated like the logical table inserted.</strong> We can obtain the updated value of a field from the<code>update(column_name)</code> function. In our trigger, we have used, <code>if update(Emp_Name)</code> to check if the column Emp_Name has been updated. We have similarly checked the column Emp_Sal for an update.</p>

<p style="text-align:start">Let&rsquo;s update a record column and see what happens.</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain334567" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
 update Employee_Test set Emp_Sal=1550 where Emp_ID=6</pre>

<p style="text-align:start">This inserts the row into the audit table as:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain385448" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
<span style="color:navy">6</span>  Chris  <span style="color:navy">1550</span>.<span style="color:navy">00</span>  Updated Record -- After Update Trigger.	  <span style="color:navy">2008</span>-<span style="color:navy">04</span>-<span style="color:navy">26</span> <span style="color:navy">12</span>:<span style="color:navy">38</span>:<span style="color:navy">11</span>.<span style="color:navy">843</span></pre>

<h2 style="font-style:normal; text-align:start">(c) AFTER DELETE Trigger</h2>

<p style="text-align:start">This trigger is fired after a delete on the table. Let&rsquo;s create the trigger as:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain521377" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
<span style="color:blue">CREATE</span> <span style="color:blue">TRIGGER</span> trgAfterDelete <span style="color:blue">ON</span> [dbo].[Employee_Test] 
AFTER <span style="color:blue">DELETE</span>
<span style="color:blue">AS</span>
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @empid int;
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @empname <span style="color:blue">varchar</span>(<span style="color:navy">100</span>);
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @empsal <span style="color:blue">decimal</span>(<span style="color:navy">10</span>,<span style="color:navy">2</span>);
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @audit_action <span style="color:blue">varchar</span>(<span style="color:navy">100</span>);

	<span style="color:blue">select</span> @empid=d.Emp_ID <span style="color:blue">from</span> deleted d;	
	<span style="color:blue">select</span> @empname=d.Emp_Name <span style="color:blue">from</span> deleted d;	
	<span style="color:blue">select</span> @empsal=d.Emp_Sal <span style="color:blue">from</span> deleted d;	
	<span style="color:blue">set</span> @audit_action=<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">Deleted -- After Delete Trigger.&#39;</span>;

	<span style="color:blue">insert</span> <span style="color:blue">into</span> Employee_Test_Audit
(Emp_ID,Emp_Name,Emp_Sal,Audit_Action,Audit_Timestamp) 
	<span style="color:blue">values</span>(@empid,@empname,@empsal,@audit_action,getdate());

	<span style="color:blue">PRINT</span> <span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">AFTER DELETE TRIGGER fired.&#39;</span>
<span style="color:blue">GO</span></pre>

<p style="text-align:start">In this trigger, the deleted record&rsquo;s data is picked from the <strong>logical deleted table</strong> and inserted into the audit table. Let&rsquo;s fire a delete on the main table. A record has been inserted into the audit table as:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain268393" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
 <span style="color:navy">6</span>  Chris	<span style="color:navy">1550</span>.<span style="color:navy">00</span>  Deleted -- After Delete Trigger.  <span style="color:navy">2008</span>-<span style="color:navy">04</span>-<span style="color:navy">26</span> <span style="color:navy">12</span>:<span style="color:navy">52</span>:<span style="color:navy">13</span>.<span style="color:navy">867</span></pre>

<p style="text-align:start">All the triggers can be enabled/disabled on the table using the statement</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain158179" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
ALTER TABLE Employee_Test {ENABLE|DISBALE} TRIGGER ALL</pre>

<p style="text-align:start">Specific Triggers can be enabled or disabled as:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain925961" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
ALTER TABLE Employee_Test DISABLE TRIGGER trgAfterDelete</pre>

<p style="text-align:start">This disables the After Delete Trigger named <code>trgAfterDelete</code> on the specified table.</p>

<h2 style="font-style:normal; text-align:start">(ii) Instead Of Triggers</h2>

<p style="text-align:start">These can be used as an interceptor for anything that anyone tried to do on our table or view. If you define an<em>Instead Of trigger</em> on a table for the Delete operation, they try to delete rows, and they will not actually get deleted (unless you issue another delete instruction from within the trigger)</p>

<p style="text-align:start">INSTEAD OF TRIGGERS can be classified further into three types as:</p>

<ol>
	<li>INSTEAD OF INSERT Trigger.</li>
	<li>INSTEAD OF UPDATE Trigger.</li>
	<li>INSTEAD OF DELETE Trigger.</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:start">Let&rsquo;s create an Instead Of Delete Trigger as:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain905725" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
<span style="color:blue">CREATE</span> <span style="color:blue">TRIGGER</span> trgInsteadOfDelete <span style="color:blue">ON</span> [dbo].[Employee_Test] 
INSTEAD <span style="color:blue">OF</span> <span style="color:blue">DELETE</span>
<span style="color:blue">AS</span>
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @emp_id int;
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @emp_name <span style="color:blue">varchar</span>(<span style="color:navy">100</span>);
	<span style="color:blue">declare</span> @emp_sal int;
	
	<span style="color:blue">select</span> @emp_id=d.Emp_ID <span style="color:blue">from</span> deleted d;
	<span style="color:blue">select</span> @emp_name=d.Emp_Name <span style="color:blue">from</span> deleted d;
	<span style="color:blue">select</span> @emp_sal=d.Emp_Sal <span style="color:blue">from</span> deleted d;

	<span style="color:blue">BEGIN</span>
		<span style="color:blue">if</span>(@emp_sal&gt;1200)
		<span style="color:blue">begin</span>
			<span style="color:blue">RAISERROR</span>(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">Cannot delete where salary &gt; 1200&#39;</span>,<span style="color:navy">16</span>,<span style="color:navy">1</span>);
			ROLLBACK;
		<span style="color:blue">end</span>
		<span style="color:blue">else</span>
		<span style="color:blue">begin</span>
			<span style="color:blue">delete</span> <span style="color:blue">from</span> Employee_Test <span style="color:blue">where</span> Emp_ID=@emp_id;
			COMMIT;
			<span style="color:blue">insert</span> <span style="color:blue">into</span> Employee_Test_Audit(Emp_ID,Emp_Name,Emp_Sal,Audit_Action,Audit_Timestamp)
			<span style="color:blue">values</span>(@emp_id,@emp_name,@emp_sal,<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">Deleted -- Instead Of Delete Trigger.&#39;</span>,getdate());
			<span style="color:blue">PRINT</span> <span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">Record Deleted -- Instead Of Delete Trigger.&#39;</span>
		<span style="color:blue">end</span>
	<span style="color:blue">END</span>
<span style="color:blue">GO</span></pre>

<p style="text-align:start">This trigger will prevent the deletion of records from the table where Emp_Sal &gt; 1200. If such a record is deleted, the Instead Of Trigger will rollback the transaction, otherwise the transaction will be committed. Now, let&rsquo;s try to delete a record with the Emp_Sal &gt;1200 as:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain313182" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
<span style="color:blue">delete</span> from Employee_Test where Emp_ID=4</pre>

<p style="text-align:start">This will print an error message as defined in the <code>RAISE ERROR</code> statement as:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain729293" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); display: block; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; width: 700px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</div>

<pre style="text-align:start">
Server: Msg <span style="color:navy">50000</span>, Level <span style="color:navy">16</span>, State <span style="color:navy">1</span>, Procedure trgInsteadOfDelete, Line <span style="color:navy">15</span>
Cannot <span style="color:blue">delete</span> where salary &gt; <span style="color:navy">1200</span></pre>

<p style="text-align:start">And this record will not be deleted.</p>

<p style="text-align:start">In a similar way, you can code Instead of Insert and Instead Of Update triggers on your tables.</p>

<h2 style="font-style:normal; text-align:start">Conclusion</h2>

<p style="text-align:start">In this article, I took a brief introduction of triggers, explained the various kinds of triggers &ndash; After Triggers and Instead Of Triggers along with their variants and explained how each of them works. I hope you will get a clear understanding about the Triggers in SQL Server and their usage.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A8013A4808 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (18, 6, N'Object Oriented Programming', N'<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="color:#800000"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>What is object-oriented programming (OOP) Language?</strong></span></span></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="background-color:rgb(255, 255, 255); color:rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family:verdana,geneva,sans-serif; font-size:12px">Object-oriented programming (OOP) is a programming language model organized around objects rather than &quot;actions&quot; and data rather than logic. Historically, a program has been viewed as a logical procedure that takes input data, processes it, and produces output data.</span></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="color:#800000"><span style="font-size:14px"><span style="background-color:rgb(255, 255, 255); font-family:inherit"><strong>Types of comments in C#?</strong></span></span></span></p>

<p style="margin-left:40px; text-align:justify"><strong><span style="background-color:rgb(255, 255, 255); color:rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family:verdana,geneva,sans-serif; font-size:12px">1. Single line comments</span></strong>:</p>

<p style="margin-left:80px; text-align:justify"><span style="background-color:rgb(255, 255, 255); color:rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family:verdana,geneva,sans-serif; font-size:12px">// for single line comments</span></p>

<p style="margin-left:40px; text-align:justify"><strong><span style="background-color:rgb(255, 255, 255); color:rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family:verdana,geneva,sans-serif; font-size:12px">2. Multiple line comments</span></strong></p>

<p style="margin-left:80px; text-align:justify"><span style="background-color:rgb(255, 255, 255); color:rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family:verdana,geneva,sans-serif; font-size:12px">/* for multi line comments */</span></p>

<p style="margin-left:40px; text-align:justify"><strong><span style="background-color:rgb(255, 255, 255); color:rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family:verdana,geneva,sans-serif; font-size:12px">3. XML tags comments</span></strong></p>

<p style="margin-left:80px; text-align:justify"><span style="background-color:rgb(255, 255, 255); color:rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family:verdana,geneva,sans-serif; font-size:12px">/// XML tags displayed in a code comment</span><br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="font-size:14px"><span style="color:rgb(128, 0, 0)"><strong>What is a Class?</strong></span></span><br />
A set or category of things having some property or attribute in common and differentiated from others by kind, type, or quality.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="font-size:14px"><span style="color:rgb(128, 0, 0)"><strong>What is object?</strong></span></span><br />
Objects are created from Classes, in C#, is an instance of a class that is created dynamically. Object is also a keyword that is an alias for the predefined type System.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="font-size:14px"><span style="color:rgb(128, 0, 0)"><strong>What is Constructors, explain with syntax?</strong></span></span><br />
A is special method of the class that will be automatically invoked when an instance of the class is created is called as constructor.Constructors are mainly used to initialize private fields of the class while creating an instance for the class.When you are not creating a constructor in the class, then compiler will automatically create a default constructor in the class that initializes all numeric fields in the class to zero and all string and object fields to null.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="color:#008080"><strong>Syntax.<br />
[Access Modifier] ClassName([Parameters])<br />
{<br />
}</strong></span></p>
