<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="color:#800000"><strong><span style="font-size:14px">Types of Constructors</span>?</strong></span><br />
Basically constructors are 5 types those are</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Default Constructor</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Parameterized Constructor</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Copy Constructor</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Static Constructor</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Private Constructor</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="color:#800000"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Index value of the first element in an array?</strong></span></span><br />
first element is 0 (zero). In a Array.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="color:#800000"><strong><span style="font-size:14px">Different between method overriding and&nbsp; method overloading?</span></strong></span><br />
In Overriding methods it will create two or more methods with same name and same parameter in different classes, while Overloading it will create more then one method with same name but different parameter in same class.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="color:#800000"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Explain use of Abstract and Sealed Classes in C#?</strong></span></span><br />
The abstract keyword enables you to create classes and class members that are incomplete and must be implemented in a derived class.The sealed keyword enables you to prevent the inheritance of a class or certain class members that were previously marked virtual.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="color:#800000"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>What is Static Classes?</strong></span></span><br />
A static class is basically the same as a non-static class, but there is one difference: a static class cannot be instantiated. In other words, you cannot use the new keyword to create a variable of the class type. Because there is no instance variable, you access the members of a static class by using the class name itself.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><span style="color:#800000"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Explain Static Class Members.</strong></span></span><br />
A non-static class can contain static methods, fields, properties, or events.The static member is callable on a class even when no instance of the class has been created. The static member is always accessed by the class name, not the instance name. Only one copy of a static member exists, regardless of how many instances of the class are created.Static methods and properties cannot access non-static fields and events in their containing type, and they cannot access an instance variable of any object unless it is explicitly passed in a method parameter.</p>

<p><span style="font-size:14px"><span style="color:rgb(128, 0, 0)"><strong>Which are Access Modifiers available in C#?</strong></span></span><br />
All types and type members have an accessibility level, which controls whether they can be used from other code in your assembly or other assemblies.You can use the following access modifiers to specify the accessibility of a type or member when you declare it:</p>

<ol>
	<li><strong>public</strong>: The type or member can be accessed by any other code in the same assembly or another assembly that references it.</li>
	<li><strong>private</strong>: The type or member can be accessed only by code in the same class or struct.</li>
	<li><strong>protected</strong>: The type or member can be accessed only by code in the same class or struct, or in a class that is derived from that class.</li>
	<li><strong>internal</strong>: The type or member can be accessed by any code in the same assembly, but not from another assembly.</li>
</ol>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Data Types in C#?</strong></span></span><br />
bool, byte , char, decimal , double, float, int, long, sbyte , short, uint, ulong, ushort.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A80144C796 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (19, 4, N'Generics', N'<p><strong>Generics</strong></p>

<p>Generics were added to version 2.0 of the C# language and the common language runtime (CLR). Generics introduce to the .NET Framework the concept of type parameters, which make it possible to design classes and methods that defer the specification of one or more types until the class or method is declared and instantiated by client code. For example, by using a generic type parameter T you can write a single class that other client code can use without incurring the cost or risk of runtime casts or boxing operations as shown below.</p>

<pre>
<span style="color:green">// Declare the generic class.&nbsp;</span>
<span style="color:blue">public</span>&nbsp;<span style="color:blue">class</span> GenericList&lt;T&gt;
{
    <span style="color:blue">void</span> Add(T input) { }
}
<span style="color:blue">class</span> TestGenericList
{
    <span style="color:blue">private</span>&nbsp;<span style="color:blue">class</span> ExampleClass { }
    <span style="color:blue">static</span>&nbsp;<span style="color:blue">void</span> Main()
    {
        <span style="color:green">// Declare a list of type int.</span>
        GenericList&lt;<span style="color:blue">int</span>&gt; list1 = <span style="color:blue">new</span> GenericList&lt;<span style="color:blue">int</span>&gt;();

        <span style="color:green">// Declare a list of type string.</span>
        GenericList&lt;<span style="color:blue">string</span>&gt; list2 = <span style="color:blue">new</span> GenericList&lt;<span style="color:blue">string</span>&gt;();

        <span style="color:green">// Declare a list of type ExampleClass.</span>
        GenericList&lt;ExampleClass&gt; list3 = <span style="color:blue">new</span> GenericList&lt;ExampleClass&gt;();
    }
}</pre>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Generics Overview</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>Use generic types to maximize code reuse, type safety, and performance.</li>
	<li>The most common use of generics is to create collection classes.</li>
	<li>The .NET Framework class library contains several new generic collection classes in the System.Collections.Generic namespace. These should be used whenever possible instead of classes such as ArrayList in the System.Collections namespace.</li>
	<li>You can create your own generic interfaces, classes, methods, events and delegates.</li>
	<li>Generic classes may be constrained to enable access to methods on particular data types.</li>
	<li>Information on the types that are used in a generic data type may be obtained at run-time by using reflection.</li>
</ul>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A901396A88 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (20, 4, N'Benefits of Generics (C# Programming Guide)', N'<h1>Benefits of Generics (C# Programming Guide)</h1>

<div class="lw_vs" style="position: relative; margin-top: -8px; margin-bottom: 35px; padding-bottom: 2px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', ''Lucida Grande'', Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 17.5499992370605px;">
<div id="curversion" style="float: left; color: rgb(93, 93, 93);">&nbsp;</div>

<div id="versionclick" style="float: left;">
<div style="float: left;">
<div style="float: left;">Other Versions</div>

<div class="cl_vs_arrow clip10x10" style="position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 10px; height: 10px; margin-top: 5px; margin-right: 5px; cursor: pointer; float: left;"><img alt="" class="cl_lw_vs_arrow" id="vsArrow" src="https://i-msdn.sec.s-msft.com/Areas/Epx/Content/Images/ImageSprite.png?v=635677640249401973" style="border:0px; height:auto; left:-533px; margin:0px; padding:0px; position:absolute; top:-3px; width:auto" /></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<div style="color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', ''Lucida Grande'', Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 17.5499992370605px; clear: both;">&nbsp;</div>

<div id="mainSection" style="clear: both; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', ''Lucida Grande'', Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 17.5499992370605px;">
<div id="mainBody">
<div class="introduction">
<p>Generics provide the solution to a limitation in earlier versions of the common language runtime and the C# language in which generalization is accomplished by casting types to and from the universal base type&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.object.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">Object</a>. By creating a generic class, you can create a collection that is type-safe at compile-time.</p>

<p>The limitations of using non-generic collection classes can be demonstrated by writing a short program that uses the&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.collections.arraylist.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">ArrayList</a>&nbsp;collection class from the .NET Framework class library.&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.collections.arraylist.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">ArrayList</a>&nbsp;is a highly convenient collection class that can be used without modification to store any reference or value type.</p>

<div>
<div class="codeSnippetContainer" id="code-snippet-1" style="min-width: 260px; clear: both;">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerTabs" style="vertical-align: middle; height: 23px; position: relative; z-index: 1;">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerTabSingle" dir="ltr" style="font-size: 1em; line-height: 17px; height: 23px; float: left; width: auto; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(112, 112, 112); position: relative; border-width: 1px; border-style: solid; border-color: rgb(147, 147, 147) rgb(147, 147, 147) rgb(255, 255, 255); border-top-left-radius: 4px; border-top-right-radius: 4px; top: auto; left: auto;">C#</div>
</div>

<div class="codeSnippetContainerCodeContainer" style="border: 1px solid rgb(147, 147, 147); clear: both; margin-bottom: 12px; position: relative; top: -1px;">
<div class="codeSnippetToolBar" style="width: auto; height: auto;">
<div class="codeSnippetToolBarText" style="float: right; top: -8px; position: relative; width: auto; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0px; height: 0px; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</div>
</div>

<div class="codeSnippetContainerCode" dir="ltr" id="CodeSnippetContainerCode_2722cbcc-a9ad-48fb-8c0e-c84c264044eb" style="width: auto; margin: 0px; padding: 10px 21px;">
<div style="padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
<pre>
<span style="color:green">// The .NET Framework 1.1 way to create a list:</span>
System.Collections.ArrayList list1 = <span style="color:blue">new</span> System.Collections.ArrayList();
list1.Add(3);
list1.Add(105);

System.Collections.ArrayList list2 = <span style="color:blue">new</span> System.Collections.ArrayList();
list2.Add(<span style="color:rgb(163, 21, 21)">&quot;It is raining in Redmond.&quot;</span>);
list2.Add(<span style="color:rgb(163, 21, 21)">&quot;It is snowing in the mountains.&quot;</span>);
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<p>But this convenience comes at a cost. Any reference or value type that is added to an&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.collections.arraylist.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">ArrayList</a>&nbsp;is implicitly upcast to&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.object.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">Object</a>. If the items are value types, they must be boxed when they are added to the list, and unboxed when they are retrieved. Both the casting and the boxing and unboxing operations decrease performance; the effect of boxing and unboxing can be very significant in scenarios where you must iterate over large collections.</p>

<p>The other limitation is lack of compile-time type checking; because an&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.collections.arraylist.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">ArrayList</a>&nbsp;casts everything to&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.object.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">Object</a>, there is no way at compile-time to prevent client code from doing something such as this:</p>

<div>
<div class="codeSnippetContainer" id="code-snippet-2" style="min-width: 260px; clear: both;">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerTabs" style="vertical-align: middle; height: 23px; position: relative; z-index: 1;">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerTabSingle" dir="ltr" style="font-size: 1em; line-height: 17px; height: 23px; float: left; width: auto; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(112, 112, 112); position: relative; border-width: 1px; border-style: solid; border-color: rgb(147, 147, 147) rgb(147, 147, 147) rgb(255, 255, 255); border-top-left-radius: 4px; border-top-right-radius: 4px; top: auto; left: auto;">C#</div>
</div>

<div class="codeSnippetContainerCodeContainer" style="border: 1px solid rgb(147, 147, 147); clear: both; margin-bottom: 12px; position: relative; top: -1px;">
<div class="codeSnippetToolBar" style="width: auto; height: auto;">
<div class="codeSnippetToolBarText" style="float: right; top: -8px; position: relative; width: auto; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0px; height: 0px; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</div>
</div>

<div class="codeSnippetContainerCode" dir="ltr" id="CodeSnippetContainerCode_9f532ea5-d5c5-4ee0-b254-02143920dcf7" style="width: auto; margin: 0px; padding: 10px 21px;">
<div style="padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
<pre>
System.Collections.ArrayList list = <span style="color:blue">new</span> System.Collections.ArrayList();
<span style="color:green">// Add an integer to the list.</span>
list.Add(3);
<span style="color:green">// Add a string to the list. This will compile, but may cause an error later.</span>
list.Add(<span style="color:rgb(163, 21, 21)">&quot;It is raining in Redmond.&quot;</span>);

<span style="color:blue">int</span> t = 0;
<span style="color:green">// This causes an InvalidCastException to be returned.&nbsp;</span>
<span style="color:blue">foreach</span> (<span style="color:blue">int</span> x <span style="color:blue">in</span> list)
{
    t += x;
}
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<p>Although perfectly acceptable and sometimes intentional if you are creating a heterogeneous collection, combining strings and&nbsp;<strong>ints</strong>&nbsp;in a single&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.collections.arraylist.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">ArrayList</a>&nbsp;is more likely to be a programming error, and this error will not be detected until runtime.</p>

<p>In versions 1.0 and 1.1 of the C# language, you could avoid the dangers of generalized code in the .NET Framework base class library collection classes only by writing your own type specific collections. Of course, because such a class is not reusable for more than one data type, you lose the benefits of generalization, and you have to rewrite the class for each type that will be stored.</p>

<p>What&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.collections.arraylist.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">ArrayList</a>&nbsp;and other similar classes really need is a way for client code to specify, on a per-instance basis, the particular data type that they intend to use. That would eliminate the need for the upcast to&nbsp;<strong>T:System.Object</strong>&nbsp;and would also make it possible for the compiler to do type checking. In other words,&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.collections.arraylist.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">ArrayList</a>&nbsp;needs a type parameter. That is exactly what generics provide. In the generic&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/6sh2ey19.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">List&lt;T&gt;</a>&nbsp;collection, in the&nbsp;<strong>N:System.Collections.Generic</strong>&nbsp;namespace, the same operation of adding items to the collection resembles this:</p>

<div>
<div class="codeSnippetContainer" id="code-snippet-3" style="min-width: 260px; clear: both;">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerTabs" style="vertical-align: middle; height: 23px; position: relative; z-index: 1;">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerTabSingle" dir="ltr" style="font-size: 1em; line-height: 17px; height: 23px; float: left; width: auto; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(112, 112, 112); position: relative; border-width: 1px; border-style: solid; border-color: rgb(147, 147, 147) rgb(147, 147, 147) rgb(255, 255, 255); border-top-left-radius: 4px; border-top-right-radius: 4px; top: auto; left: auto;">C#</div>
</div>

<div class="codeSnippetContainerCodeContainer" style="border: 1px solid rgb(147, 147, 147); clear: both; margin-bottom: 12px; position: relative; top: -1px;">
<div class="codeSnippetToolBar" style="width: auto; height: auto;">
<div class="codeSnippetToolBarText" style="float: right; top: -8px; position: relative; width: auto; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0px; height: 0px; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</div>
</div>

<div class="codeSnippetContainerCode" dir="ltr" id="CodeSnippetContainerCode_e630bfeb-dff2-4304-8904-00ddac4a47d8" style="width: auto; margin: 0px; padding: 10px 21px;">
<div style="padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
<pre>
<span style="color:green">// The .NET Framework 2.0 way to create a list</span>
List&lt;<span style="color:blue">int</span>&gt; list1 = <span style="color:blue">new</span> List&lt;<span style="color:blue">int</span>&gt;();

<span style="color:green">// No boxing, no casting:</span>
list1.Add(3);

<span style="color:green">// Compile-time error:&nbsp;</span>
<span style="color:green">// list1.Add(&quot;It is raining in Redmond.&quot;);</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<p>For client code, the only added syntax with&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/6sh2ey19.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">List&lt;T&gt;</a>&nbsp;compared to&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.collections.arraylist.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">ArrayList</a>&nbsp;is the type argument in the declaration and instantiation. In return for this slightly more coding complexity, you can create a list that is not only safer than&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.collections.arraylist.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(3, 105, 122);">ArrayList</a>, but also significantly faster, especially when the list items are value types.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (21, 4, N'Difference Between ArrayList and Generic List in C#', N'<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;"><span style="color:#800000"><strong>Difference Between ArrayList and Generic List in C#</strong></span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;"><strong><u>ArrayList</u></strong></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;">1. ArrayList belongs to the&nbsp;<u>System.Collections</u>&nbsp;namespace, i.e. you need to import the following namespace.</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;"><strong>C#</strong></div>

<div class="code_block" style="box-sizing: border-box; border: 1px solid rgb(225, 225, 232); padding: 5px; word-break: break-all; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; background-color: rgb(245, 242, 240) !important;">
<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:blue; font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">using</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&nbsp;System.Collections;</span></div>
</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 10px 0in 8pt;">2. ArrayList does not have type restriction for storing data i.e. it is not Type Safe. You can store anything in ArrayList. In fact same ArrayList can store multiple types of objects.</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;"><strong>C#</strong></div>

<div class="code_block" style="box-sizing: border-box; border: 1px solid rgb(225, 225, 232); padding: 5px; word-break: break-all; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; background-color: rgb(245, 242, 240) !important;">
<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">ArrayList</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&nbsp;arrList =&nbsp;<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">new</span>&nbsp;<span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">ArrayList</span>();</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">arrList.Add(921);</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">arrList.Add(<span style="color:rgb(163, 21, 21); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">&quot;Mudassar Khan&quot;</span>);</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">arrList.Add(<span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">DateTime</span>.Now);</span></div>
</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 10px 0in 8pt;">&nbsp;</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 10px 0in 8pt;">3. ArrayList stores all data as object thus to get it back you must remember what you stored where and correspondingly Type Cast it as per its original Type when stored.</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;"><strong>C#</strong></div>

<div class="code_block" style="box-sizing: border-box; border: 1px solid rgb(225, 225, 232); padding: 5px; word-break: break-all; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; background-color: rgb(245, 242, 240) !important;">
<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:blue; font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">int</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&nbsp;number =&nbsp;<span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">Convert</span>.ToInt32(arrList[0]);</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:blue; font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">string</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&nbsp;name = arrList[1].ToString();</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">DateTime</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&nbsp;dt =&nbsp;<span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">Convert</span>.ToDateTime(arrList[2]);</span></div>
</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: normal;">&nbsp;</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;">4. ArrayList is mainly for .Net 2.0 Framework projects as during that period Generic List was not invented.</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;">5. While running a Loop on ArrayList you need to use Object data type. Thus this is another disadvantage as you again do not know what type of data particular item contains.</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;"><strong>C#</strong></div>

<div class="code_block" style="box-sizing: border-box; border: 1px solid rgb(225, 225, 232); padding: 5px; word-break: break-all; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; background-color: rgb(245, 242, 240) !important;">
<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:blue; font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">foreach</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&nbsp;(<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">object</span>&nbsp;o&nbsp;<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">in</span>&nbsp;arrList)</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">{</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;">&nbsp;</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">}</span></div>
</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 10px 0in 8pt;"><strong><u>Generic Lists (List&lt;T&gt;)</u></strong></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;">1. Generic List (List&lt;T&gt;) belongs to the&nbsp;<u>System.Collections.Generic</u>&nbsp;namespace, i.e. you need to import the following namespace.</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;"><strong>C#</strong></div>

<div class="code_block" style="box-sizing: border-box; border: 1px solid rgb(225, 225, 232); padding: 5px; word-break: break-all; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; background-color: rgb(245, 242, 240) !important;">
<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:blue; font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">using</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&nbsp;System.Collections.Generic;</span></div>
</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 10px 0in 8pt;">&nbsp;</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 10px 0in 8pt;">2. In Generic List (List&lt;T&gt;), T means data type, i.e. string, int, DateTime, etc. Thus it will store only specific types of objects based on what data type has been specified while declarations i.e. it is Type Safe. Thus if you have a Generic List of string you can only store string values, anything else will give compilation error.</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;">Below I had no option other than having three different Generic Lists for three different data types.</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;"><strong>C#</strong></div>

<div class="code_block" style="box-sizing: border-box; border: 1px solid rgb(225, 225, 232); padding: 5px; word-break: break-all; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; background-color: rgb(245, 242, 240) !important;">
<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">List</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&lt;<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">string</span>&gt; lstString =&nbsp;<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">new</span>&nbsp;<span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">List</span>&lt;<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">string</span>&gt;();</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">lstString.Add(<span style="color:rgb(163, 21, 21); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">&quot;Mudassar Khan&quot;</span>);</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">lstString.Add(<span style="color:rgb(163, 21, 21); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">&quot;Robert Hammond&quot;</span>);</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">lstString.Add(<span style="color:rgb(163, 21, 21); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">&quot;Ramesh Singh&quot;</span>);</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;">&nbsp;</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">List</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&lt;<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">int</span>&gt; lstInt =&nbsp;<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">new</span>&nbsp;<span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">List</span>&lt;<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">int</span>&gt;();</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">lstInt.Add(991);</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">lstInt.Add(10);</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">lstInt.Add(4450);</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;">&nbsp;</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">List</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&lt;<span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">DateTime</span>&gt; lstDateTime =&nbsp;<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">new</span>&nbsp;<span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">List</span>&lt;<span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">DateTime</span>&gt;();</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">lstDateTime.Add(<span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">DateTime</span>.Now);</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">lstDateTime.Add(<span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">DateTime</span>.Now.AddDays(20));</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">lstDateTime.Add(<span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">DateTime</span>.Now.AddHours(-10));</span></div>
</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 10px 0in 8pt;">3. Generic List stores all data of the data type it is declared thus to getting the data back is hassle free and no type conversions required.</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;"><strong>C#</strong></div>

<div class="code_block" style="box-sizing: border-box; border: 1px solid rgb(225, 225, 232); padding: 5px; word-break: break-all; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; background-color: rgb(245, 242, 240) !important;">
<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:blue; font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">int</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&nbsp;number = lstInt[0];</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:blue; font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">string</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&nbsp;name = lstString[0];</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">DateTime</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&nbsp;dt = lstDateTime[0];</span></div>
</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 10px 0in 8pt;">4. Generic List must be used instead of ArrayList unless specific requirement for projects higher than .Net 2.0 Framework.</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;">5. While running a Loop on Generic List again it is problem free as we exactly know what the List contains.</div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; margin: 0in 0in 8pt;"><strong>C#</strong></div>

<div class="code_block" style="box-sizing: border-box; border: 1px solid rgb(225, 225, 232); padding: 5px; word-break: break-all; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: sans-serif; font-size: 14.6666669845581px; line-height: 20.9523811340332px; background-color: rgb(245, 242, 240) !important;">
<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:blue; font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">foreach</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&nbsp;(<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">int</span>&nbsp;number&nbsp;<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">in</span>&nbsp;lstInt)</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">{</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">}</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:blue; font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">foreach</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&nbsp;(<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">string</span>&nbsp;name&nbsp;<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">in</span>&nbsp;lstString)</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">{</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">}</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="color:blue; font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">foreach</span><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">&nbsp;(<span style="color:rgb(43, 145, 175); font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">DateTime</span>&nbsp;dt&nbsp;<span style="color:blue; font-family:inherit; font-size:11pt !important">in</span>&nbsp;lstDateTime)</span></div>

<div style="box-sizing: border-box; font-family: ''Courier New'' !important; font-size: 11pt !important;"><span style="font-family:courier new; font-size:9.5pt">{</span></div>
