INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (22, 4, N'Various types of generic collections', N'<h2 style="text-align:justify">Various types of generic collections</h2>

<p style="text-align:justify">There are basically four different types of generic collections which are as follows:-</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">1.&nbsp;<strong>List:-</strong>Lists are indexed based Generic Collections.&nbsp;Lists are Generic form of ArrayList.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">List helps us to create flexible strong type collection as you can see in below code snippet i have defined List as &quot;int&quot; and &quot;string&quot;.</p>

<pre style="text-align:justify">
//index based Generic collection&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
List&lt;int&gt; ObjInt = new List&lt;int&gt;();&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
ObjInt.Add(123);&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
ObjInt.Add(456);&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
Console.WriteLine(ObjInt[0]); //accessing the List by internal index based value.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
List&lt;string&gt; ObjString = new List&lt;string&gt;();&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
ObjString.Add(&quot;feroz&quot;);</pre>

<p style="text-align:justify">2.&nbsp;<strong>Dictionary:-</strong>Dictionary are key based generics collection.<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Dictionary are generic form of Hashtable.</p>

<pre style="text-align:justify">
&nbsp;//key based Generic collection&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
Dictionary&lt;int, int&gt; ObjDict = new Dictionary&lt;int,int&gt;();&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
ObjDict.Add(1,2);&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
Dictionary&lt;int, string&gt; ObjDict1 = new Dictionary&lt;int,string&gt;();&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
ObjDict1.Add(3, &quot;feroz is a developer&quot;);&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
ObjDict1.Add(4, &quot;wasim is a developer&quot;);&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
Console.WriteLine(ObjDict1[3]); //accessing the dictionary by defined key.</pre>

<p style="text-align:justify">3.&nbsp;<strong>Stack:-</strong>Stack generic collection allows you to get value in &quot;LIFO&quot;(last in first out) manner.</p>

<pre style="text-align:justify">
// Stack &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
Stack&lt;string&gt; ObjStack = new Stack&lt;string&gt;();&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
ObjStack.Push(&quot;feroz&quot;);&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
ObjStack.Push(&quot;moosa&quot;);&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
Console.WriteLine(ObjStack.Pop());</pre>

<p style="text-align:justify">4.&nbsp;<strong>Queue:-</strong>Queue generic collection allows you to get value in &quot;FIFO&quot;(first in first out) manner.</p>

<pre style="text-align:justify">
//Queue&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
Queue&lt;int&gt; ObjStr = new Queue&lt;int&gt;();&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
ObjStr.Enqueue(789);&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
ObjStr.Enqueue(456);&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
Console.WriteLine(ObjStr.Dequeue());</pre>

<p style="text-align:justify"><img src="http://dotnetinterviewquestion.files.wordpress.com/2011/05/1a8.jpg" style="background:transparent; border:0px; height:265px; margin:0px; outline:0px; padding:0px; vertical-align:baseline; width:854px" /></p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A90146B1DD AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (23, 4, N'Hashtable vs. Dictionary', N'<h1>Hashtable vs. Dictionary</h1>

<h2>HashTable</h2>

<p>Hashtable optimizes lookups. It computes a hash of each key you add. It then uses this hash code to look up the element very quickly. It is an older .NET Framework type. It is slower than the generic&nbsp;<code>Dictionary</code>&nbsp;type.</p>

<h4>Example:</h4>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain500210" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
<span style="color:blue">using</span> System.Collections;
<span style="color:blue">class</span> Program
{
    <span style="color:blue">static</span> Hashtable GetHashtable()
    {
        <em>//</em><em> Create and return new Hashtable.
</em>        Hashtable hashtable = <span style="color:blue">new</span> Hashtable();
        hashtable.Add(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">Area&quot;</span>, <span style="color:navy">1000</span>);
        hashtable.Add(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">Perimeter&quot;</span>, <span style="color:navy">55</span>);
        hashtable.Add(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">Mortgage&quot;</span>, <span style="color:navy">540</span>);
        <span style="color:blue">return</span> hashtable;
    }
    <span style="color:blue">public</span>  <span style="color:blue">static</span> <span style="color:blue">void</span> Main()
    {
        Hashtable hashtable = GetHashtable();
        <em>//</em><em> See if the Hashtable contains this key.
</em>        Console.WriteLine(hashtable.ContainsKey(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">Perimeter&quot;</span>));
        <em>//</em><em> Test the Contains method. It works the same way.
</em>        Console.WriteLine(hashtable.Contains(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">Area&quot;</span>));
        <em>//</em><em> Get value of Area with indexer.
</em>        <span style="color:blue">int</span> value = (<span style="color:blue">int</span>)hashtable[<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">Area&quot;</span>];
        <em>//</em><em> Write the value of Area.
</em>        Console.WriteLine(value);
    }
}</pre>

<h5>Output:</h5>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain737618" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
True
True
1000</pre>

<h2>Dictionary</h2>

<p>A dictionary is used where fast lookups are critical. The&nbsp;<code>Dictionary</code>&nbsp;type provides fast lookups with keys to get values. With it we use keys and values of any type, including&nbsp;<code>int</code>s and&nbsp;<code>string</code>s. Dictionary requires a special syntax form.</p>

<p>Dictionary is used when we have many different elements. We specify its key type and its value type. It provides good performance.</p>

<h4>Example:</h4>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain243453" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
<span style="color:blue">class</span> Dict
{
    <span style="color:blue">static</span> <span style="color:blue">void</span> Main()
    {
       <em>//</em><em> Example Dictionary again
</em>       Dictionary&lt;<span style="color:blue">string</span>, <span style="color:blue">int</span>&gt; d = <span style="color:blue">new</span> Dictionary&lt;<span style="color:blue">string</span>, <span style="color:blue">int</span>&gt;()
       {
           {<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">Lion&quot;</span>, <span style="color:navy">2</span>},  {<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">dog&quot;</span>, <span style="color:navy">1</span>}};
           <em>//</em><em> Loop over pairs with foreach
</em>           <span style="color:blue">foreach</span> (KeyValuePair&lt;<span style="color:blue">string</span>, <span style="color:blue">int</span>&gt; pair <span style="color:blue">in</span> d)
           {
               Console.WriteLine (<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">{0}, {1}&quot;</span>,pair.Key,  pair.Value);
           }
           <span style="color:blue">foreach</span> (<span style="color:blue">var</span> pair <span style="color:blue">in</span> d)
           {
               Console.WriteLine(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">{0}, {1}&quot;</span>, pair.Key, pair.Value);
           }
           Console.ReadKey();
       }
    }</pre>

<h2>Differences between Hashtable and&nbsp;Dictionary</h2>

<h4>Dictionary:</h4>

<ul>
	<li>It returns error if we try to find a key which does not exist.</li>
	<li>It is faster than a Hashtable because there is no boxing and unboxing.</li>
	<li>Only public static members are thread safe.</li>
	<li>Dictionary is a generic type which means we can use it with any&nbsp;data type.</li>
</ul>

<h4>Hashtable:</h4>

<ul>
	<li>It returns null if we try to find a key which does not exist.</li>
	<li>It is slower than dictionary because it requires boxing and unboxing.</li>
	<li>All the members in a Hashtable are thread safe,</li>
	<li>Hashtable is not a generic type,</li>
</ul>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A90148F49E AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (24, 1, N'Difference between NameSpace and Assembly', N'<p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color:#800000"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Difference between NameSpace and Assembly</strong></span></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Namespace</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Namespaces is a logical group of related classes that can be used by any other language targeting the Microsoft .Net framework . It is more used for logical organization of your classes. Namespaces are a way of grouping type names and reducing the chance of name collisions.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Assembly</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">An assembly is a collection of types and resources that are built to work together and form a logical unit of functionality. It is an Output Unit, that is .exe or .dll file. It is a unit of Deployment and a unit of versioning and also it contain MSIL (Microsoft Intermediate Language) code. Assemblies are self describing, it contains all the metadata about the modules, types, and other elements in the form of a manifest.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Assemblies are of two types: Private and Shared Assemblies.</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Private Assemblies</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Private assembly is intended only for one application. The files of that assembly must be placed in the same folder of the application.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Shared Assemblies</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Shared assembly is to be made into a Shared Assembly, then the naming conventions are very strict since it has to be unique across the entire system</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A9014D5360 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (25, 2, N'Application Pool & Worker Process', N'<p><strong>Introduction to Application Pool</strong><br />
<br />
<span style="font-family:roboto,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Application Pools are logical groupings of web applications that will execute in a common process, thereby allowing greater granularity of which programs are grouped together in a single process. For instance, if you wanted every Web Application to execute in a separate process, you simply create an Application Pool for each application. The Application Pool is the heart of a website. Application Pools enable us to isolate our Web Application for better security, reliability and availability. The worker process serves as the process boundary that separates each Application Pool so that when a worker process or application is having an issue or recycles, other applications or worker processes are not affected.</span><br />
<br />
<img alt="Application Pool" src="http://www.c-sharpcorner.com/UploadFile/225740/introduction-to-application-pool-in-iis/Images/Application%20Pool.jpg" style="border:none; font-family:roboto,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:21px; outline:none 0px" /><br />
<br />
<span style="font-family:roboto,sans-serif; font-size:14px">The maximum number of Application Pools that is supported by IIS is 2000.&nbsp;</span><br />
<br />
<strong>Introduction to Web Garden</strong><br />
<br />
<span style="font-family:roboto,sans-serif; font-size:14px">An Application Pool with multiple worker processes is called a Web Garden. Many worker processes with the same Application Pool can sometimes provide better throughput performance and application response time.</span><br />
<br />
<img alt="IIS" src="http://www.c-sharpcorner.com/UploadFile/225740/introduction-to-application-pool-in-iis/Images/iis.jpg" style="border:none; font-family:roboto,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:21px; outline:none 0px" /><br />
<br />
<span style="font-family:roboto,sans-serif; font-size:14px">A Web Garden is a site configured to run within multiple processes on a single server. You can still have multiple servers configured in a web farm, but the Web Garden reflects the configuration of a specific individual server. Now I am explaining how to deploy a Web Site on IIS.</span></p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4A9014FD875 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (26, 1, N'Assemblies', N'<p><strong>Assemblies </strong></p>

<p><strong>Assemblies</strong>: Assemblies are the basic building blocks required for any application to function in the .NET realm. They are partially compiled code libraries that form the fundamental unit of deployment, versioning, activation scoping, reuse, and security. Typically, assemblies provide a collection of types and resources that work together to form a logical unit of functionality. They are the smallest deployable units of code in .NET. Compared to the executable files assemblies are far more reliable, more secure, and easy to manage. An assembly contains a lot more than the Microsoft Intermediate Language (MSIL) code that is compiled and run by the Common Language Runtime (CLR). In other words, you can say that an assembly is a set of one or more modules and classes compiled in MSIL, and metadata that describes the assembly itself, as well as the functionalities of the assembly classes.</p>

<p><strong>Different components of an assembly.</strong></p>

<p>An assembly is a logical unit that is made up of the following four different types of components:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Assembly manifest</li>
	<li>MSIL source code</li>
	<li>Type metadata</li>
	<li>Resources</li>
</ol>

<p><strong>What are the different types of assemblies? Explain them in detail.</strong></p>

<p>The following are the two types of assemblies:</p>

<ol>
	<li><strong>Private Assembly</strong> - Refers to the assembly that is used by a single application. Private assemblies are kept in a local folder in which the client application has been installed.</li>
	<li><strong>Public or Shared Assembly</strong> - Refers to the assembly that is allowed to be shared by multiple applications. A shared assembly must reside in Global Assembly Cache (GAC) with a strong name assigned to it.</li>
</ol>

<p>For example, imagine that you have created a DLL containing information about your business logic. This DLL can be used by your client application. In order to run the client application, the DLL must be included in the same folder in which the client application has been installed. This makes the assembly private to your application. Now suppose that the DLL needs to be reused in different applications. Therefore, instead of copying the DLL in every client application folder, it can be placed in the global assembly cache using the GAC tool. These assemblies are called shared assemblies.</p>

<p><strong>Can one DLL file contain the compiled code of more than one .NET language?</strong></p>

<p>No, a DLL file can contain the compiled code of only one programming language.</p>

<p><strong>What is the maximum number of classes that can be contained in a DLL file?</strong></p>

<p>There is no limit to the maximum number of classes that can be contained in a DLL file.</p>

<p><strong>What is a satellite assembly?</strong></p>

<p>Satellite assemblies are assemblies that are used to deploy language and culture specific resources for an application. In an application, a separate product ID is assigned to each language and a satellite assembly is installed in a language specific sub-directory.</p>

<p><strong>Is versioning applicable to private assemblies?</strong></p>

<p>No, versioning is not applicable to private assemblies as these assemblies reside in their individual folders. Versioning can be applied to GAC only.</p>

<p><strong>What is metadata?</strong></p>

<p>An assembly metadata describes every data type and member defined in the code. It stores the description of an assembly, such as name, version, culture, public key of an assembly along with the types exported, other assemblies dependent on this assembly, and security permissions needed to run the application. In addition, it stores the description of types, such as the name, visibility, base class, interfaces implemented, and members, such as methods, fields, properties, events, and nested types.</p>

<p>It also stores attributes. Metadata is stored in binary format. Therefore, metadata of an assembly is sharable among applications that execute on various platforms. It can also be exported to other applications to give information about the services and various features of an application.</p>

<p><strong>What is Assembly Manifest?</strong></p>

<p>Assemblies maintain all their information in a special unit called the manifest. Every assembly has a manifest.</p>

<p>The followings are the contents of an Assembly Manifest:</p>

<ol>
	<li><strong>Assembly name</strong> - Represents a text string that specifies the assembly&#39;s name.</li>
	<li><strong>Version number</strong> - Represents a major and minor version number, as well as a revision and builds number. The CL.R makes use of these numbers to enforce version policy.</li>
	<li><strong>Culture -</strong> Represents information of the culture or language, which the assembly supports. An assembly is a container of only resources containing culture- or language-specific information.</li>
	<li><strong>Strong name information</strong> - Represents the public key from the publisher, if a strong name is assigned to an assembly.</li>
	<li><strong>List of all files in the assembly</strong> - Represents a hash of each file contained in the assembly and a file name.</li>
	<li><strong>Type reference information</strong> - Represents the information used at the runtime to map a type reference to the file that contains its declaration and implementation.</li>
	<li><strong>Information on referenced assemblies</strong> - Represents a list of other assemblies that are statically referenced by the assembly. Each reference includes the names of dependent assemblies, assembly metadata (version, culture, operating system, and so on), and public key, if the assembly is strong named.</li>
</ol>

<p><strong>What is the value of the Copy Local property when you add an assembly in the GAC?</strong></p>

<p>False.</p>

<p><strong>What is Native Image Generator?</strong></p>

<p>The Native Image Generator (Ngen.exe) is a tool that creates a native image from an assembly and stores that image to native image cache on the computer. Whenever, an assembly is run, this native image is automatically used to compile the original assembly. In this way, this tool improves the performance of the managed application by loading and executing an assembly faster.</p>

<p>Note that native images are files that consist of compiled processor-specific machine code. The Ngen.exe tool installs these files on to the local computer.</p>

<p><strong>Name the MSIL Disassembler utility that parses any .NET Framework assembly and shows the information in human readable format</strong></p>

<p>The Ildasm.exe utility.</p>

<p><strong>What is the significance of the Strong Name tool?</strong></p>

<p>The Strong Name utility (sn.exe) helps in creating unique public-private key pair files that are called strong name files and signing assemblies with them. It also allows key management, signature generation, and signature verification.</p>

<p><strong>How can different versions of private assemblies be used in the same application without a re-build?</strong></p>

<p>You can use different versions of private assemblies in the same application without a re-build by specifying the assembly version in the AssemblyInfo.cs or AssemblyInfo.vb file.</p>

<p><strong>What is Global Assembly Cache (GAC) ?</strong></p>

<p>GAC is a central repository (cache) in a system in which assemblies are registered to share among various applications that execute on local or remote machines. .NET Framework provides the GAC tool (gacutil.exe utility), which is used to view and change the content of GAC of a system. Adding new assemblies to GAC and removing assemblies from GAC are some of the tasks that can be performed by using the gacutil.exe utility. GAC can contain multiple versions of the same .NET assembly. CLR checks GAC for a requested assembly before using information of configuration files.</p>

<p>The gacutil.exe /i &lt;assembly name&gt; - is the command that is used to install an assembly in GAC. Users use the Command Prompt of Visual Studio to install an assembly in GAC by using this command.</p>

<p>You can see all the assemblies installed in the GAC using the GAC viewer, which is located at the &lt;WinDrive&gt;:&lt;WinDir&gt;\assembly directory, where &lt;WinDir&gt; is windows in Windows XP or windows in Windows Vista or WinNT in Windows 2000. Apart from the list of assemblies, the assembly viewer also shows relevant information, such as the global assembly name, version, culture, and the public key token.</p>

<p><strong>Where is the information regarding the version of the assembly stored?</strong></p>

<p>Information for the version of assembly is stored inside the assembly manifest.</p>

<p><strong>Discuss the concept of strong names.</strong></p>

<p>Whenever, an assembly is deployed in GAC to make it shared, a strong name needs to be assigned to it for its unique identification. A strong name contains an assembly&#39;s complete identity - the assembly name, version number, and culture information of an assembly. A public key and a digital signature, generated over the assembly, are also contained in a strong name. A strong name makes an assembly identical in GAC.</p>

<p>&nbsp;<strong>What is the difference between .EXE and .DLL files?</strong></p>

<p>EXE</p>

<ul>
	<li>It is an executable file, which can be run independently.</li>
	<li>EXE is an out-process component, which means that it runs in a separate process.</li>
	<li>It cannot be reused in an application.</li>
	<li>It has a main function.</li>
</ul>

<p>DLL</p>

<ul>
	<li>It is Dynamic Link Library that is used as a part of EXE or other DLLs. It cannot be run independently.</li>
	<li>It runs in the application process memory, so it is called as in-process component.</li>
	<li>It can be reused in an application.</li>
	<li>It does not have a main function.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Which utility allows you to reference an assembly in an application?</strong></p>

<p>An assembly can be referenced by using the gacutil.exe utility with the /r option. The /r option requires a reference type, a reference ID, and a description.</p>

<p><strong>The AssemblyInfo.cs file stores the assembly configuration information and other information, such as the assembly name, version, company name, and trademark information. (True/False)? </strong>True.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AB015BD083 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (27, 1, N'Framework Interview Questions', N'<p><strong>Common Language Runtime (CLR):</strong></p>

<p>The most important part of the .NET Framework is the .Net Common Language Runtime (CLR) also called .Net Runtime in short. It is a framework layer that resides above the Operating System and handles/manages the execution of the .NET applications. Our .Net programs don&#39;t directly communicate with the Operating System but through CLR.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>MSIL (Microsoft Intermediate Language) Code:</strong></p>

<p>When we compile our .Net Program using any .Net compliant language like (C#, <a href="http://VB.NET" target="_blank">VB.NET</a>, C++.NET) it does not get converted into the executable binary code but to an intermediate code, called MSIL or IL in short, understandable by CLR. MSIL is an OS and H/w independent code. When the program needs to be executed, this MSIL or intermediate code is converted to binary executable code, called native code. The presence of IL makes it possible the Cross Language Relationship as all the .Net compliant languages produce the similar standard IL code.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Just In Time Compilers (JITers):</strong></p>

<p>When our IL compiled code needs to be executed, CLR invokes JIT compilers which compile the IL code to native executable code (.exe or .dll) for the specific machine and OS. JITers in many ways are different from traditional compilers as they, as their name suggests, compile the IL to native code only when desired e.g., when a function is called, IL of function&#39;s body is converted to native code; just in time of need. So, the part of code that is not used by particular run is not converted to native code. If some IL code is converted to native code then the next time when its needed to be used, the CLR uses the same copy without re-compiling. So, if a program runs for sometime, then it won&#39;t have any just in time performance penalty. As JITers are aware of processor and OS exactly at runtime, they can optimize the code extremely efficiently resulting in very robust applications. Also, since JITer knows the exact current state of executable code, they can also optimize the code by in-lining small function calls (like replacing body of small function when its called in a loop, saving the function call time). Although, Microsoft stated that C# and .Net are not competing with languages like C++ in efficiency, speed of execution, JITers can make your code even faster than C++ code in some cases when program is run over extended period of time (like web-servers).</p>

<p><strong>Framework Class Library (FCL):</strong></p>

<p>.NET Framework provides huge set of Framework (or Base) Class Library (FCL) for common, usual tasks. FCL contains thousands of classes to provide the access to Windows API and common functions like String Manipulation, Common Data Structures, IO, Streams, Threads, Security, Network Programming, Windows Programming, Web Programming, Data Access, etc. It is simply the largest standard library ever shipped with any development environment or programming language. The best part of this library is they follow extremely efficient OO design (design patterns) making their access and use very simple and predictable. You can use the classes in FCL in your program just as you use any other class and can even apply inheritance and polymorphism on these.</p>

<p><strong>Common Language Specification (CLS):</strong></p>

<p>Earlier we used the term &#39;.NET Compliant Language&#39; and stated that all the .NET compliant languages can make use of CLR and FCL. But what makes a language &#39;.NET compliant language&#39;? The answer is Common Language Specification (CLS). Microsoft has released a small set of specification that each language should meet to qualify as a .NET Compliant Language. As IL is a very rich language, it is not necessary for a language to implement all the IL functionality, rather it meets the small subset of it, CLS, to qualify as a .NET compliant language, which is the reason why so many languages (procedural and OO) are now running under .Net umbrella. CLS basically addresses to language design issues and lays certain standards like there should be no global function declaration, no pointers, no multiple inheritance and things like that. The important point to note here is that if you keep your code within CLS boundary, your code is guaranteed to be usable in any other .Net language.</p>

<p><strong>Common Type System (CTS):</strong></p>

<p>.NET also defines a Common Type System (CTS). Like CLS, CTS is also a set of standards. CTS defines the basic data types that IL understands. Each .NET compliant language should map its data types to these standard data types. This makes it possible for the 2 languages to communicate with each other by passing/receiving parameters to/from each other. For example, CTS defines a type Int32, an integral data type of 32 bits (4 bytes) which is mapped by C# through int and VB.Net through its Integer data type.</p>

<p><strong>Garbage Collector (GC):</strong></p>

<p>CLR also contains Garbage Collector (GC) which runs in a low-priority thread and checks for un-referenced dynamically allocated memory space. If it finds some data that is no more referenced by any variable/reference, it re-claims it and returns the occupied memory back to the Operating System; so that it can be used by other programs as necessary. The presence of standard Garbage Collector frees the programmer from keeping track of dangling data.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AB015DBB58 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (28, 6, N'Classes & Objects', N'<h1><span style="font-size:18px"><strong>Classes</strong></span></h1>

<p>A class is a construct that enables you to create your own custom types by grouping together variables of other types, methods and events. A class is like a blueprint. It defines the data and behavior of a type. If the class is not declared as static, client code can use it by creating objects or instances which are assigned to a variable. The variable remains in memory until all references to it go out of scope. At that time, the CLR marks it as eligible for garbage collection. If the class is declared as <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/98f28cdx.aspx">static</a>, then only one copy exists in memory and client code can only access it through the class itself, not an instance variable.</p>

<div><span style="font-size:18px"><strong>Declaring Classes</strong></span></div>

<div class="sectionblock">
<p>Classes are declared by using the <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/0b0thckt.aspx">class</a> keyword, as shown in the following example:</p>

<div>
<div class="codeSnippetContainer" id="code-snippet-1">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerCodeContainer">
<div style="color:Black;">
<pre>
<span style="color:Blue">public</span>&nbsp;<span style="color:Blue">class</span> Customer
{
    <span style="color:Green">//Fields, properties, methods and events go here...</span>
}
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<p>The class keyword is preceded by the access level. Because <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/yzh058ae.aspx">public</a> is used in this case, anyone can create objects from this class. The name of the class follows the class keyword. The remainder of the definition is the class body, where the behavior and data are defined. Fields, properties, methods, and events on a class are collectively referred to as class members.</p>

<p><span style="font-size:18px"><strong>Creating Objects</strong></span></p>

<p>Although they are sometimes used interchangeably, a class and an object are different things. A class defines a type of object, but it is not an object itself. An object is a concrete entity based on a class, and is sometimes referred to as an instance of a class.</p>

<p>Objects can be created by using the <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/51y09td4.aspx">new</a> keyword followed by the name of the class that the object will be based on, like this:</p>

<div>
<div class="codeSnippetContainer" id="code-snippet-2">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerCode" dir="ltr" id="CodeSnippetContainerCode_b0d0fcfe-9d02-4e4e-8406-37312879c91a">
<div style="color:Black;">
<pre>
Customer object1 = <span style="color:Blue">new</span> Customer();
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<p>When an instance of a class is created, a reference to the object is passed back to the programmer. In the previous example, object1 is a reference to an object that is based on Customer. This reference refers to the new object but does not contain the object data itself. In fact, you can create an object reference without creating an object at all:</p>

<div>
<div class="codeSnippetContainer" id="code-snippet-3">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerCodeContainer">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerCode" dir="ltr" id="CodeSnippetContainerCode_3a438899-8ed5-414a-9b10-c2c851cf11ce">
<div style="color:Black;">
<pre>
Customer object2;
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<p>We do not recommend creating object references such as this one that does not refer to an object because trying to access an object through such a reference will fail at run time. However, such a reference can be made to refer to an object, either by creating a new object, or by assigning it to an existing object, such as this:</p>

<div>
<div class="codeSnippetContainer" id="code-snippet-4">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerCodeContainer">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerCode" dir="ltr" id="CodeSnippetContainerCode_32e4d3cc-41f2-43a3-a9f4-7b261af2628d">
<div style="color:Black;">
<pre>
Customer object3 = <span style="color:Blue">new</span> Customer();
Customer object4 = object3;
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<p>This code creates two object references that both refer to the same object. Therefore, any changes to the object made through object3 will be reflected in subsequent uses of object4. Because objects that are based on classes are referred to by reference, classes are known as reference types.</p>
</div>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AF00B92D47 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (29, 4, N'Inheritance', N'<p><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Inheritance</strong></span></p>

<p>Inheritance enables you to create new classes that reuse, extend, and modify the behavior that is defined in other classes. The class whose members are inherited is called the base class, and the class that inherits those members is called the derived class. A derived class can have only one direct base class. However, inheritance is transitive. If ClassC is derived from ClassB, and ClassB is derived from ClassA, ClassC inherits the members declared in ClassB and ClassA.</p>

<p>Conceptually, a derived class is a specialization of the base class. For example, if you have a base class Animal, you might have one derived class that is named Mammal and another derived class that is named Reptile. A Mammal is an Animal, and a Reptile is an Animal, but each derived class represents different specializations of the base class.</p>

<p>When you define a class to derive from another class, the derived class implicitly gains all the members of the base class, except for its constructors and destructors. The derived class can thereby reuse the code in the base class without having to re-implement it. In the derived class, you can add more members. In this manner, the derived class extends the functionality of the base class.</p>

<p>The following illustration shows a class WorkItem that represents an item of work in some business process. Like all classes, it derives from System.Object and inherits all its methods. WorkItem adds five members of its own. These include a constructor, because constructors are not inherited. Class ChangeRequest inherits from WorkItem and represents a particular kind of work item. ChangeRequest adds two more members to the members that it inherits from WorkItem and from Object. It must add its own constructor, and it also adds originalItemID. Property originalItemID enables the ChangeRequest instance to be associated with the original WorkItem to which the change request applies.</p>

<div class="caption">Class inheritance</div>

<p><br />
<img alt="Class Inheritance" id="Class_Inheritance" src="https://i-msdn.sec.s-msft.com/dynimg/IC176590.png" title="Class Inheritance" /></p>

<p>The following example shows how the class relationships demonstrated in the previous illustration are expressed in C#. The example also shows how WorkItem overrides the virtual method <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/vstudio/system.object.tostring%28v=vs.100%29.aspx">Object.ToString</a>, and how the ChangeRequest class inherits the WorkItem implementation of the method.</p>

<div id="snippetGroup">
<div class="codeSnippetContainer" id="code-snippet-1">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerTabs">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerTabSingle" dir="ltr">C#</div>
</div>

<div class="codeSnippetContainerCodeContainer">
<div class="codeSnippetToolBar">
<div class="codeSnippetToolBarText">&nbsp;</div>
</div>

<div class="codeSnippetContainerCode" dir="ltr" id="CodeSnippetContainerCode_b91ea68f-5aca-4ee6-adb2-c4c30f2606f4">
<div style="color:Black;">
<pre>
<span style="color:Green">// WorkItem implicitly inherits from the Object class.</span>
<span style="color:Blue">public</span> <span style="color:Blue">class</span> WorkItem
{
    <span style="color:Green">// Static field currentID stores the job ID of the last WorkItem that</span>
    <span style="color:Green">// has been created.</span>
    <span style="color:Blue">private</span> <span style="color:Blue">static</span> <span style="color:Blue">int</span> currentID;

    <span style="color:Green">//Properties.</span>
    <span style="color:Blue">protected</span> <span style="color:Blue">int</span> ID { <span style="color:Blue">get</span>; <span style="color:Blue">set</span>; }
    <span style="color:Blue">protected</span> <span style="color:Blue">string</span> Title { <span style="color:Blue">get</span>; <span style="color:Blue">set</span>; }
    <span style="color:Blue">protected</span> <span style="color:Blue">string</span> Description { <span style="color:Blue">get</span>; <span style="color:Blue">set</span>; }
    <span style="color:Blue">protected</span> TimeSpan jobLength { <span style="color:Blue">get</span>; <span style="color:Blue">set</span>; }

    <span style="color:Green">// Default constructor. If a derived class does not invoke a base-</span>
    <span style="color:Green">// class constructor explicitly, the default constructor is called</span>
    <span style="color:Green">// implicitly. </span>
    <span style="color:Blue">public</span> WorkItem()
    {
        ID = 0;
        Title = <span style="color:#A31515">&quot;Default title&quot;</span>;
        Description = <span style="color:#A31515">&quot;Default description.&quot;</span>;
        jobLength = <span style="color:Blue">new</span> TimeSpan();
    }

    <span style="color:Green">// Instance constructor that has three parameters.</span>
    <span style="color:Blue">public</span> WorkItem(<span style="color:Blue">string</span> title, <span style="color:Blue">string</span> desc, TimeSpan joblen)
    {
        <span style="color:Blue">this</span>.ID = GetNextID();
        <span style="color:Blue">this</span>.Title = title;
        <span style="color:Blue">this</span>.Description = desc;
        <span style="color:Blue">this</span>.jobLength = joblen;
    }

    <span style="color:Green">// Static constructor to initialize the static member, currentID. This</span>
    <span style="color:Green">// constructor is called one time, automatically, before any instance</span>
    <span style="color:Green">// of WorkItem or ChangeRequest is created, or currentID is referenced.</span>
    <span style="color:Blue">static</span> WorkItem()
    {
        currentID = 0;
    }


    <span style="color:Blue">protected</span> <span style="color:Blue">int</span> GetNextID()
    {
        <span style="color:Green">// currentID is a static field. It is incremented each time a new</span>
        <span style="color:Green">// instance of WorkItem is created.</span>
        <span style="color:Blue">return</span> ++currentID;
    }

    <span style="color:Green">// Method Update enables you to update the title and job length of an</span>
    <span style="color:Green">// existing WorkItem object.</span>
    <span style="color:Blue">public</span> <span style="color:Blue">void</span> Update(<span style="color:Blue">string</span> title, TimeSpan joblen)
    {
        <span style="color:Blue">this</span>.Title = title;
        <span style="color:Blue">this</span>.jobLength = joblen;
    }

    <span style="color:Green">// Virtual method override of the ToString method that is inherited</span>
    <span style="color:Green">// from System.Object.</span>
    <span style="color:Blue">public</span> <span style="color:Blue">override</span> <span style="color:Blue">string</span> ToString()
    {
        <span style="color:Blue">return</span> String.Format(<span style="color:#A31515">&quot;{0} - {1}&quot;</span>, <span style="color:Blue">this</span>.ID, <span style="color:Blue">this</span>.Title);
    }
}

<span style="color:Green">// ChangeRequest derives from WorkItem and adds a property (originalItemID) </span>
<span style="color:Green">// and two constructors.</span>
<span style="color:Blue">public</span> <span style="color:Blue">class</span> ChangeRequest : WorkItem
{
    <span style="color:Blue">protected</span> <span style="color:Blue">int</span> originalItemID { <span style="color:Blue">get</span>; <span style="color:Blue">set</span>; }

    <span style="color:Green">// Constructors. Because neither constructor calls a base-class </span>
    <span style="color:Green">// constructor explicitly, the default constructor in the base class</span>
    <span style="color:Green">// is called implicitly. The base class must contain a default </span>
    <span style="color:Green">// constructor.</span>

    <span style="color:Green">// Default constructor for the derived class.</span>
    <span style="color:Blue">public</span> ChangeRequest() { }

    <span style="color:Green">// Instance constructor that has four parameters.</span>
    <span style="color:Blue">public</span> ChangeRequest(<span style="color:Blue">string</span> title, <span style="color:Blue">string</span> desc, TimeSpan jobLen,
                         <span style="color:Blue">int</span> originalID)
    {
        <span style="color:Green">// The following properties and the GetNexID method are inherited </span>
        <span style="color:Green">// from WorkItem.</span>
        <span style="color:Blue">this</span>.ID = GetNextID();
        <span style="color:Blue">this</span>.Title = title;
        <span style="color:Blue">this</span>.Description = desc;
        <span style="color:Blue">this</span>.jobLength = jobLen;

        <span style="color:Green">// Property originalItemId is a member of ChangeRequest, but not </span>
        <span style="color:Green">// of WorkItem.</span>
        <span style="color:Blue">this</span>.originalItemID = originalID;
    }
}

<span style="color:Blue">class</span> Program
{
    <span style="color:Blue">static</span> <span style="color:Blue">void</span> Main()
    {
        <span style="color:Green">// Create an instance of WorkItem by using the constructor in the </span>
        <span style="color:Green">// base class that takes three arguments.</span>
        WorkItem item = <span style="color:Blue">new</span> WorkItem(<span style="color:#A31515">&quot;Fix Bugs&quot;</span>,
                                     <span style="color:#A31515">&quot;Fix all bugs in my code branch&quot;</span>,
                                     <span style="color:Blue">new</span> TimeSpan(3, 4, 0, 0));

        <span style="color:Green">// Create an instance of ChangeRequest by using the constructor in</span>
        <span style="color:Green">// the derived class that takes four arguments.</span>
        ChangeRequest change = <span style="color:Blue">new</span> ChangeRequest(<span style="color:#A31515">&quot;Change Base Class Design&quot;</span>,
                                                 <span style="color:#A31515">&quot;Add members to the class&quot;</span>,
                                                 <span style="color:Blue">new</span> TimeSpan(4, 0, 0),
                                                 1);

        <span style="color:Green">// Use the ToString method defined in WorkItem.</span>
        Console.WriteLine(item.ToString());

        <span style="color:Green">// Use the inherited Update method to change the title of the </span>
        <span style="color:Green">// ChangeRequest object.</span>
        change.Update(<span style="color:#A31515">&quot;Change the Design of the Base Class&quot;</span>,
            <span style="color:Blue">new</span> TimeSpan(4, 0, 0));

        <span style="color:Green">// ChangeRequest inherits WorkItem&#39;s override of ToString.</span>
        Console.WriteLine(change.ToString());

        <span style="color:Green">// Keep the console open in debug mode.</span>
        Console.WriteLine(<span style="color:#A31515">&quot;Press any key to exit.&quot;</span>);
        Console.ReadKey();
    }
}
<span style="color:Green">/* Output:
    1 - Fix Bugs
    2 - Change the Design of the Base Class
*/</span>


</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AF00C0A681 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (30, 4, N'Constructor in C#', N'<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Constructor in C#</strong></span></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Constructor is a special method of a class which will invoke automatically whenever instance or object of class is created. Constructors are responsible for object initialization and memory allocation of its class. If we create any class without constructor, the compiler will automatically create one default constructor for that class. There is always at least one constructor in every class.</span></p>

<div><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Here you need to remember that a class can have any number of constructors and constructors don&rsquo;t have any return type, not even void and within a class we can create only one static constructor.</span></div>

<div>&nbsp;</div>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Generally constructor name should be same as class name. If we want to create constructor in a class we need to create a constructor method name same as class name check below sample method for constructor</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<div><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">class SampleA</span></div>

<div><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">{</span></div>

<div style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">public SampleA()</span></div>

<div style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">{</span></div>

<div style="margin-left: 80px;"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Console.WriteLine(&quot;Sample A Test Method&quot;);</span></div>

<div style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">}</span></div>

<div><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">}</span></div>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Types of Constructors</strong></span></span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><strong>Basically constructors are 5 types those are</strong></span></p>

<ol>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Default Constructor</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Parameterized Constructor</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Copy Constructor</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Static Constructor</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Private Constructor</span></li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><strong>Default Constructor</strong> : A constructor without having any parameters called default constructor. In this constructor every instance of the class will be initialized without any parameter values like as shown below.</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">using System;<br />
namespace ConsoleApplication3<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;class Sample<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public string param1, param2;</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public Sample()&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; // Default Constructor<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param1 = &quot;Welcome&quot;;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param2 = &quot;Aspdotnet-Suresh&quot;;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;class Program<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;static void Main(string[] args)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Sample obj=new Sample();&nbsp;&nbsp; // Once object of class created automatically constructor will be called<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(obj.param1);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(obj.param2);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.ReadLine();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">When we run above program it will show output like as shown below</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><strong>Output</strong></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Welcome<br />
Aspdotnet-Suresh</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><strong>Parameterized Constructor:</strong> A constructor with at least one parameter is called as parameterized constructor. In parameterized constructor we can initialize each instance of the class to different values like as shown below</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;using System;<br />
namespace ConsoleApplication3<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;class Sample<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public string param1, param2;</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public Sample(string x, string y)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; // Declaring Parameterized constructor with Parameters<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param1 = x;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param2 = y;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;class Program<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;static void Main(string[] args)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Sample obj=new Sample(&quot;Welcome&quot;,&quot;Aspdotnet-Suresh&quot;);&nbsp;&nbsp; // Parameterized Constructor Called<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(obj.param1 +&quot; to &quot;+ obj.param2);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.ReadLine();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">When we run above program it will show output like as shown below</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">// <strong>Output</strong></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Welcome to Aspdotnet-Suresh</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><strong>Constructor Overloading</strong></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">In c# we can overload constructor by creating another constructor with same method name and different parameters like as shown below</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">using System;<br />
namespace ConsoleApplication3<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;class Sample<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public string param1, param2;</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public Sample()&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; // Default Constructor<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param1 = &quot;Hi&quot;;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param2 = &quot;I am Default Constructor&quot;;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public Sample(string x, string y)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; // Declaring Parameterized constructor with Parameters<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param1 = x;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param2 = y;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;class Program<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;static void Main(string[] args)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Sample obj = new Sample();&nbsp;&nbsp; // Default Constructor will Called<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Sample obj1=new Sample(&quot;Welcome&quot;,&quot;Aspdotnet-Suresh&quot;);&nbsp;&nbsp; // Parameterized Constructor will Called<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(obj.param1 + &quot;, &quot;+obj.param2);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(obj1.param1 +&quot; to &quot; + obj1.param2);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.ReadLine();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">When we run above program it will show output like as shown below</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">// Output</span></p>

<p><br />
<span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Hi, I am Default Constructor<br />
Welcome to Aspdotnet-Suresh</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Copy Constructor</strong></span>: A parameterized constructor that contains a parameter of same class type is called as copy constructor. Main purpose of copy constructor is to initialize new instance to the values of an existing instance. Check below example for this</span></p>

<p><br />
<span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">using System;<br />
namespace ConsoleApplication3<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;class Sample<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public string param1, param2;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public Sample(string x, string y)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param1 = x;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param2 = y;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public Sample(Sample obj)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; // Copy Constructor<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param1 = obj.param1;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param2 = obj.param2;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;class Program<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;static void Main(string[] args)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Sample obj = new Sample(&quot;Welcome&quot;, &quot;Aspdotnet-Suresh&quot;);&nbsp; // Create instance to class Sample<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Sample obj1=new Sample(obj); // Here obj details will copied to obj1<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(obj1.param1 +&quot; to &quot; + obj1.param2);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.ReadLine();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">When we run above program it will show output like as shown below</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">// <strong>Output</strong></span></p>

<p><br />
<span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Welcome to Aspdotnet-Suresh</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><strong>Static Constructor: </strong>When we declared constructor as static it will be invoked only once for any number of instances of the class and it&rsquo;s during the creation of first instance of the class or the first reference to a static member in the class. Static constructor is used to initialize static fields of the class and to write the code that needs to be executed only once.</span></p>

<p><br />
<span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">using System;<br />
namespace ConsoleApplication3<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;class Sample<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public string param1, param2;</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;static Sample()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(&quot;Static Constructor&quot;);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public Sample()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param1 = &quot;Sample&quot;;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param2 = &quot;Instance Constructor&quot;;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;class Program<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;static void Main(string[] args)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// Here Both Static and instance constructors are invoked for first instance<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Sample obj=new Sample();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(obj.param1 + &quot; &quot; + obj.param2);</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// Here only instance constructor will be invoked<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Sample obj1 = new Sample();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(obj1.param1 +&quot; &quot; + obj1.param2);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.ReadLine();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">When we run above program we will get output like as shown below</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">// <strong>Output</strong><br />
Static Constructor<br />
Sample Instance Constructor<br />
Sample Instance Constructor</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><strong>Importance points of static constructor</strong></span></p>

<ul>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Static constructor will not accept any parameters because it is automatically called by CLR.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Static constructor will not have any access modifiers.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Static constructor will execute automatically whenever we create first instance of class</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Only one static constructor will allowed.</span></li>
</ul>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><strong>Private Constructor:</strong> Private constructor is a special instance constructor used in a class that contains static member only. If a class has one or more private constructor and no public constructor then other classes is not allowed to create instance of this class this mean we can neither create the object of the class nor it can be inherit by other class. The main purpose of creating private constructor is used to restrict the class from being instantiated when it contains every member as static.</span></p>

<p><br />
<span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">using System;<br />
namespace ConsoleApplication3<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public class Sample<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public string param1, param2;</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public Sample(string a,string b)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param1 = a;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;param2 = b;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;private Sample()&nbsp; // Private Constructor Declaration<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(&quot;Private Constructor with no prameters&quot;);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;class Program<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;static void Main(string[] args)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// Here we don&#39;t have chance to create instace for private constructor<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Sample obj = new Sample(&quot;Welcome&quot;,&quot;to Aspdotnet-Suresh&quot;);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(obj.param1 +&quot; &quot; + obj.param2);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.ReadLine();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">// Output</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Welcome to Aspdotnet-Suresh</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">In above method we can create object of class with parameters will work fine. If create object of class without parameters it will not allow us create.</span></p>

<p><br />
<span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">/ it will works fine<br />
Sample obj = new Sample(&quot;Welcome&quot;,&quot;to Aspdotnet-Suresh&quot;);<br />
// it will not work because of inaccessability<br />
Sample obj=new Sample();</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Important points of private constructor</strong></span></span></p>

<ul>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">One use of private construct is when we have only static member.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Once we provide a constructor that is either private or public or any, the compiler will not allow us to add public constructor without parameters to the class.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">If we want to create object of class even if we have private constructors then we need to have public constructor along with private constructor</span></li>
</ul>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AF00C3C066 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (31, 4, N'Destructor in c#', N'<p><strong>Destructor in c#</strong></p>

<p>Destructor in c# is a special method of a class which will invoke automatically when an instance of the class is destroyed. Destructor is used to write a code that needs to be executed while an instance is destroyed.</p>

<p>To create destructor we need to create method in a class with same name as class preceded with ~ operator.</p>

<p>Syntax of Destructor</p>

<p><br />
class SampleA<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public SampleA()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// Constructor<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;~SampleA()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// Destructor<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</p>

<p>Example of Destructor</p>

<p>In below example I created a class with one constructor and one destructor. An instance of class is created within a main function. As the instance is created within the function, it will be local to the function and its life time will be expired immediately after execution of the function was completed.</p>

<p><br />
using System;<br />
namespace ConsoleApplication3<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;class SampleA<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// Constructor<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public SampleA()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(&quot;An&nbsp; Instance&nbsp; Created&quot;);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// Destructor<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;~SampleA()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(&quot;An&nbsp; Instance&nbsp; Destroyed&quot;);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;class Program<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public static void Test()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;SampleA T = new SampleA(); // Created instance of class<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;static void Main(string[] args)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Test();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;GC.Collect();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.ReadLine();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</p>

<p>When we run above program it will show output like as shown below</p>

<p>// <strong>Output</strong></p>

<p><br />
An instance created<br />
An instance destroyed</p>

INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (32, 4, N'Types of Classes in C#', N'<p><strong>Types of Classes in C#</strong></p>

<ol>
	<li>Abstract Class (sometimes called a Pure Virtual Class)</li>
	<li>Partial Class</li>
	<li>Sealed Class</li>
	<li>Static Class</li>
</ol>

<p><strong>Abstract Class</strong>: An Abstract Class means that, no object of this class can be instantiated, but can make derivation of this. It can serve the purpose of base class only as no object of this class can be created. Abstract Class is denoted by the keyword abstract.</p>

<p>abstract class myClass<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public myClass()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// code to initialize the class&hellip;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;abstract public void anyMethod_01();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;abstract public void anyMethod_02(int anyVariable);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;abstract public int anyMethod_03 (int anyvariable);<br />
}</p>

<p>It is important here to note that abstract classes can have non-abstract method(s), even can have only non-abstract method(s).<br />
abstract class myclass<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public void nonAbstractMethod ()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// code&hellip;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</p>

<p>&hellip; is perfectly alright.<br />
An abstract class can be derived from another abstract class. In that case, in the derived class, it is optional to implement the abstract method(s) of the base class.</p>

<p>// Base abstract class<br />
abstract class baseClass<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public abstract int addNumbers (int a, int b);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public abstract int multiplyNumbers(int a, int b);<br />
}</p>

<p>// Derived abstract class<br />
abstract class derivedClass:baseClass<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// implementing addNumbers&hellip;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public override int addnumbers (int a, int b)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;return a+b;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</p>

<p>// Derived class from 2nd class (derivedClass)<br />
class anyClass: derivedClass<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// implementing multiplyNumbers of baseClass&hellip;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public override int multiplyNumbers(int a, int b)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;return a*b;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</p>

<p>In the above example, we only implemented addNumbers in the derived abstract class (derivedClass). The abstract method multiplyNumbers is implemented in the anyClass, which is in turn derived from derivedClass.</p>

<p><strong>Partial Class: </strong>This special type of class called &quot;Partial Class&quot; is introduced with .Net Framework 2.0. Partial Class allows its members &ndash; method, properties, and events &ndash; to be divided into multiple source files (.cs). At compile time these files get combined into a single class.Partial Class is denoted by the keyword partial.<br />
Some do&#39;s and don&#39;ts about partial class:-</p>

<ul>
	<li>All the parts of a partial class must be prefixed with the keyword partial.</li>
	<li>Accessibility, signature etc. must be same in all parts of the partial class.</li>
	<li>You cannot sealed one part of the partial class. In that case entire class in sealed.</li>
	<li>If you define any part of the partial class abstract, entire class will become abstract.</li>
	<li>Inheritance cannot be applied to a part of partial class. If you do so, it applies to entire class.</li>
</ul>

<p>public partial class myPartialClass<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public void firstMethod()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// code&hellip;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</p>

<p>public partial class myPartialClass<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public void secondMethod()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// code&hellip;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</p>

<p><strong>Sealed Class:</strong> A sealed class is a class which cannot be inherited. A sealed class cannot be a base class. The modifier abstract cannot be applied to a sealed class. By default, struct (structure) is sealed. It is the last class in hierarchy. To access the members of a sealed class, you must create objects of that class.<br />
Sealed Class is denoted by the keyword sealed.</p>

<p>sealed class mySealedClass<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;int a;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;int b;<br />
}</p>

<p>Class mainClass<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public static void Main()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;mySealedClass obj = new mySealedClass();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;obj.a = 5;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;obj.b = 7;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(&quot;a = {0}, b = {1}&quot;, obj.a, obj.b);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</p>

<p><strong>Static Class:</strong> A Static Class is one which cannot be instantiated. The keyword new cannot be used with static classes as members of such class can be called directly by using the class name itself.</p>

<p>Following are the main characteristics of a static class:-</p>

<ul>
	<li>A Static Class can only have static members.</li>
	<li>A Static Class cannot be instantiated.</li>
	<li>A Static Class is sealed, so cannot be inherited.</li>
	<li>A Static Class cannot have a constructor (except static constructor).</li>
</ul>

<p>Static Class is denoted by the keyword static.</p>

<p>// static class definition&hellip;<br />
public static class myclass<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public static int addNumbers(int a, int b)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;return (a + b);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</p>

<p>// to use it, we call directly on the class&hellip;<br />
Console.WriteLine(&quot;The addition of 5 and 7 is: &quot; + myClass.addNumbers(5, 7));</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AF00E0F9C2 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (33, 4, N'Abstract Class versus Interface', N'<h1>Abstract Class versus Interface</h1>

<h3>What is an Abstract Class?</h3>

<p>An abstract class is a special kind of class that cannot be instantiated. So the question is why we need a class that cannot be instantiated? An abstract class is only to be sub-classed (inherited from). In other words, it only allows other classes to inherit from it but cannot be instantiated. The advantage is that it enforces certain hierarchies for all the subclasses. In simple words, it is a kind of contract that forces all the subclasses to carry on the same hierarchies or standards.</p>

<h3>What is an Interface?</h3>

<p>An interface is not a class. It is an entity that is defined by the word Interface. An interface has no implementation; it only has the signature or in other words, just the definition of the methods without the body. As one of the similarities to Abstract class, it is a contract that is used to define hierarchies for all subclasses or it defines specific set of methods and their arguments. The main difference between them is that a class can implement more than one interface but can only inherit from one abstract class. Since C# doesn&rsquo;t support multiple inheritance, interfaces are used to implement multiple inheritance.</p>

<h3>Both Together</h3>

<p>When we create an interface, we are basically creating a set of methods without any implementation that must be overridden by the implemented classes. The advantage is that it provides a way for a class to be a part of two classes: one from inheritance hierarchy and one from the interface.</p>

<p>When we create an abstract class, we are creating a base class that might have one or more completed methods but at least one or more methods are left uncompleted and declared <code>abstract</code>. If all the methods of an abstract class are uncompleted then it is same as an interface. The purpose of an abstract class is to provide a base class definition for how a set of derived classes will work and then allow the programmers to fill the implementation in the derived classes.</p>

<p>There are some similarities and differences between an interface and an abstract class that I have arranged in a table for easier comparison:</p>

<table cellpadding="7" cellspacing="0" class="ArticleTable" style="height:952px; width:930px">
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p><strong>Feature</strong></p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p><strong>Interface</strong></p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p><strong>Abstract class</strong></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Multiple inheritance</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>A class may inherit several interfaces.</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p style="text-align: right;">A class may inherit only one abstract class.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Default implementation</p>
			</td>
			<td>
