			<p>An interface cannot provide any code, just the signature.</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p style="text-align: right;">An abstract class can provide complete, default code and/or just the details that have to be overridden.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Access Modfiers</td>
			<td>An interface cannot have access modifiers for the subs, functions, properties etc everything is assumed as public</td>
			<td style="text-align: right;">An abstract class can contain access modifiers for the subs, functions, properties</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Core VS Peripheral</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>Interfaces are used to define the peripheral abilities of a class. In other words both Human and Vehicle can inherit from a IMovable interface.</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p style="text-align: right;">An abstract class defines the core identity of a class and there it is used for objects of the same type.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Homogeneity</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>If various implementations only share method signatures then it is better to use Interfaces.</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p style="text-align: right;">If various implementations are of the same kind and use common behaviour or status then abstract class is better to use.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Speed</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>Requires more time to find the actual method in the corresponding classes.</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p style="text-align: right;">Fast</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p>Adding functionality (Versioning)</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>If we add a new method to an Interface then we have to track down all the implementations of the interface and define implementation for the new method.</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p style="text-align: right;">If we add a new method to an abstract class then we have the option of providing default implementation and therefore all the existing code might work properly.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Fields and Constants</td>
			<td>No fields can be defined in interfaces</td>
			<td style="text-align: right;">An abstract class can have fields and constrants defined</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<h2>&nbsp;</h2>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AF00E55C4B AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (34, 4, N'Difference Between Constant and ReadOnly and Static', N'<p><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Difference Between Constant and ReadOnly and Static</strong></span></p>

<p>Constant and ReadOnly keyword are used to make a field constant which value cannot be modified. Static keyword is used to make members static that can be shared by all the class objects.</p>

<p><strong>Constant: </strong>Constant fields or local variables must be assigned a value at the time of declaration and after that they cannot be modified. By default constant are static, hence you cannot define a constant type as static.</p>

<p><strong>public const int X = 10;</strong></p>

<p>A const field is a compile-time constant. A constant field or local variable can be initialized with a constant expression which must be fully evaluated at compile time.</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <strong>void Calculate(int Z)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; const int X = 10, X1 = 50;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; const int Y = X + X1; //no error, since its evaluated a compile time<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; const int Y1 = X + Z; //gives error, since its evaluated at run time<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }</strong></p>

<p>You can apply const keyword to built-in value types (byte, short, int, long, char, float, double, decimal, bool), enum, a string literal, or a reference type which can be assigned with a value null.</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <strong>const MyClass obj1 = null;//no error, since its evaluated a compile time<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; const MyClass obj2 = new MyClass();//gives error, since its evaluated at run time</strong></p>

<p>Constants can be marked as public, private, protected, internal, or protected internal access modifiers. Use the const modifier when you sure that the value a field or local variable would not be changed.</p>

<p><strong>ReadOnly: </strong>A readonly field can be initialized either at the time of declaration or with in the constructor of same class. Therefore, readonly fields can be used for run-time constants.</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; class MyClass<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; readonly int X = 10; // initialized at the time of declaration<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; readonly int X1;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; public MyClass(int x1)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; X1 = x1; // initialized at run time<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }</p>

<p>Explicitly, you can specify a readonly field as static since, like constant by default it is not static. Readonly keyword can be apply to value type and reference type (which initialized by using the new keyword) both. Also, delegate and event could not be readonly. Use the readonly modifier when you want to make a field constant at run time.</p>

<p><strong>Static</strong>: The static keyword is used to specify a static member, which means static members are common to all the objects and they do not tied to a specific object. This keyword can be used with classes, fields, methods, properties, operators, events, and constructors, but it cannot be used with indexers, destructors, or types other than classes.</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong> class MyClass<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; static int X = 10;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; int Y = 20;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; public static void Show()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Console.WriteLine(X);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Console.WriteLine(Y); //error, since you can access only static members<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }</strong></p>

<p><strong>Key points about Static keyword</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; If the static keyword is applied to a class, all the members of the class must be static.</li>
	<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Static methods can only access static members of same class. Static properties are used to get or set the value of static fields of a class.</li>
	<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Static constructor can&#39;t be parameterized. Access modifiers can not be applied on Static constructor, it is always a public default constructor which is used to initialize static fields of the class.</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AF00ED212F AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (35, 4, N'Difference between ref and out parameters', N'<p><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Difference between ref and out parameters</strong></span></p>

<p>Ref and out parameters are used to pass an argument within a method.</p>

<p><strong>Ref</strong>: The ref keyword is used to pass an argument as a reference. This means that when value of that parameter is changed in the method, it gets reflected in the calling method. An argument that is passed using a ref keyword must be initialized in the calling method before it is passed to the called method.</p>

<p><strong>Out: </strong>The out keyword is also used to pass an argument like ref keyword, but the argument can be passed without assigning any value to it. An argument that is passed using an out keyword must be initialized in the called method before it returns back to calling method.</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; public class Example<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public static void Main() //calling method<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;int val1 = 0; //must be initialized<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;int val2; //optional<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Example1(ref val1);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(val1); // val1=1<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Example2(out val2);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(val2); // val2=2<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;static void Example1(ref int value) //called method<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;value = 1;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;static void Example2(out int value) //called method<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;value = 2; //must be initialized<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; /* Output<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 1<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 2<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; */</p>

<p><strong>Ref and out in method overloading</strong></p>

<p>Both ref and out cannot be used in method overloading simultaneously. However, ref and out are treated differently at run-time but they are treated same at compile time (CLR doesn&#39;t differentiates between the two while it created IL for ref and out). Hence methods cannot be overloaded when one method takes a ref parameter and other method takes an out parameter. The following two methods are identical in terms of compilation.</p>

<p>class MyClass<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public void Method(out int a) // compiler error &ldquo;cannot define overloaded&rdquo;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// method that differ only on ref and out&quot;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public void Method(ref int a)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; // method that differ only on ref and out&quot;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</p>

<p>However, method overloading can be done, if one method takes a ref or out argument and the other method takes simple argument. The following example is perfectly valid to be overloaded.</p>

<p>class MyClass<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public void Method(int a)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public void Method(out int a)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// method differ in signature.<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AF00F1E27D AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (36, 4, N'Understanding Delegates in C#', N'<p><strong>Understanding Delegates in C#</strong></p>

<p><br />
A delegate is a reference type that holds the reference of a class method. Any method which has the same signature as delegate can be assigned to delegate. It is very similar to the function pointer but with a difference that delegates are a type-safe. We can say that it is the object-oriented implementation of function pointers.</p>

<p>There are three steps for defining and using delegates:</p>

<ol>
	<li><strong>Declaration</strong>: A delegate is declared by using the keyword delegate, otherwise it resembles a method declaration.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</li>
	<li><strong>Instantiation</strong>:To create a delegate instance, we need to assign a method (which has same signature as delegate) to delegate.</li>
	<li><strong>Invocation: </strong>Invoking a delegate is like as invoking a regular method.</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; //1. Declaration<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; public delegate int MyDelagate(int a, int b); //delegates having same signature as method<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; public class Example<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// methods to be assigned and called by delegate<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public int Sum(int a, int b)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;return a + b;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public int Difference(int a, int b)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;return a - b;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
class Program<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;static void Main()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Example obj = new Example();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// 2. Instantiation : As a single cast delegate<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;MyDelagate sum = new MyDelagate(obj.Sum);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;MyDelagate diff = new MyDelagate(obj.Difference);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// 3.Invocation<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(&quot;Sum of two integer is = &quot; + sum(10, 20));<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;Console.WriteLine(&quot;Difference of two integer is = &quot; + diff(20, 10));<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; /* Out Put<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Sum of two integer is = 30<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Difference of two integer is = 10<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; */</p>

<p><strong>Key points about delegates</strong></p>

<ol>
	<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Delegates are like C++ function pointers but are type safe.</li>
	<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Delegates allow methods to be passed as parameters.</li>
	<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Delegates are used in event handling for defining callback methods.</li>
	<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Delegates can be chained together i.e. these allow defining a set of methods that executed as a single unit.</li>
	<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Once a delegate is created, the method it is associated will never changes because delegates are immutable in nature.</li>
	<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Delegates provide a way to execute methods at run-time.</li>
	<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; All delegates are implicitly derived from System.MulticastDelegate, class which is inheriting from System.Delegate class.</li>
	<li>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Delegate types are incompatible with each other, even if their signatures are the same. These are considered equal if they have the reference of same method.</li>
</ol>

<p><strong>Types of delegates</strong></p>

<ol>
	<li><strong>Single cast delegate</strong>: A single cast delegate holds the reference of only single method. In previous example, created delegate is a single cast delegate.</li>
	<li><strong>Multi cast delegate</strong>: A delegate which holds the reference of more than one method is called multi-cast delegate. A multicast delegate only contains the reference of methods which return type is void. The + and += operators are used to combine delegate instances. Multicast delegates are considered equal if they reference the same methods in the same order.</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; //1. Declaration<br />
public delegate void MyDelagate(int a, int b);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
public class Example<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; // methods to be assigned and called by delegate<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; public void Sum(int a, int b)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Console.WriteLine(&quot;Sum of integers is = &quot; + (a + b));<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;public void Difference(int a, int b)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Console.WriteLine(&quot;Difference of integer is = &quot; + (a - b));<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; class Program<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; static void Main()<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Example obj = new Example();</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; // 2. Instantiation<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; MyDelagate multicastdel = new MyDelagate(obj.Sum);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; multicastdel += new MyDelagate(obj.Difference);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;// 3. Invocation<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;multicastdel (50, 20);<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; /* Out put<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Sum of integers is = 70<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Difference of integer is = 30<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; */</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AF00F458C8 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (37, 4, N'Difference Between Finalize and Dispose Method', N'<p><strong>Difference Between Finalize and Dispose Method</strong></p>

<p>.NET Framework provides two methods Finalize and Dispose for releasing unmanaged resources like files, database connections, COM etc. This article helps you to understand the difference between Finalize and Dispose method.</p>

<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td style="width:319px">
			<p><strong>Finalize</strong></p>

			<p>&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:319px">
			<p><strong>Dispose</strong></p>

			<p>&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width:319px">
			<ul>
				<li><strong>Used to free unmanaged resources like files, database connections, COM etc. held by an object before that object is destroyed.</strong></li>
				<li><strong>Internally, it is called by Garbage Collector and cannot be called by user code.</strong></li>
				<li><strong>It belongs to Object class.</strong></li>
				<li><strong>Implement it when you have unmanaged resources in your code, and want to make sure that these resources are freed when the Garbage collection happens.</strong></li>
				<li><strong>There is performance costs associated with Finalize method.</strong></li>
			</ul>

			<p>&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:319px">
			<ul>
				<li>It is used to free unmanaged resources like files, database connections, COM etc. at any time.</li>
				<li>Explicitly, it is called by user code and the class implementing dispose method must implement IDisposable interface.</li>
				<li>It belongs to IDisposable interface.</li>
				<li>Implement this when you are writing a custom class that will be used by other users.</li>
				<li>There is no performance costs associated with Dispose method.</li>
			</ul>

			<p>&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Example : Finalize</strong></p>

<p>// Implementing Finalize method</p>

<p>public class MyClass</p>

<p>{</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; //At runtime C# destructor is automatically converted to Finalize method.</p>

<p>&nbsp;~MyClass ()</p>

<p>&nbsp;{</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; //TO DO: clean up unmanaged objects</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }</p>

<p>}</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Example: Dispose</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>// Implementing Dispose method</p>

<p>public class MyClass : IDisposable</p>

<p>{</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; private bool disposed = false;</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>//Implement IDisposable.</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; public void Dispose()</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {</p>

<p style="margin-left:.5in">&nbsp;Dispose(true);</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; protected virtual void Dispose(bool disposing)</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {</p>

<p style="margin-left:.5in">&nbsp;if (!disposed)</p>

<p style="margin-left:.5in">&nbsp;{</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; if (disposing)</p>

<p style="margin-left:1.0in">&nbsp;{</p>

<p style="margin-left:1.5in">&nbsp;//TO DO: clean up managed objects</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left:1.0in">&nbsp;//TO DO: clean up unmanaged objects</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; disposed = true;</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }</p>

<p>&nbsp;}</p>

<p>}</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Note:</p>

<ol>
	<li>You cannot override the Finalize method in the C# or C++ languages. But you can override Finalize method in VB.NET since it does not support destructor.</li>
	<li>You should not implement a Finalize method for managed objects, because the garbage collector cleans up managed resources automatically.</li>
	<li>A Dispose method should call the <strong>GC.SupressFinalize()</strong> method for the object of a class which has destructor because it has already done the work to clean up the object, then it is not necessary for the garbage collector to call the object&#39;s Finalize method.</li>
</ol>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>// Using Dispose and Finalize method</p>

<p>public class MyClass : IDisposable</p>

<p>{</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; private bool disposed = false;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;//Implement IDisposable.</p>

<p>&nbsp;public void Dispose()</p>

<p>&nbsp;{</p>

<p style="margin-left:.5in">&nbsp;Dispose(true);</p>

<p style="margin-left:.5in">&nbsp;GC.SuppressFinalize(this);</p>

<p>&nbsp;}</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;protected virtual void Dispose(bool disposing)</p>

<p>&nbsp;{</p>

<p style="margin-left:.5in">&nbsp;if (!disposed)</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {</p>

<p style="margin-left:1.0in">&nbsp;if (disposing)</p>

<p style="margin-left:1.0in">&nbsp;{</p>

<p style="margin-left:1.5in">&nbsp;// TO DO: clean up managed objects</p>

<p style="margin-left:1.0in">&nbsp;}</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left:1.0in">&nbsp;// TO DO: clean up unmanaged objects</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin-left:1.0in">&nbsp;disposed = true;</p>

<p style="margin-left:.5in">&nbsp;}</p>

<p>&nbsp;}</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;//At runtime C# destructor is automatically Converted to Finalize method</p>

<p>&nbsp;~MyClass()</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Dispose(false);</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }</p>

<p>}</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AF0110DCA4 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (38, 1, N'.NET Framework', N'<h1 style="text-align:justify">.NET Framework</h1>

<p style="text-align:justify">The .NET Framework is a technology that supports building and running the next generation of applications and XML Web services.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">The .NET Framework consists of the common language runtime and the .NET Framework class library. The common language runtime is the foundation of the .NET Framework. You can think of the runtime as an agent that manages code at execution time, providing core services such as memory management, thread management, and remoting, while also enforcing strict type safety and other forms of code accuracy that promote security and robustness. In fact, the concept of code management is a fundamental principle of the runtime. Code that targets the runtime is known as managed code, while code that does not target the runtime is known as unmanaged code. The class library is a comprehensive, object-oriented collection of reusable types that you can use to develop applications ranging from traditional command-line or graphical user interface (GUI) applications to applications based on the latest innovations provided by ASP.NET, such as Web Forms and XML Web services.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">The .NET Framework can be hosted by unmanaged components that load the common language runtime into their processes and initiate the execution of managed code, thereby creating a software environment that can exploit both managed and unmanaged features. The .NET Framework not only provides several runtime hosts, but also supports the development of third-party runtime hosts.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">For example, ASP.NET hosts the runtime to provide a scalable, server-side environment for managed code. ASP.NET works directly with the runtime to enable ASP.NET applications and XML Web services, both of which are discussed later in this topic.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Internet Explorer is an example of an unmanaged application that hosts the runtime (in the form of a MIME type extension). Using Internet Explorer to host the runtime enables you to embed managed components or Windows Forms controls in HTML documents. Hosting the runtime in this way makes managed mobile code possible, but with significant improvements that only managed code can offer, such as semi-trusted execution and isolated file storage.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">The following illustration shows the relationship of the common language runtime and the class library to your applications and to the overall system. The illustration also shows how managed code operates within a larger architecture.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">.NET Framework in context<br />
<br />
<img alt="Managed code within a larger architecture" id="circle" src="https://i-msdn.sec.s-msft.com/dynimg/IC104620.gif" title="Managed code within a larger architecture" /></p>

<p>The following sections describe the main features of the .NET Framework in greater detail.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Common Language Runtime (CLR):</strong> The heart of the .Net Framework. It is also called the&nbsp;.Net runtime. It resides above the operating system and handles all .Net applications. It handles garbage collection, Code Access Security (CAS) etc.Common Language Runtime or CLR is the run-time execution environment of .Net Framework. Converting MS-IL into platform or OS specific code is done by the CLR.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Microsoft Intermediate Language (MSIL) Code:</strong> When we compile our .Net code then it is not directly converted to native/binary code; it is first converted into intermediate code known as MSIL code which is then interpreted by the CLR. MSIL is independent of hardware and the operating system. Cross language relationships are possible&nbsp;since MSIL is the same for all .Net languages. MSIL is further converted into native code.</p>

<p><img alt="NET2.gif" src="http://www.c-sharpcorner.com/UploadFile/09f663/net-architecture-and-net-framework-basics/Images/NET2.gif" style="height:56px; width:591px" /></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Just in Time Compilers (JIT):</strong> It compiles IL code into native executable code (exe or dlls). Once code is converted to IL then it can be called again by JIT instead of recompiling that code.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Framework class library:</strong> The .Net Framework provides a&nbsp;huge class library called&nbsp;FCL for common tasks. It contains thousands of classes to access Windows APIs and common functions like string manipulations, Data structures, stream, IO, thread, security etc.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Common Language Specification (CLS):</strong> What makes a language to be .Net compliant? Answer is CLS. Microsoft has defined some specifications that each .Net language has to follow. For e.g.: no pointer, no multiple inheritances etc.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Common Type System (CTS):</strong> CTS defines some basic data types that IL can understand. Each .Net compliant language should map its data types&nbsp;to these standard data types. This makes it possible for two .Net compliant languages to communicate by passing/receiving parameters to and from each other. For example CTS defines Int32 for C# int and VB integer data types.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AF011A3FDA AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (39, 4, N'Difference between String and Stringbuilder in C#', N'<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><strong>Difference between String and Stringbuilder in C#</strong></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><strong>String</strong>: String is immutable. Immutable means once we create string object we cannot modify. Any operation like insert, replace or append happened to change string simply it will discard the old value and it will create new instance in memory to hold the new value.</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><strong>Example</strong></span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">string str = &quot;hi&quot;;<br />
// create a new string instance instead of changing the old one<br />
str += &quot;test&quot;;<br />
str += &quot;help&quot;;</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><strong>String Builder: </strong>String builder is mutable it means once we create string builder object we can perform any operation like insert, replace or append without creating new instance for every time.</span></p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Example</span></p>

<p><br />
<span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(&quot;&quot;);<br />
sb.Append(&quot;hi&quot;);<br />
sb.Append(&quot;test &quot;);<br />
string str = sb.ToString();</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif"><strong>String</strong></span></p>

<ul>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">It&rsquo;s an immutable</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Performance wise string is slow because every time it will create new instance</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">In string we don&rsquo;t have append keyword</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">String belongs to System namespace</span></li>
</ul>

<p><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;<br />
<strong>StringBuilder</strong></span></p>

<ul>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">It&rsquo;s mutable</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Performance wise stringbuilder is high because it will use same instance of object to perform any action</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">In StringBuilder we can use append keyword</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-family:trebuchet ms,helvetica,sans-serif">Stringbuilder belongs to System.Text namespace</span></li>
</ul>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AF01217A7B AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (40, 1, N'Frameworks Versions', N'<p><u>.NET Framework 4.5 Features:</u></p>

<p>Windows Workflow Foundation(WF)</p>

<ul>
	<li>State machine workflows Enhancements</li>
	<li>Enhanced Workflow Designer features</li>
	<li>Storage of the view state information for a workflow in a single element in the XAML file</li>
	<li>Versioning enhancements</li>
</ul>

<p>Windows Communication Foundation(WCF)</p>

<ul>
	<li>Support for a UDP transport that enables developers to write services that use &ldquo;fire and forget&rdquo; messaging. A client sends a message to a service and expects no response from the service</li>
	<li>Support for WCF services that use internationalized domain names (IDNs).</li>
	<li>Ability to support multiple authentication modes on a single WCF endpoint when using the HTTP transport and transport security</li>
	<li>New HTTPS protocol mapping to make it easier to expose an endpoint over HTTPS with Internet Information Services (IIS).</li>
</ul>

<p>Windows Presentation Foundation(WPF)</p>

<ul>
	<li>New features for the VirtualizingPanel and Dispatcher classes.</li>
	<li>Improved performance when displaying large sets of grouped data, and by accessing collections on non-UI threads.</li>
	<li>Ability to set the amount of time that should elapse between property changes and data source updates</li>
	<li>The new Ribbon control, which enables you to implement a ribbon user interface that hosts a Quick Access Toolbar, Application Menu, and tabs</li>
</ul>

<p>Networking</p>

<ul>
	<li>Support for Internationalized Domain Name (IDN) parsing</li>
	<li>Support for Email Address Internationalization (EAI)</li>
	<li>Improved IPv6 support.</li>
	<li>Dual-mode socket support.</li>
</ul>

<p>Web</p>

<ul>
	<li>Support for content distribution network (CDN) fallback in the ScriptManager control.</li>
	<li>Support for asynchronous modules and handlers</li>
	<li>Support for new HTML5 form types</li>
	<li>Support for unobtrusive JavaScript in client-side validation scripts</li>
	<li>Integrated encoding routines from the AntiXSS library (previously an external library) to protect from cross-site scripting attacks</li>
	<li>Enhancements in Parallel Computing</li>
</ul>

<p>Tools</p>

<ul>
	<li>Resource file Generator(Resgen.exe) &ndash; Used to creat a .resources file to .resw file for use in Windows Store apps</li>
	<li>Managed Profile Guided Optimization (Mpgo.exe) &ndash; Enables you to improve application startup time, memory utilization (working set size), and throughput by optimizing native image assemblies</li>
</ul>

<p>.NET for Windows Store apps</p>

<ul>
	<li>Windows Store apps are designed for specific form factors and leverage the power of the Windows operating system. A subset of the .NET Framework 4.5 is available for building Windows Store apps for Windows by using C# or Visual Basic. This subset is called .NET for Windows Store apps.</li>
</ul>

<p><u>.NET Framework 4.0 Features:</u></p>

<ul>
	<li>Common Language Runtime (CLR)&nbsp; &ndash; The following sections describe new features in security, parallel computing, performance and diagnostics, dynamic language runtime, and other CLR-related technologies</li>
	<li>Base Class Libraries</li>
	<li>Networking&nbsp; &ndash; Enhancements have been made that affect how integrated Windows authentication is handled by the&nbsp;<a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.httpwebrequest%28VS.100%29.aspx">HttpWebRequest</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.httplistener%28VS.100%29.aspx">HttpListener</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.mail.smtpclient%28VS.100%29.aspx">SmtpClient</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.security.sslstream%28VS.100%29.aspx">SslStream</a>,&nbsp;<a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.security.negotiatestream%28VS.100%29.aspx">NegotiateStream</a>, and related classes in the&nbsp;<a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net%28VS.100%29.aspx">System.Net</a>&nbsp;and related namespaces</li>
	<li>Web&nbsp; &ndash; The following sections describe new features in ASP.NET core services, Web Forms, Dynamic Data, and Visual Web Developer.</li>
	<li>Client&nbsp; &ndash; The following sections describe new features in Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) and Managed Extensibility Framework (MEF).</li>
	<li>Data</li>
	<li>Communications&nbsp; &ndash; Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) provides the new features and enhancements described in the following sections.</li>
	<li>Workflow &ndash; Windows Workflow Foundation (WF) in .NET Framework 4.0 changes several development paradigms from earlier versions. Workflows are now easier to create, execute, and maintain.</li>
</ul>

<p><u>.NET Framework 3.5 Features:</u></p>

<ul>
	<li>Language Integrated Query (LINQ)&nbsp; for SQL, XML, Dataset, Object</li>
	<li>Addin system</li>
	<li>p2p&nbsp;base class</li>
	<li>Active directory</li>
	<li>ASP.NET Ajax</li>
	<li>Anonymous types with static type inference</li>
	<li>Paging support for ADO.NET</li>
	<li>ADO.NET synchronization API to synchronize local caches and server side data stores</li>
	<li>Asynchronous network I/O API</li>
	<li>Support for HTTP pipelining and syndication feeds.</li>
	<li>New System.CodeDom namespace</li>
</ul>

<p><u>.NET Framework 3.0 Features:</u></p>

<p>Also called WinFX,includes a new set of managed code APIs that are an integral part of Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008 operating systems and provides</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Windows Communication Foundation (WCF)</strong>&nbsp;&ndash; formerly called Indigo; a service-oriented messaging system which allows programs to interoperate locally or remotely similar to web services</li>
	<li><strong>Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF)</strong>&nbsp;&ndash;&nbsp; formerly called Avalon; a new user interface subsystem and API based on XML and vector graphics, which uses 3D computer graphics hardware and Direct3D technologies.</li>
	<li><strong>Windows Workflow Foundation (WF)</strong>&nbsp;allows for building of task automation and integrated transactions using workflows.</li>
	<li><strong>Windows CardSpace</strong>, formerly called InfoCard; a software component which securely stores a person&rsquo;s digital identities and provides a unified interface for choosing the identity for a particular transaction, such as logging in to a website</li>
</ul>

<p><u>.NET FrameWork 2. 0 Features:</u></p>

<ul>
	<li>Generics</li>
	<li>Anonymous methods</li>
	<li>Partial class</li>
	<li>Nullable type</li>
	<li>The new API gives a fine grain control on the behavior of the runtime with regards to multithreading, memory allocation, assembly loading and more</li>
	<li>Full 64-bit support for both the x64 and the IA64 hardware platforms</li>
	<li>New personalization features for ASP.NET, such as support for themes, skins and webparts.</li>
	<li>.NET Micro Framework</li>
	<li>Data Tables</li>
</ul>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AF0123605C AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (41, 3, N'Difference between Asp.Net WebForm and Asp.Net MVC', N'<h1>Difference between Asp.Net WebForm and Asp.Net MVC</h1>

<table class="ArticleTable" style="height:611px; width:937px">
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<td><strong>ASP.NET Web Forms</strong></td>
			<td><strong>ASP.NET MVC</strong></td>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>ASP.NET Web Forms use Page controller pattern approach for rendering layout. In this approach, every page has its own controller, i.e., code-behind file that processes the request.</td>
			<td>ASP.NET MVC uses Front Controller approach. That approach means a common controller for all pages processes the requests.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>No separation of concerns. As we discussed that every page (<em>.aspx</em>) has its own controller (code behind i.e. <em>aspx.cs/.vb</em> file), so both are tightly coupled.</td>
			<td>Very clean separation of concerns. View and Controller are neatly separate.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Because of this coupled behavior, automated testing is really difficult.</td>
			<td>Testability is a key feature in ASP.NET MVC. Test driven development is quite simple using this approach.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>In order to achieve stateful behavior, viewstate is used. Purpose was to give developers the same experience of a typical WinForms application.</td>
			<td>ASP.NET MVC approach is stateless as that of the web. So there is no concept of viewstate.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Statefulness has a lots of problem for web environment in case of excessively large viewstate. Large viewstate means increase in page size.</td>
			<td>As controller and view are not dependent and also no viewstate concept in ASP.NET MVC, so output is very clean.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>ASP.NET WebForms model follows a Page Life cycle.</td>
			<td>No Page Life cycle like WebForms. Request cycle is simple in ASP.NET MVC model.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>Along with statefulness, Microsoft tries to introduce server-side controls as in Windows applications. Purpose was to provide somehow an abstraction to the details of HTML. In ASP.NET Web Forms, minimal knowledge of HTML, JavaScript and CSS is required.</td>
			<td>In MVC, detailed knowledge of HTML, JavaScript and CSS is required.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>The above abstraction was good but provides limited control over HTML, JavaScript and CSS which is necessary in many cases.</td>
			<td>Full control over HTML, JavaScript and CSS.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>With a lots of control libraries availability and limited knowledge of other related technologies, ASP.NET WebForms is RAD(Rapid Application Development) approach.</td>
			<td>It&#39;s a step back. For developers decrease in productivity.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>It&rsquo;s good for small scale applications with limited team size.</td>
			<td>It&rsquo;s better as well as recommended approach for large-scale applications where different teams are working together.</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p>This article explains the pros and cons associated with each model. And in the last point, I concluded which model is suitable in a scenario. Hopefully, it will be a reference for choosing the right approach.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4AF015B4BBB AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (42, 12, N'What is O/RM?', N'<p><strong>What is O/RM?</strong></p>

<p>O/RM is an acronym that stands for object/relational mapping. Basically, an O/RM framework is used to persist model objects in a relational database and retrieve them. It uses metadata information to interface with the database. This way, your data-layer code knows nothing about the database structure. The O/RM tool becomes middleware that completely hides the complexity.</p>

<p>The heart of O/RM is the mapping&mdash;the mapping technique is what binds the object and relational worlds. By mapping, you express how a class and its properties are related to one or more tables in the database. This information is used by the O/RM tool&rsquo;s engine to dynamically build SQL code that retrieves data and transforms it into objects. Similarly, by tracking changes to objects&rsquo; properties, it can use mapping data to send updates back to the database. The mapping information is generally expressed as an XML file. As an alternative, some O/RM tools use attributes on the classes and their properties to maintain mapping data.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4BD011E73E1 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (43, 12, N'Entity Framework', N'<p><strong>Entity Framework</strong></p>

<p>Entity Framework is an Object/Relational Mapping (ORM) framework that enables developers to work with relational database. It enables developers to deal with data as objects and properties. Using the Entity Framework, developer&rsquo;s issue queries using LINQ, then retrieve and manipulate data as strongly typed objects using C# or VB.Net.</p>

<p>The Entity Framework&rsquo;s ORM implementation also provides services like change tracking, identity resolution, lazy loading, and query translation so that developers can focus on their application-specific business logic rather than the data access fundamentals. ADO.NET Entity Framework is targeted for developing Enterprise applications which can support MS SQL databases as well as other databases like as Oracle, DB2, MySql and many more.</p>

<p><span style="color:#008080"><strong>Advantage of Entity Framework</strong></span></p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>Productivity</strong></span></p>

<p>Entity Framework can take up to 35 percent of the entire application code. It make the developer&rsquo;s life easier than ever. In spite of its limitations, the designer integrated into Visual Studio dramatically simplifies the mapping process.</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>Maintainability</strong></span></p>

<p>Since you have the fewer lines of code to fetch data from database, the fewer lines of code you have to maintain. This is particularly true in the big projects.</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>Performance</strong></span></p>

<p>The complexity of O/RM introduces an obvious slowdown in performance. In entity framework first request to fetch data is little bit slow but after that is fast to fetch data from database.</p>

<p><span style="color:#008080"><strong>Entity Framework Models</strong></span></p>

<p>Microsoft&rsquo;s Entity Framework evolved from a methodology known as Entity Relationship Modeling (ERM). An ERM defines a schema of entities and their relationships with one another. Entities are not the same as objects. Entities define the schema of an object, but not its behavior. So, an entity is something like the schema of a table in your database, except that it describes the schema of your business objects. There are three models in the entity framework:</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>CONCEPTUAL MODEL</strong></span></p>

<p>The conceptual model is where you describe the model classes. This file is split into two main sections: the first is a container that lists all the entities and the relationships that are managed by Entity Framework, and the second contains a detailed description of their structure.</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>STORAGE MODEL</strong></span></p>

<p>The storage model is the equivalent of the conceptual model, but it describes the database organization. Not only is this file conceptually similar to the previous one, but it also uses the same XML nodes. Unlike the conceptual model, it isn&rsquo;t possible to split this model into several physical files. The first section of this file lists all the tables, views, stored procedures, and foreign keys that are affected. The second section describes the items listed in the first node.</p>

<p>Regarding tables and views, the columns and primary keys are described. When it comes to stored procedures, input and output parameters are described. The description of a foreign key contains information about the table involved, the cardinality, and the delete and update rules.</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>MAPPING MODEL</strong></span></p>

<p>The mapping file is completely different. Its job isn&rsquo;t to describe something but to compensate for the differences that exist between the two previous models. This is where the real magic of mapping happens: you map a class to one or multiple tables map one table to one or multiple classes, define inheritance mapping, and map stored procedures for both updates and object retrieval.</p>

<p>There is only one important node in this file: it associates the class to a table and can be repeated more than once to ensure that a class can be mapped against multiple tables, and vice versa. Like the storage description file and unlike the conceptual file, the mapping file can&rsquo;t be split into multiple files.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4BD011F28B9 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (44, 12, N' Domain modelling approaches in Entity Framework', N'<p><strong>Various Domain modelling approaches in Entity Framework</strong></p>

<p>EF allow developers to focus on the business domain and to model it in terms of classes.</p>

<p><strong>Domain modelling approaches</strong></p>

<p>There are three approaches of domain modelling which was introduced with Entity Framework 4.1</p>

<ol>
	<li>Code First</li>
	<li>Model First</li>
	<li>Database first</li>
</ol>

<p><span style="color:#008080"><strong>Code First</strong></span></p>

<p>Code first is the domain modelling approach in Entity Framework. It enables you to describe a model by using C# or VB.NET classes and then create database from these classes. These classes are called POCO classes.</p>

<p>This approach enables us to work entirely in an object-oriented direction, and not worry about the structure of the database. This abstraction allow us to make a more logically and flexible application that focuses on the behavior of the application rather than the database generated by it.</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>Advantages of Code First</strong></span></p>

<ul>
	<li>It is very popular approach since it allow you to make a more logically and flexible application.</li>
	<li>It provides full control over the code since there is no auto generated code which is hard to modify.</li>
	<li>In this approach, your code defines only the database mappings and EF will handle creation of database with its relations.</li>
	<li>Manual changes to database schema is not preferable because your code defines the database.</li>
	<li>You can also use Code first to map your model to an existing database.</li>
</ul>

<p><span style="color:#008080"><strong>Model First</strong></span></p>

<p>Model first is the domain modelling approach in Entity Framework. It enables you to create model&rsquo;s Entities, relationships, and inheritance hierarchies on the design surface of empty model (.edmx file) by using entity designer and then create database from it. This approach is adopted by the architect and solution lead developers.</p>

<p>In Model First approach, while creating Entity Data Model, you must select the option &ldquo;Empty Model&rdquo; instead of &quot;Generate from database&quot; option.</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>Advantage of Model First</strong></span></p>

<ul>
	<li>It is good if you like to visualize the structure of the data in the application or you don&#39;t like writing code or SQL since it will generate for you.</li>
	<li>In this approach you have no much control over your entities (auto generated code which is hard to modify) and database. In this way it is rarely used but for small easy projects this approach will be very productive.</li>
	<li>To add extra features in POCO entities you must either T4 modify template or use partial classes.</li>
	<li>Manual changes to database schema is not preferable because your model defines the database.</li>
</ul>

<p><span style="color:#008080"><strong>Database First</strong></span></p>

<p>Database first is the domain modelling approach in Entity Framework. It enables you to create model from an existing database (like SQL Server, Oracle, DB2 etc.). This approach reduces the amount of code that we need to write since it automatically generates code. But it also limits us to work with the structure of the generated code.</p>

<p><span style="color:#8B4513"><strong>Advantage of Database First</strong></span></p>

<ul>
	<li>Very popular if you have Database designed by DBAs, developed separately or if you have existing Database.</li>
	<li>EDM wizard creates entities, relationships, and inheritance hierarchies for you. After modification of mapping, you can also generate POCO class entities.</li>
	<li>To add extra features in POCO entities you must either T4 modify template or use partial classes.</li>
	<li>Manual changes to the database are possible because the database defines your domain model. You can always update model from database.</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4BD0123871A AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (45, 12, N'LINQ', N'<p><strong>LINQ</strong></p>

<p>LINQ stands for Language-Integrated Query. Basically LINQ address the current database development model in the context of Object Oriented Programming Model. If someone wants to develop database application on .Net platform the very simple approach he uses ADO.Net. ADO.Net is serving as middle ware in application and provides complete object oriented wrapper around the database SQL.So developer must have good knowledge of object oriented concept as well as SQL to develop an application. But in case of Linq SQL statements are become part of the C# and VB.Net code so there are less chance of mistake.</p>

<p>LINQ enables developers to query data sources using a query like syntax with both C# and VB.NET. Using LINQ we can query any database and collection.</p>

<p><span style="color:#FF0000"><strong>LINQ Flavors</strong></span></p>

<p><span style="color:#008080"><strong>LINQ to Objects</strong></span></p>

<p>It provides the facility to query any kind of C# in-memory objects, like as arrays, lists, generic list and other collection types. LINQ to object query returns IEnumerable collection. It provides a new approach to query collection with powerful filtering, ordering and grouping capabilities with minimum code.</p>

<p><span style="color:#008080"><strong>LINQ to Ado.Net</strong></span></p>

<p>LINQ to ADO.NET includes different flavors of LINQ to query data from different databases like as Microsoft SQL Server, Oracle, and others. It has following flavours</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="color:#800000"><strong>LINQ to SQL</strong></span><br />
It is specifically designed for working with Sql Server database. It provides run-time infrastructure for managing relational data as objects. It also supports transactions, views and stored procedures. It is an object-relational mapping (ORM) framework that allow 1-1 mapping of Sql Server database to .net classes. In this mapping the classes that match the database table are created automatically from the database itself and we can use these classes immediately.</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="color:#800000"><strong>LINQ to DataSet</strong></span><br />
It is an easy and faster way to query data cached in a DataSet object. It also allow LINQ to query over any database that can be query with Ado.Net.</p>

<p style="margin-left: 40px;"><strong><span style="color:#800000">LINQ to Entities</span></strong><br />
In many ways it is very similar to LINQ to SQL. It uses a conceptual Entity Data Model (EDM). The ADO.NET Entity Framework has been improved in .NET framework 4.0 to query any database like Sql Server, Oracle, MySQL, DB2 and many more.</p>

<p><span style="color:#008080"><strong>LINQ to XML</strong></span><br />
It provides an improved XML programming interface. Using this we can query, modify xml document and also save document after modification. System.Xml.Linq namespace contains classes for LINQ to XML.</p>

<p><span style="color:#008080"><strong>PLINQ (Parallel LINQ)</strong></span><br />
PLINQ was introduced in .Net framework 4.0. It extends LINQ to Objects with a new parallel programming library. Using this, we can break/split up a query to execute simultaneously/parallel on different processors.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4BD0125A058 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (46, 6, N'IEnumerable VS IQueryable', N'<p><span style="color:#008080"><strong>IEnumerable VS IQueryable</strong></span></p>

<p>In LINQ to query data from database and collections, we use IEnumerable and IQueryable for data manipulation. IEnumerable is inherited by IQueryable, Hence IQueryable has all the features of IEnumerable and except this, it has its own features. Both have its own importance to query data and data manipulation. Let&rsquo;s see both the features and take the advantage of both the features to boost your LINQ Query performance.</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>IEnumerable</strong></span></p>

<ul>
	<li>IEnumerable exists in System.Collections Namespace.</li>
	<li>IEnumerable can move forward only over a collection, it can&rsquo;t move backward and between the items.</li>
	<li>IEnumerable is best to query data from in-memory collections like List, Array etc.</li>
	<li>While query data from database, IEnumerable execute select query on server side, load data in-memory on client side and then filter data.</li>
	<li>IEnumerable is suitable for LINQ to Object and LINQ to XML queries.</li>
	<li>IEnumerable supports deferred execution.</li>
	<li>IEnumerable doesn&rsquo;t supports custom query.</li>
</ul>

<p>IEnumerable doesn&rsquo;t support lazy loading. Hence not suitable for paging like scenarios.<br />
Extension methods supports by IEnumerable takes functional objects.</p>

<p><strong>IEnumerable Example</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; MyDataContext dc = new MyDataContext ();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; IEnumerable&lt;Employee&gt; list = dc.Employees.Where(p =&gt; p.Name.StartsWith(&quot;S&quot;));<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; list = list.Take&lt;Employee&gt;(10);</p>

<p>Generated SQL statements of above query will be :</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; SELECT [t0].[EmpID], [t0].[EmpName], [t0].[Salary] FROM [Employee] AS [t0]<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; WHERE [t0].[EmpName] LIKE @p0</p>

<p>Notice that in this query &quot;top 10&quot; is missing since IEnumerable filters records on client side</p>

<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>IQueryable</strong></span></p>

<ul>
	<li>IQueryable exists in System.Linq Namespace.</li>
	<li>IQueryable can move forward only over a collection, it can&rsquo;t move backward and between the items.</li>
	<li>IQueryable is best to query data from out-memory (like remote database, service) collections.</li>
	<li>While query data from database, IQueryable execute select query on server side with all filters.</li>
	<li>IQueryable is suitable for LINQ to SQL queries.</li>
	<li>IQueryable supports deferred execution.</li>
	<li>IQueryable supports custom query using Create Query and Execute methods.</li>
	<li>IQueryable support lazy loading. Hence it is suitable for paging like scenarios.</li>
	<li>Extension methods supports by IQueryable takes expression objects means expression tree.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>IQueryable Example</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; MyDataContext dc = new MyDataContext ();<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; IQueryable&lt;Employee&gt; list = dc.Employees.Where(p =&gt; p.Name.StartsWith(&quot;S&quot;));<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; list = list.Take&lt;Employee&gt;(10);</p>

<p>Generated SQL statements of above query will be :</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; SELECT TOP 10 [t0].[EmpID], [t0].[EmpName], [t0].[Salary] FROM [Employee] AS [t0]<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; WHERE [t0].[EmpName] LIKE @p0</p>

<p>Notice that in this query &quot;top 10&quot; is exist since IQueryable executes query in SQL server with all filters.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4BD01284D7D AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (47, 13, N'Loose Coupling and Tight Coupling', N'<p><strong>Loose Coupling and Tight Coupling</strong></p>

<p><span style="color:#800000">Tight coupling is when a group of classes are highly dependent on one another.</span></p>

<p><span style="color:#800000">This scenario arises when a class assumes too many responsibilities, or when one concern is spread over many classes rather than having its own class.</span></p>

<p><span style="color:#008080">Loose coupling is achieved by means of a design that promotes single-responsibility and separation of concerns.</span></p>

<p><span style="color:#008080">A loosely-coupled class can be consumed and tested independently of other (concrete) classes.</span></p>

<p><span style="color:#008000">Interfaces are a powerful tool to use for decoupling. Classes can communicate through interfaces rather than other concrete classes, and any class can be on the other end of that communication simply by implementing the interface.</span></p>

<p><strong>Example of tight coupling:</strong></p>

<pre>
<code>class CustomerRepository
{
    private readonly Database database;

    public CustomerRepository(Database database)
    {
        this.database = database;
    }

    public void Add(string CustomerName)
    {
        database.AddRow(&quot;Customer&quot;, CustomerName);
    }
}

class Database
{
    public void AddRow(string Table, string Value)
    {
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Example of loose coupling:</strong></p>

<pre>
<code>class CustomerRepository
{
    private readonly IDatabase database;

    public CustomerRepository(IDatabase database)
    {
        this.database = database;
    }

    public void Add(string CustomerName)
    {
        database.AddRow(&quot;Customer&quot;, CustomerName);
    }
}

interface IDatabase
{
    void AddRow(string Table, string Value);
}

class Database : IDatabase
{
    public void AddRow(string Table, string Value)
    {
    }
}
</code></pre>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4BD012F5920 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (48, 13, N'What is Dependency Injection?', N'<p><strong>What is Dependency Injection?</strong></p>

<p>Dependency Injection (DI) is a design pattern that takes away the responsibility of creating dependencies from a class thus resulting in a loosely coupled system. In order to understand DI you need to be aware of the following terms:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Dependency</li>
	<li>Dependency Inversion Principle</li>
	<li>Inversion of Control (IoC)</li>
</ol>

<p><strong>Dependency Inversion Principle</strong></p>

<p>Dependency inversion principle is a software design principle which provides us the guidelines to write loosely coupled classes. According to the definition of Dependency inversion principle:</p>

<ol>
	<li>High-level modules should not depend on low-level modules. Both should depend on abstractions.</li>
	<li>Abstractions should not depend upon details. Details should depend upon abstractions.</li>
</ol>

<p style="margin-left:.5in"><strong>Inversion of control (IoC)</strong></p>

<p style="margin-left:.5in">Inversion of control (IoC) is a programming technique, expressed here in terms of object-oriented programming, in which object coupling is bound at run time by an assembler object and is typically not known at compile time using static analysis</p>

<p><strong>What is Dependency Injection?</strong></p>

<p>Dependency injection eliminates tight coupling between objects to make both the objects and applications that use them more flexible, reusable, and easier to test. It facilitates the creation of loosely coupled objects and their dependencies. The basic idea behind Dependency Injection is that you should isolate the implementation of an object from the construction of objects on which it depends. Dependency Injection is a form of the Inversion of Control Pattern where a factory object carries the responsibility for object creation and linking. The factory object ensures loose coupling between the objects and promotes seamless testability.</p>

<p><strong>Advantages and Disadvantages of Dependency Injection</strong></p>

<p><strong>The primary advantages of dependency injection are:</strong></p>

<ol>
	<li>Loose coupling</li>
	<li>Centralized configuration</li>
	<li>Easily testable</li>
</ol>

<p>Code becomes more testable because it abstracts and isolates class dependencies.</p>

<p><strong>Disadvantages of Dependency Injection</strong></p>

<p>However, the primary drawback of dependency injection is that wiring instances together can become a nightmare if there are too many instances and many dependencies that need to be addressed</p>

<p>Dependency injection can make code difficult to trace (read) because it separates behavior from construction. This means developers must refer to more files to follow how a system performs.</p>

<p>Dependency injection typically requires more lines of code to accomplish the same behavior legacy code would.</p>

<p>Dependency injection diminishes encapsulation by requiring users of a system to know how it works and not merely what it does.</p>

<p>Increases the coupling between a class and its consumer (since the consumer needs more info to create it) and the dependency and its consumer (since the consumer needs to know the dependency to use).</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4BD01344165 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (49, 2, N'Exploring Session in ASP.NET', N'<h2>Introduction</h2>

<p>First of all, I would like to thank all the readers who have read and voted for my articles. In the Beginner&#39;s Guide series, I have written some articles on state management. Probably this is my last article on state management.</p>

<p>This article will give you a very good understanding of session. In this article, I have covered the basics of session, different ways of storing session objects, session behavior in web farm scenarios, session on Load Balancer, etc. I have also explained details of session behavior in a live production environment. Hope you will enjoy this article and provide your valuable suggestions and feedback.</p>

<h2><a name="2"></a>What is Session?</h2>

<p>Web is <strong>stateless</strong>, which means a new instance of a web page class is re-created each time the page is posted to the server. As we all know, HTTP is a stateless protocol, it can&#39;t hold client information on a page. If the user inserts some information and move to the next page, that data will be lost and the user would not be able to retrieve that information. What do we need here? We need to store information. Session provides a facility to store information on server memory. It can support any type of object to store along with our own custom objects. For every client, session data is stored separately, which means session data is stored on a per client basis. Have a look at the following diagram:</p>

<p><img alt="explor2.jpg" src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor2.jpg" style="height:228px; width:246px" /></p>

<div class="Caption">Fig: For every client, session data is stored separately</div>

<p>State management using session is one of the best ASP.NET features, because it is secure, transparent from users, and we can store any kind of object in it. Along with these advantages, some times session can cause performance issues in high traffic sites because it is stored in server memory and clients read data from the server. Now let&#39;s have a look at the advantages and disadvantages of using session in our web applications.</p>

<h2><a name="3"></a>Advantages and disadvantages of Session?</h2>

<p>Following are the basic advantages and disadvantages of using session. I have describe in details with each type of session at later point of time.</p>

<h4>Advantages:</h4>

<ul>
	<li>It helps maintain user state and data all over the application.</li>
	<li>It is easy to implement and we can store any kind of object.</li>
	<li>Stores client data separately.</li>
	<li>Session is secure and transparent from the user.</li>
</ul>

<h4>Disadvantages:</h4>

<ul>
	<li>Performance overhead in case of large volumes of data/user, because session data is stored in server memory.</li>
	<li>Overhead involved in serializing and de-serializing session data, because in the case of <code>StateServer</code> and <code>SQLServer</code> session modes, we need to serialize the objects before storing them.</li>
</ul>

<p>Besides these, there are many advantages and disadvantages of session that are based on the session type. I have discussed all of them in the respective sections below.</p>

<h2><a name="4"></a>Storing and retrieving values from Session</h2>

<p>Storing and retrieving values in session are quite similar to that in ViewState. We can interact with session state with the <code>System.Web.SessionState.HttpSessionState</code> class, because this provides the built-in session object in ASP.NET pages.</p>

<p>The following code is used for storing a value to session:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain720251" style="width:100%;display:block;">Hide &nbsp; Copy Code</div>

<pre>
//Storing UserName in Session
Session[&quot;UserName&quot;] = txtUser.Text;</pre>

<p>Now, let&#39;s see how we can retrieve values from session:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain184080" style="width:100%;display:block;">Hide &nbsp; Copy Code</div>

<pre>
//Check weather session variable null or not
if (Session[&quot;UserName&quot;] != null)
{
    //Retrieving UserName from Session
    lblWelcome.Text = &quot;Welcome : &quot; + Session[&quot;UserName&quot;];
}
else
{
 //Do Something else
}</pre>

<p>We can also store other objects in session. The following example shows how to store a <code>DataSet</code> in session.</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain65935" style="width:100%;display:block;">Hide &nbsp; Copy Code</div>

<pre>
//Storing dataset on Session
Session[&quot;DataSet&quot;] = _objDataSet;</pre>

<p>The following code shows how we to retrieve that <code>DataSet</code> from session:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain277822" style="width:100%;display:block;">Hide &nbsp; Copy Code</div>

<pre>
//Check weather session variable null or not
if (Session[&quot;DataSet&quot;] != null)
{
    //Retrieving UserName from Session
    DataSet _MyDs = (DataSet)Session[&quot;DataSet&quot;];
}
else
{
    //Do Something else
}</pre>

<h4>References:</h4>

<ul>
	<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms178581.aspx#CodeExamples" title="Session Variables - MSDN">MSDN (read the session variable section)</a></li>
</ul>

<h2><a name="5"></a>Session ID</h2>

<p>ASP.NET uses an 120 bit identifier to track each session. This is secure enough and can&#39;t be reverse engineered. When a client communicates with a server, only the session ID is transmitted between them. When the client requests for data, ASP.NET looks for the session ID and retrieves the corresponding data. This is done in the following steps:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Client hits the web site and information is stored in the session.</li>
	<li>Server creates a unique session ID for that client and stores it in the Session State Provider.</li>
	<li>The client requests for some information with the unique session ID from the server.</li>
	<li>Server looks in the Session Providers and retrieves the serialized data from the state server and type casts the object.</li>
</ul>

<p>Take a look at the the pictorial flow:</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor3.jpg" style="height:219px; width:616px" /></p>

<div class="Caption">Fig: Communication of client, web server, and State Provider</div>

<h4>References:</h4>

<ul>
	<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.web.sessionstate.httpsessionstate.sessionid.aspx">SessionID in MSDN</a></li>
</ul>

<h2><a name="6"></a>Session Mode and State Provider</h2>

<p>In ASP.NET, there are the following session modes available:</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>InProc</strong></li>
	<li><strong>StateServer</strong></li>
	<li><strong>SQLServer</strong></li>
	<li><strong>Custom</strong></li>
</ul>

<p>For every session state, there is a Session Provider. The following diagram will show you how they are related:</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor5.jpg" style="height:361px; width:522px" /></p>

<div class="Caption">Fig: Session state architecture</div>

<p>We can choose the session state provider based on which session state we are selecting. When ASP.NET requests for information based on the session ID, the session state and its corresponding provider are responsible for sending the proper information. The following table shows the session mode along with the provider name:</p>

<table class="ArticleTable">
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<td>Session State Mode</td>
			<td>State Provider</td>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td><strong>InProc</strong></td>
			<td>In-memory object</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td><strong>StateServer</strong></td>
			<td><em>Aspnet_state.exe</em></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td><strong>SQLServer</strong></td>
			<td>Database</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td><strong>Custom</strong></td>
			<td>Custom provider</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p>Apart from that, there is another mode <strong>Off</strong>. If we select this option, the session will be disabled for the application. But our objective is to use session, so we will look into the above four session state modes.</p>

<h2><a name="8"></a>Session States</h2>

<p>Session state essentially means all the settings that you have made for your web application for maintaining the session. Session State itself is a big thing. It says all about your session configuration, either in the <em>web.config</em> or from the code-behind. In the <em>web.config</em>, <code>&lt;SessionState&gt;</code> elements are used for setting the configuration of the session. Some of them are <code>Mode</code>, <code>Timeout</code>, <code>StateConnectionString</code>, <code>CustomProvider</code>, etc. I have discussed about each and every section of the connection string. Before I discuss Session Mode, take a brief overview of session events.</p>

<h2><a name="9"></a>Session Event</h2>

<p>There are two types of session events available in ASP.NET:</p>

<ul>
	<li><code>Session_Start</code></li>
	<li><code>Session_End</code></li>
</ul>

<p>You can handle both these events in the <em>global.asax</em> file of your web application. When a new session initiates, the <code>session_start</code> event is raised, and the <code>Session_End</code> event raised when a session is abandoned or expires.</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain836955" style="width:100%;display:block;">Hide &nbsp; Copy Code</div>

<pre>
void Session_Start(object sender, EventArgs e) 
{
    // Code that runs when a new session is started
}

void Session_End(object sender, EventArgs e) 
{
    // Code that runs when a session ends. 
}</pre>

<h4>References:</h4>

<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.microsoft.com/technet/prodtechnol/windows2000serv/reskit/iisbook/c06_application_and_session_events.mspx?mfr=true" title="Application and Session Events">Application and Session Events</a></li>
</ul>

<h2><a name="10"></a>Session Mode</h2>

<p>I have already discussed about session modes in ASP.NET. Following are the different types of session modes available in ASP.NET:</p>

<ul>
	<li><code>Off</code></li>
	<li><code>InProc</code></li>
	<li><code>StateServer</code></li>
	<li><code>SQLServer</code></li>
	<li><code>Custom</code></li>
</ul>

<p>If we set session <code>Mode=&quot;off&quot;</code> in <em>web.config</em>, session will be disabled in the application. For this, we need to configure <em>web.config</em> the following way:</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor1.gif" style="height:114px; width:434px" /></p>

<h3><a name="11"></a>InProc Session Mode</h3>

<p>This is the default session mode in ASP.NET. Its stores session information in the current Application Domain. This is the best session mode for web application performance. But the main disadvantage is that, it will lose data if we restart the server. There are some more advantages and disadvantages of the InProc session mode. I will come to those points later on.</p>

<h4><a name="12"></a>Overview of InProc session mode</h4>

<p>As I have already discussed, in InProc mode, session data will be stored on the current application domain. So it is easily and quickly available.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor6.jpg" style="height:266px; width:274px" /></p>

<p>InProc session mode stores its session data in a memory object on the application domain. This is handled by a worker process in the application pool. So if we restart the server, we will lose the session data. If the client request for data, the state provider read the data from an in-memory object and returns it to the client. In <em>web.config</em>, we have to mention the session mode and also set the timeout.</p>

<p><img alt="explor3.gif" src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor3.gif" style="height:82px; width:434px" /></p>

<p>The above session timeout setting keeps the session alive for 30 minute. This is configurable from the code-behind too.</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain551103" style="width:100%;display:block;">Hide &nbsp; Copy Code</div>

<pre>
Session.TimeOut=30;</pre>

<p>There are two types of session events available in ASP.NET: <code>Session_Start()</code> and <code>Session_End</code> and this is the only mode that supports the<code> Session_End()</code> event. This event is called after the session timeout period is over. The general flow for the InProc session state is like this:</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor7.jpg" style="height:322px; width:154px" /></p>

<p>When the <code>Session_End()</code> is called depends on the session timeout. This is a very fast mechanism because no serialization occurs for storing and retrieving data, and data stays inside the same application domain.</p>

<h4><a name="13"></a>When should we use the InProc session mode?</h4>

<p>InProc is the default session mode. It can be very helpful for a small web site and where the number of users is very less. We should avoid InProc in a Web Garden scenario (I will come to this topic later on).</p>

<h4><a name="14"></a>Advantages and disadvantages</h4>

<h5>Advantages:</h5>

<ul>
	<li>It store session data in a memory object of the current application domain. So accessing data is very fast and data is easily available.</li>
	<li>There is not requirement of serialization to store data in InProc session mode.</li>
	<li>Implementation is very easy, similar to using the ViewState.</li>
</ul>

<h5>Disadvantages:</h5>

<p>Although InProc session is the fastest, common, and default mechanism, it has a lot of limitations:</p>

<ul>
	<li>If the worker process or application domain is recycled, all session data will be lost.</li>
