	<li>Though it is the fastest, more session data and more users can affect performance, because of memory usage.</li>
	<li>We can&#39;t use it in web garden scenarios.</li>
	<li>This session mode is not suitable for web farm scenarios.</li>
</ul>

<p>As per the above discussion, we can conclude that InProc is a very fast session storing mechanism but suitable only for small web applications. InProc session data will get lost if we restart the server, or if the application domain is recycled. It is also not suitable for Web Farm and Web Garden scenarios.</p>

<p>Now we will have a look the other options available to overcome these problems. First comes the StateServer mode.</p>

<h3>StateServer Session Mode<a name="15"></a></h3>

<h4><a name="16"></a>Overview of StateServer session mode</h4>

<p>This is also called Out-Proc session mode. StateServer uses a stand-alone Windows Service which is independent of IIS and can also be run on a separate server. This session state is totally managed by <em>aspnet_state.exe</em>. This server may run on the same system, but it&#39;s outside of the main application domain where your web application is running. This means if you restart your ASP.NET process, your session data will still be alive. This approaches has several disadvantages due to the overhead of the serialization and de-serialization involved, it also increases the cost of data access because every time the user retrieves session data, our application hits a different process.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor8.jpg" style="height:189px; width:410px" /></p>

<h4><a name="17"></a>Configuration for StateServer session mode</h4>

<p>In StateServer mode, session data is stored in a separate server which is independent of IIS and it is handled by <em>aspnet_state.exe</em>. This process is run as a Windows Service. You can start this service from the Windows MMC or from the command prompt.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor10.jpg" style="height:176px; width:600px" /></p>

<p>By default, the &quot;Startup Type&quot; of the ASP.NET state service is set to Manual; we have to set it to Automatic.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor11.jpg" style="height:368px; width:327px" /></p>

<p>From the command prompt, just type &quot;net start aspnet_state&quot;. By default, this service listens to TCP port 42424, but we can change the port from the Registry editor as show in the picture below:</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor9.jpg" style="height:165px; width:600px" /></p>

<p>Now have a look at the <em>web.config</em> configuration for the StateServer setting. For the StateServer setting, we need to specify the <code>stateConnectionString</code>. This will identify the system that is running the state server. By default, <code>stateConnectionString</code> used the IP 127.0.0.1 (localhost) and port 42424.</p>

<p><img alt="explor9.gif" src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor9.gif" style="height:106px; width:490px" /></p>

<p>When we are using StateServer, we can configure the <code>stateNetworkTimeOut</code> attribute to specify the maximum number of seconds to wait for the service to respond before canceling the request. The default timeout value is 10 seconds.</p>

<p><img alt="explor10.gif" src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor10.gif" style="height:138px; width:466px" /></p>

<p>For using StateServer, the object which we are going to store should be serialized, and at the time of retrieving, we need to de-serialize it back. I have described this below with an example.</p>

<h4>How the StateServer Session Mode works<a name="18"></a></h4>

<p>We use the StateServer session mode to avoid unnecessary session data loss when restarting our web server. StateServer is maintained by the <em>aspnet_state.exe</em> process as a Windows service. This process maintains all the session data. But we need to serialize the data before storing it in StateServer session mode.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor12.jpg" style="height:258px; width:574px" /></p>

<p>As shown in the above figure, when the client sends a request to the web server, the web server stores the session data on the state server. The StateServer may be the current system or a different system. But it will be totally independent of IIS. The destination of the StateServer will depend on the <em>web.config</em> <code>stateConnectionString</code> setting. If we set it to 127.0.0.1:42424, it will store data in the local system itself. For changing the StateServer destination, we need to change the IP, and make sure <em>aspnet_state.exe</em> is up and running on that system. Otherwise you will get the following exception while trying to store data on session.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor14.jpg" style="height:128px; width:600px" /></p>

<p>When we are storing an object on session, it should be serialized. That data will be stored in the StateServer system using the State Provider. And at the time of retrieving the data, the State Provider will return the data. The complete flow is given in the picture below:</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor15.jpg" style="height:355px; width:276px" /></p>

<h4>Example of StateServer Session Mode<a name="19"></a></h4>

<p>Here is a simple example of using the StateServer session mode. I have created this sample web application directly on IIS so that we can easily understand its usage.</p>

<p><strong>Step 1</strong>: Open Visual Studio &gt; File &gt; New &gt; Web Sites. Choose Location as HTTP and create the web application.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor16.jpg" style="height:288px; width:445px" /></p>

<p>Now if you open IIS, you will see a virtual directory created with the name of your web application, in my case it is <em>StateServer</em>.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor17.jpg" style="height:306px; width:339px" /></p>

<p><strong>Step 2</strong>: Create s simple UI that will take the roll number and the name of a student. We will store the name and roll number in a state server session. I have also created a class <code>StudentInfo</code>. This class is listed below:</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain34465" style="width:100%;display:block;">Hide &nbsp; Shrink <img id="preimg34465" src="http://www.codeproject.com/images/arrow-up-16.png" style="height:16px; width:16px" /> &nbsp; Copy Code</div>

<pre>
[Serializable]
public class StudentInfo
{
    //Default Constructor
    public StudentInfo()
    {
       
    }
    /// &lt;summary&gt;
    /// Create object of student Class
    /// &lt;/summary&gt;
    /// &lt;param name=&quot;intRoll&quot;&gt;Int RollNumber&lt;/param&gt;
    /// &lt;param name=&quot;strName&quot;&gt;String Name&lt;/param&gt;
    public StudentInfo(int intRoll, string strName)
    {
        this.Roll = intRoll;
        this.Name = strName;
    }

    private int intRoll;
    private string strName;
    public int Roll
    {
        get
        {
            return intRoll;
        }
        set
        {
            intRoll = value;
        }
    }

    public string Name
    {
        get
        {
            return strName;
        }
        set
        {
            strName = value;
        }
    }
}</pre>

<p>Now have a look at the code-behind. I have added two buttons: one for storing session and another for retrieving session.</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain462320" style="width:100%;display:block;">Hide &nbsp; Copy Code</div>

<pre>
protected void btnSubmit_Click(object sender, EventArgs e)
{
    StudentInfo _objStudentInfo = 
      new StudentInfo(Int32.Parse( txtRoll.Text) ,txtUserName.Text);
    Session[&quot;objStudentInfo&quot;] = _objStudentInfo;
    ResetField();
}
protected void btnRestore_Click(object sender, EventArgs e)
{
    StudentInfo _objStudentInfo = (StudentInfo) Session[&quot;objStudentInfo&quot;];
    txtRoll.Text = _objStudentInfo.Roll.ToString();
    txtUserName.Text = _objStudentInfo.Name;
}
</pre>

<p><strong>Step 3</strong>: Configure your <em>web.config</em> for state server as I have already explained. And please make sure <em>aspnet_state.exe</em> is up and running on the configured server.</p>

<p><strong>Step 4</strong>: Run the application.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor18.jpg" style="height:194px; width:282px" /></p>

<p>Enter the data, click on Submit.</p>

<p>There are the following tests that I have made which will totally explain how exactly StateServer is useful.</p>

<p><strong>First</strong>: Remove the [<code>Serializable</code> ] keyword from the <code>StudentInfo</code> class and try to run the application. When you click on the Submit button, you will get the following error:</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor19.jpg" style="height:173px; width:600px" /></p>

<p>Which clearly says that you have to serialize the object before storing it.</p>

<p><strong>Second</strong>: Run the application, store data by clicking on the Submit button. Restart IIS.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor20.jpg" style="height:234px; width:411px" /></p>

<p>In the case of InProc, you will have already lost your session data, but with StateServer, click on Restore Session and you will get your original data, because StateServer data does not depend on IIS. It keeps it separately.</p>

<p><strong>Third</strong>: Stop <em>aspnet_state.exe</em> from the Windows Services MMC and submit the data. You will get the following error:</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor21.jpg" style="height:128px; width:600px" /></p>

<p>because your State Server process is not running. So please keep in mind these three points when using StateServer mode.</p>

<h4>Advantages and Disadvantages<a name="20"></a></h4>

<p>Based on the above discussion:</p>

<h5>Advantages:</h5>

<ul>
	<li>It keeps data separate from IIS so any issues with IIS will not hamper session data.</li>
	<li>It is useful in web farm and web garden scenarios.</li>
</ul>

<h5>Disadvantages:</h5>

<ul>
	<li>Process is slow due to serialization and de-serialization.</li>
	<li>State Server always needs to be up and running.</li>
</ul>

<p>I am stopping here on StateServer, you will find some more interesting points on it in the Load Balancer, Web Farm, and Web Garden section.</p>

<h4>References:</h4>

<ul>
	<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms178586.aspx">State Server Session Mode</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms972429.aspx" title="ASP.Net Session State">ASP.NET Session State</a></li>
</ul>

<h3>SQLServer Session Mode<a name="21"></a></h3>

<h4><a name="22"></a>Overview of SQL Server Session Mode</h4>

<p>This session mode provide us more secure and reliable session management in ASP.NET. In this session mode, session data is serialized and stored in A SQL Server database. The main disadvantage of this session storage method is the overhead related with data serialization and de-serialization. It is the best option for using in web farms though.</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor22.jpg" style="height:188px; width:317px" /></p>

<p>To setup SQL Server, we need these SQL scripts:</p>

<ul>
	<li>For installing: <em>InstallSqlState.sql</em></li>
	<li>For uninstalling: <em>UninstallSQLState.sql</em></li>
</ul>

<p>The easiest way to configure SQL Server is using the <em>aspnet_regsql</em> command.</p>

<p>I have explained in detail the use of these files in the configuration section. This is the most useful state management in web farm scenarios.</p>

<h4>When should we use SQLServer Session Mode?<a name="23"></a></h4>

<ul>
	<li>SQL Server session mode is a more reliable and secure session state management.</li>
	<li>It keeps data in a centralized location (database).</li>
	<li>We should use the SQLServer session mode when we need to implement session with more security.</li>
	<li>If there happens to be frequent server restarts, this is an ideal choice.</li>
	<li>This is the perfect mode for web farm and web garden scenarios (I have explained this in detail later).</li>
	<li>We can use SQLServer session mode when we need to share session between two different applications.</li>
</ul>

<h4>Configuration for SQLServer Session Mode<a name="24"></a></h4>

<p>In SQLServer session mode, we store session data in SQL Server, so we need to first provide the database connection string in <em>web.config</em>. The <code>sqlConnectionString</code> attribute is used for this.</p>

<p>After we setup the connection string, we need to configure the SQL Server. I will now explain how to configure your your SQL Server using the <em>aspnet_regsql</em> command.</p>

<p><strong>Step 1</strong>: From command prompt, go to your Framework version directory. E.g.: <em>c:\windows\microsoft.net\framework\&lt;version&gt;</em>.</p>

<p><strong>Step 2</strong>: Run the <em>aspnet_regsql</em> command with the following parameters:</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor23.gif" style="height:54px; width:600px" /></p>

<p>Have a look at the parameters and their uses:</p>

<table class="ArticleTable">
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<td>Parameters</td>
			<td>Description</td>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>-ssadd</td>
			<td>Add support for SQLServer mode session state.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>-sstype p</td>
			<td>P stands for Persisted. It persists the session data on the server.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>-S</td>
			<td>Server name.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>-U</td>
			<td>User name.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>-P</td>
			<td>Password.</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p>After you run the command, you will get the following message:</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor24.gif" style="height:99px; width:600px" /></p>

<p>That&#39;s all.</p>

<p><strong>Step 3</strong>: Open SQL Server Management Studio, check if a new database ASPState has been created, and there should be two tables:</p>

<ul>
	<li><em>ASPStateTempApplications</em></li>
	<li><em>ASPStateTempSessions</em></li>
</ul>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor25.jpg" style="height:250px; width:322px" /></p>

<p>Change the configuration string of the StateServer example and run the same sample application.</p>

<p>Just store the roll number and user name and click on the Submit button. Open the <em>ASPStateTempSessions</em> table from SQL Server Management Studio.. here is your session data:</p>

<p><img src="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/session/ExploringSession/explor26.gif" style="height:74px; width:600px" /></p>

<p>Now do the following test that I have already explained in the StateServer mode section:</p>

<ol>
	<li>Remove the <code>Serialize</code> keyword from the <code>StydentInfo</code> class</li>
	<li>Reset IIS and click on Restore Session</li>
	<li>Stop SQL Server Services</li>
</ol>

<p>I think I have explained the SQLServer session mode well.</p>

<h4>Advantages and Disadvantages<a name="25"></a></h4>

<h5>Advantages:</h5>

<ul>
	<li>Session data not affected if we restart IIS.</li>
	<li>The most reliable and secure session management.</li>
	<li>It keeps data located centrally, is easily accessible from other applications.</li>
	<li>Very useful in web farms and web garden scenarios.</li>
</ul>

<h5>Disadvantages:</h5>

<ul>
	<li>Processing is very slow in nature.</li>
	<li>Object serialization and de-serialization creates overhead for the application.</li>
	<li>As the session data is handled in a different server, we have to take care of SQL Server. It should be always up and running.</li>
</ul>

<h4>References:</h4>

<ul>
	<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms178586.aspx" title="Read SQL Server Mode Section">Read more about SQLServer mode</a></li>
</ul>

INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (50, 2, N'Asp.Net Caching', N'<p><strong>Asp.Net Caching</strong></p>

<p>One of the most important factors in building high-performance, scalable Web applications is the ability to store items, whether data objects, pages, or parts of a page, in memory the initial time they are requested. You can cache, or store, these items on the Web server or other software in the request stream, such as the proxy server or browser. This allows you to avoid recreating information that satisfied a previous request, particularly information that demands significant processor time or other resources. ASP.NET caching allows you to use a number of techniques to store page output or application data across HTTP requests and reuse it.</p>

<p><span style="color:#008080"><strong>Caching a Page</strong></span></p>

<p>In order to cache a page&#39;s output, we need to specify an @OutputCache directive at the top of the page. The syntax is as shown below:</p>

<p><strong>&lt;%@ OutputCache Duration=5 VaryByParam=&quot;None&quot; %&gt;</strong></p>

<p>As you can see, there are two attributes to this directive. They are:</p>

<p><strong>Duration </strong>- The time in seconds of how long the output should be cached. After the specified duration has elapsed, the cached output will be removed and page content generated for the next request. That output will again be cached for 5 seconds and the process repeats.</p>

<p><strong>VaryByParam </strong>- This attribute is compulsory and specifies the querystring parameters to vary the cache.</p>

<p>In the above snippet, we have specified the <strong>VaryByParam </strong>attribute as None which means the page content to be served is the same regardless of the parameters passed through the querystring.</p>

<p>If there are two requests to the same page with varying querystring parameters, e.g.: .../PageCachingByParam.aspx?id=12 and .../PageCachingByParam.aspx?id=15] and separate page content is generated for each of them, the directive should be:</p>

<p><strong>&lt;%@ OutputCache Duration=5 VaryByParam=&quot;id&quot; %&gt;</strong></p>

<p>The page content for the two requests will each be cached for the time specified by the Duration attribute.</p>

<p>To specify multiple parameters, use semicolon to separate the parameter names. If we specify the <code>VaryByParam</code> attribute as <code>*</code>, the cached content is varied for all parameters passed through the querystring.</p>

<p>Some pages generate different content for different browsers. In such cases, there is provision to vary the cached output for different browsers. The @OutputCache directive has to be modified to:</p>

<p><span style="color:#000000"><strong>&lt;%@ OutputCache Duration=5 VaryByParam=&quot;id&quot; VaryByCustom=&quot;browser&quot; %&gt;</strong></span></p>

<p><span style="color:#008080"><strong>Caching page fragments</strong></span></p>

<p>Sometimes we might want to cache just portions of a page. For example, we might have a header for our page which will have the same content for all users. There might be some text/image in the header which might change everyday. In that case, we will want to cache this header for a duration of a day.</p>

<p>The solution is to put the header contents into a user control and then specify that the user control content should be cached. This technique is called fragment caching.</p>

<p>To specify that a user control should be cached, we use the @OutputCache directive just like we used it for the page.</p>

<p><br />
<strong>&lt;%@ OutputCache Duration=10 VaryByParam=&quot;None&quot; %&gt;</strong></p>

<p>With the above directive, the user control content will be cached for the time specified by the Duration attribute [10 secs]. Regardless of the querystring parameters and browser type and/or version, the same cached output is served. [See Example 3 in the download for a demonstration].</p>

<p><span style="color:#008080"><strong>Data Caching</strong></span></p>

<p>ASP.NET also supports caching of data as objects. We can store objects in memory and use them across various pages in our application. This feature is implemented using the Cache class. This cache has a lifetime equivalent to that of the application. Objects can be stored as name value pairs in the cache. A string value can be inserted into the cache as follows:<br />
Hide&nbsp;&nbsp; Copy Code</p>

<p><strong>Cache[&quot;name&quot;]=&quot;Smitha&quot;;</strong></p>

<p>The stored string value can be retrieved like this:</p>

<p><strong>if (Cache[&quot;name&quot;] != null)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Label1.Text= Cache[&quot;name&quot;].ToString();</strong></p>

<p>To insert objects into the cache, the Add method or different versions of the Insert method of the Cache class can be used. These methods allow us to use the more powerful features provided by the Cache class. One of the overloads of the Insert method is used as follows:</p>

<p><strong>Cache.Insert(&quot;Name&quot;, strName,<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; new CacheDependency(Server.MapPath(&quot;name.txt&quot;),<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; DateTime.Now.AddMinutes(2), TimeSpan.Zero);</strong></p>

<p>The first two parameters are the key and the object to be inserted. The third parameter is of type CacheDependency and helps us set a dependency of this value to the file named name.txt. So whenever this file changes, the value in the cache is removed. We can specify null to indicate no dependency. The fourth parameter specifies the time at which the value should be removed from cache. [See example 5 for an illustration.] The last parameter is the sliding expiration parameter which shows the time interval after which the item is to be removed from the cache after its last accessed time.</p>

<p>The cache automatically removes the least used items from memory, when system memory becomes low. This process is called scavenging. We can specify priority values for items we add to the cache so that some items are given more priority than others:</p>

<p><strong>Cache.Insert(&quot;Name&quot;, strName,<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; new CacheDependency(Server.MapPath(&quot;name.txt&quot;),<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; DateTime.Now.AddMinutes(2), TimeSpan.Zero,<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; CacheItemPriority.High, null);</strong></p>

<p>The CacheItemPriority enumeration has members to set various priority values. The CacheItemPriority.High assigns a priority level to an item so that the item is least likely to be deleted from the cache.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4BD015A86DD AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (51, 2, N'Authentication Authorization & Impersonation', N'<p><strong>Authentication Authorization &amp; Impersonation</strong></p>

<p><strong>Authentication</strong>: Authentication is the process of determining the identity of a user based on the user&rsquo;s credentials. The user&rsquo;s credentials are usually in the form of user ID and password, which is checked against any credentials&#39; store such as database. If the credentials provided by the user are valid, then the user is considered an authenticated user.</p>

<p><strong>Authorization</strong>: After successful authentication, deciding which resources a user can access based on their identity and checking whether the authenticated user has sufficient rights to access the requested resource is authorization.</p>

<p><strong>Impersonation</strong>: Impersonation is a process in which user accesses the resources(Ex:Files,DB&hellip;) by using the identity of another user.</p>

INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (52, 3, N'ASPX View Engine Vs Razor View Engine in ASP.NET MVC', N'<h1>ASPX View Engine Vs Razor View Engine in ASP.NET MVC</h1>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><em>&ldquo;View Engine in ASP.NET MVC is used to translate our views to HTML and then render to response.&rdquo;</em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Multiple View&nbsp;Engines are available for MVC including ASPX, Razor, NHaml etc. Normally in ASP.NET MVC, a View Engine translates&nbsp;view into HTML by:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Providing implementation of&nbsp;<strong><em>IViewEngine</em></strong>&nbsp;(as template provider)</li>
	<li><strong><em>IView</em></strong>&nbsp;(as rendering template) and</li>
	<li>A&nbsp;<em><strong>Template Engine</strong></em>&nbsp;for parsing and compiling view file into executable code.</li>
</ul>

<p>We can even use multiple View Engines&nbsp;in parallel (if needed). For more details about ViewEngine class, please&nbsp;<a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.web.mvc.viewengines(v=vs.118).aspx" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; vertical-align: baseline; outline: none; color: rgb(11, 145, 234); text-decoration: none;" target="_blank">follows here</a>.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.webdevelopmenthelp.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/ViewEngine.jpg" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; vertical-align: baseline; outline: none; color: rgb(11, 145, 234); text-decoration: none;"><img alt="ASPX Vs Razor" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-1503" src="http://www.webdevelopmenthelp.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/ViewEngine.jpg" style="border-style:initial; border-width:0px; box-shadow:rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.0980392) 0px 1px 4px; display:block; height:auto; margin:12px auto; max-width:100%; padding:0px; vertical-align:baseline; width:452px" /></a></p>

<h3>Understanding Syntax Difference</h3>

<p>Being software developer, we are normally concerned about code syntax differences when using either of these two View Engines. So, in order to get better understanding, please look into following code snippet written using both ASPX and Razor View Engine in order.</p>

<p>ASPX View Engine is also known as Web Form View Engine and inherits it&rsquo;s syntax as &ldquo;&lt;%= %&gt;&rdquo; or &ldquo;&lt;%: %&gt;&rdquo; for rendering server-side contents:</p>

<div style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 22.2857151031494px; background-color: rgb(211, 211, 211);"><em>&lt;%foreach (var student in Students)</em><br />
<em>{ %&gt;</em><br />
<em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&lt;% if (student.IsPassed)</em></div>

<div style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 22.2857151031494px; background-color: rgb(211, 211, 211);"><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;{ %&gt;</em></div>

<div style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 22.2857151031494px; background-color: rgb(211, 211, 211);"><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &lt;%=student.Name%&gt; promoted to next Grade.</em></div>

<div style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 22.2857151031494px; background-color: rgb(211, 211, 211);"><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&lt;% }else{ %&gt;</em><br />
<em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &lt;%=student.Name%&gt; not promoted to next Grade.</em><br />
<em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&lt;% } %&gt;</em><br />
<em>&lt;% } %&gt;</em></div>

<p>Code Snippet for Razor View Engine serving same purpose:</p>

<div style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: Verdana, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 22.2857151031494px; background-color: rgb(211, 211, 211);"><em>@foreach (var student in Students)</em><br />
<em>{</em><br />
<em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; @if(student.IsPassed)</em><br />
<em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;{</em><br />
<em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;@student.Name promoted to next Grade.</em><br />
<em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;} else {</em><br />
<em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; @student.Name not promoted to next Grade.</em><br />
<em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;}</em><br />
<em>}</em></div>

<p>It&rsquo;s quite clear that Razor syntax is clean and simpler as compared to ASPX syntax.</p>

<h3>Detailed Difference Between ASPX View Engine and Razor View Engine</h3>

<p>Now, following table describe the difference in both View Engines in more details.</p>

<table align="left" border="1" style="border-bottom-color:rgb(237, 237, 237); border-bottom-style:solid; border-collapse:collapse; border-spacing:0px; border-width:0px 0px 1px; color:rgb(117, 117, 117); font-family:verdana,helvetica,arial,sans-serif; font-size:12px; line-height:2; margin:0px 0px 24px; padding:0px; vertical-align:baseline; width:100%">
	<thead>
		<tr>
			<th scope="col" style="vertical-align: baseline;">
			<h2>ASPX View Engine</h2>
			</th>
			<th scope="col" style="vertical-align: baseline;">
			<h2>Razor View Engine</h2>
			</th>
		</tr>
	</thead>
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline"><strong><em>System.Web.Mvc.WebFormViewEngine</em></strong>&nbsp;is the namespace for ASPX View Engine.</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">Namespace for ASPX view Engine is<em><strong>System.Web.Razor</strong></em>.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">File Extension for this View Engine is similar to WebForm as:
			<p>&nbsp;</p>

			<ul>
				<li>.aspx, for Views&nbsp;just like Web Form pages.</li>
				<li>.ascx, for Partial Views &amp; Editor Template&nbsp;just like User Controls.</li>
				<li>.master, for Layout and Master Pages&nbsp;just like Master Pages in Web Forms.</li>
			</ul>
			</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">As it&rsquo;s new and advanced View Engine, it&rsquo;s extensions are totally different.
			<p>&nbsp;</p>

			<ul>
				<li>.cshtml (Razor C#),&nbsp;For all including Views, Partial Views, Editor Template and Layout Pages.</li>
				<li>.vbhtml (Razor VB.NET),&nbsp;For all including Views, Partial Views, Editor Template and Layout Pages.</li>
			</ul>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">From the beginning, ASPX View Engine was part of ASP.NET MVC.</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">Razor View Engine was introduced in ASP.NET MVC v3.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">ASPX View Engine uses syntax same as that of Web Form pages (already demonstrated above).</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">Razor Syntax is different as compared to Web Forms. Using Razor syntax, developer type comparatively less code which is is easy to understand.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">ASPX syntax is inherited from Web Forms, so it&rsquo;s understandable for Web Forms developer but it&rsquo;s not that much clean as compared to Razor View Engine.</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">As Razor View Engine is introduced later in MVC3, it&rsquo;s syntax is designed to be clean, expressive and easy to learn.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">ASPX View Engine does nothing to avoid Cross-Site Scripting attacks by default.</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">By default, Razor View Engine encodes html tags or scripts before it&rsquo;s being rendered to view that avoids Cross-Site Scripting attacks.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">ASPX View Engine is comparatively fast.</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">Razor View Engine is slow as compared to ASPX View Engine.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">It supports design view in Visual Studio.</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">It doesn&rsquo;t support design view in Visual Studio.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">No support for TDD (Test Driven Development).</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:baseline">Supports TDD (Test Driven Development).</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4C30097209E AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (53, 3, N'ASP.NET MVC3 Vs MVC4 Vs MVC5 Vs MVC6', N'<p><strong>ASP.NET MVC3 Vs MVC4 Vs MVC5 Vs MVC6</strong></p>

<p><strong>ASP.NET MVC3</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>New Project Templates having support for HTML 5 and CSS 3.</li>
	<li>Improved Model validation.</li>
	<li>Razor View Engine introduced with a bundle of new features.</li>
	<li>Having support for Multiple View Engines i.e. Web Forms view engine, Razor or open source.</li>
	<li>Controller improvements like ViewBag dynamic property and ActionResults Types etc. Dynamic property is a new feature introduced in C# 4.0. ViewBag being a dynamic property has an advantage over ViewData that it doesn&rsquo;t require checking NULL values.&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Unobtrusive JavaScript approach that actually separates the functionality from presentation layer on a web page.</li>
	<li>Improved Dependency Injection with new IDependencyResolver.</li>
	<li>Partial page output caching.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>ASP.NET MVC 4</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>ASP.NET Web API, a framework that simplifies the creation of HTTP services and serving a wide range of clients. Follow to create your first ASP.NET Web API service.</li>
	<li>Adaptive rendering and other look-n-feel improvements to Default Project Templates.</li>
	<li>A truly Empty Project Template.</li>
	<li>Based on jQuery Mobile, new Mobile Project Template introduced.</li>
	<li>Support for adding controller to other project folders also.</li>
	<li>Task Support for Asynchronous Controllers.</li>
	<li>Controlling Bundling and Minification through web.config.</li>
	<li>Support for OAuth and OpenID logins using DotNetOpenAuth library.</li>
	<li>Support for Windows Azure SDK 1.6 and new releases.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>ASP.NET MVC5</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>ASP.NET Identity for authentication and identity management. Thesedays, modern applications are developed for broader range of clients such as web, mobile in mind. Also, users are actively using their social identities from various social channels like facebook, youtube, twitter etc. ASP.NET Identity is a new Membership system to handle authentication and authorization for variety of clients as well as using user&rsquo;s existing social identities.</li>
	<li>Authentication Filters for authenticating user by custom or third-party authentication provider.</li>
	<li>With the help of Filter overrides, we can now override filters on a method or controller.</li>
	<li>Bootstrap replaced the default MVC template.</li>
	<li>Attribute Routing is now integrated into MVC5. Basically, MVC Routing is an excellent way to create human friendly and Search Engine Optimized URLs. You can easily get understanding about Routing in ASP.NET MVC here. Attribute based routing enables us to define routes along with action methods as follows:</li>
</ul>

<p><em>&nbsp;[Route(&ldquo;Students/{id}&rdquo;)]</em><br />
<em>&nbsp; public ActionResult GetStudentById(string id)</em><br />
<em>{</em><span style="background-color:rgb(211, 211, 211); color:rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family:verdana,helvetica,arial,sans-serif">&nbsp;</span><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</em><br />
<em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;// code logic here.</em><span style="background-color:rgb(211, 211, 211); color:rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family:verdana,helvetica,arial,sans-serif">&nbsp;</span><em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</em><br />
<em>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;return View();</em><br />
<em>}</em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>ASP.NET MVC6 | ASP.NET vNext</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li>Single Programming Model for ASP.NET MVC and ASP.NET Web API.</li>
	<li>Optimized for Cloud Computing.</li>
	<li>Supporting side by side deployment of runtime and framework along with application.</li>
	<li>Out of the box support for dependency injection.</li>
	<li>vNext is Open Source and supports running on multiple platforms including Linux and Mac.</li>
	<li>New JSON-based project Extension.</li>
	<li>In order to dynamically compile code, Roslyn compiler is used.</li>
</ul>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4C300985A35 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (54, 3, N'Action Filters', N'<p><strong>Action Filters</strong></p>

<p>An action filter is an attribute that you can apply to a controller action -- or an entire controller -- that modifies the way in which the action is executed. The ASP.NET MVC framework includes several action filters:</p>

<p><strong>OutputCache </strong>&ndash; This action filter caches the output of a controller action for a specified amount of time.<br />
<strong>HandleError</strong> &ndash; This action filter handles errors raised when a controller action executes.<br />
<strong>Authorize</strong> &ndash; This action filter enables you to restrict access to a particular user or role.</p>

<p>You also can create your own custom action filters. For example, you might want to create a custom action filter in order to implement a custom authentication system. Or, you might want to create an action filter that modifies the view data returned by a controller action.</p>

<p><strong>The Different Types of Filters</strong></p>

<p>The ASP.NET MVC framework supports four different types of filters:</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Authorization filters</strong> &ndash; Implements the IAuthorizationFilter attribute.</li>
	<li><strong>Action filters</strong> &ndash; Implements the IActionFilter attribute.</li>
	<li><strong>Result filters</strong> &ndash; Implements the IResultFilter attribute.</li>
	<li><strong>Exception filters</strong> &ndash; Implements the IExceptionFilter attribute.</li>
</ul>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="color:#FF0000"><strong>Authorization filter</strong></span></p>

<p>This filter provides authentication and authorization logic. It will be executed before the action gets executed. To implement this action the interface IAuthorizationFilter should be implemented by the custom attribute class.</p>

<pre>
<span style="color:blue">public</span> <span style="color:blue">class</span> CustomAuthorizationAttribute : FilterAttribute, IAuthorizationFilter
{
    <span style="color:blue">void</span> IAuthorizationFilter.OnAuthorization(AuthorizationContext filterContext)
    {
        filterContext.Controller.ViewBag.OnAuthorization = <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">IAuthorizationFilter.OnAuthorization filter called&quot;</span>;
    }
}</pre>

<p>Now when we decorate the action method with this attribute the OnAuthorize filter method will be called and our custom logic will get executed.</p>

<p><span style="color:#FF0000"><strong>Action filter</strong></span></p>

<p>This filter will be called before and after the action starts executing and after the action has executed. We can put our custom pre-processing and post-processing logic in this filter.</p>

<p>Now to implement this filter we need to create a custom filter attribute class and implement the IActionFilter filter interface. This interface provides us two methods <strong>OnActionExecuting</strong> and <strong>OnActionExecuted</strong> which will be called before and after the action gets executed respectively.</p>

<pre>
<span style="color:blue">public</span> <span style="color:blue">class</span> CustomActionAttribute : FilterAttribute, IActionFilter
{
    <span style="color:blue">void</span> IActionFilter.OnActionExecuted(ActionExecutedContext filterContext)
    {
        filterContext.Controller.ViewBag.OnActionExecuted = <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">IActionFilter.OnActionExecuted filter called&quot;</span>;
    }

    <span style="color:blue">void</span> IActionFilter.OnActionExecuting(ActionExecutingContext filterContext)
    {
        filterContext.Controller.ViewBag.OnActionExecuting = <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">IActionFilter.OnActionExecuting filter called&quot;</span>;
    }
}</pre>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="color:#FF0000"><strong>Result filter</strong></span></p>

<p>This filter will execute before and after the result of the action method has been executed. We can use this filter if we want some modification to be done in the action&#39;s result.</p>

<p>To implement the result filters we need to create a custom filter attribute class and implement the IResultFilter interface. this interface provides two methods OnResultExecuting and OnResultExecuted which will be called before and after the action result respectively.</p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain716657" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
<span style="color:blue">public</span> <span style="color:blue">class</span> CustomResultAttribute : FilterAttribute, IResultFilter
{
    <span style="color:blue">void</span> IResultFilter.OnResultExecuted(ResultExecutedContext filterContext)
    {
        filterContext.Controller.ViewBag.OnResultExecuted = <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">IResultFilter.OnResultExecuted filter called&quot;</span>;
    }

    <span style="color:blue">void</span> IResultFilter.OnResultExecuting(ResultExecutingContext filterContext)
    {
        filterContext.Controller.ViewBag.OnResultExecuting = <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">IResultFilter.OnResultExecuting filter called&quot;</span>;
    }
}</pre>

<p><span style="color:#FF0000"><strong>Exception filter</strong></span></p>

<p>This filter will be invoked whenever a controller or action of the controller throws an exception. This is particularly useful when we need custom error logging module.</p>

<p>To implement this filter we need to create a custom filter attribute class which implements IExceptionFilter. This interface gives us a methods called OnException which is a perfect place to call the exception logging module and to redirect to some error page.</p>

<pre>
<span style="color:blue">public</span> <span style="color:blue">class</span> CustomExceptionAttribute : FilterAttribute, IExceptionFilter
{       
    <span style="color:blue">void</span> IExceptionFilter.OnException(ExceptionContext filterContext)
    {
        filterContext.Controller.ViewBag.OnException = <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">IExceptionFilter.OnException filter called&quot;</span>;
    }
}</pre>

<p><span style="color:#FF0000"><strong>Order of Execution</strong></span></p>

<p>Now with all the above filters we have the following filter methods.</p>

<ul>
	<li>IAuthorizationFilter.OnAuthorization</li>
	<li>IActionFilter.OnActionExecuted</li>
	<li>IActionFilter.OnActionExecuting</li>
	<li>IResultFilter.OnResultExecuted</li>
	<li>IResultFilter.OnResultExecuting</li>
	<li>IExceptionFilter.OnException</li>
</ul>

<p>Now assuming that we have all the filters attached to a single action method what will be the order of execution of these filers. These filters will execute in following order under normal(non-exception) scenario.</p>

<ul>
	<li>IAuthorizationFilter.OnAuthorization</li>
	<li>IActionFilter.OnActionExecuting</li>
	<li>IActionFilter.OnActionExecuted</li>
	<li>IResultFilter.OnResultExecuting</li>
	<li>IResultFilter.OnResultExecuted</li>
</ul>

<p>In case there is an exception, OnException will will be called as instead of the result filters.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="color:#FF0000"><strong>Built-in Attributes&nbsp;</strong></span></p>

<p>ASP.NET MVC comes with a some of built in attribute classes that provides a some boilerplate functionality. We can create custom classes that derives from these built in classes and further provide specialized behavior as per our needs. Let us try to see some of these built in attributes.</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>AuthorizeAttribute</strong>: MVC framework provides AuthorizeAttribute which is helpful in specifying our custom authorization policies.</li>
	<li><strong>ActionFilterAttribute</strong>: This is the built in implementation of IActionFilter and IResultFilter. This attribute can be used as base class to implement the custom behavior for action and result filters.</li>
	<li><strong>HandleErrorAttribute</strong>: This is the built in implementation of IExceptionFilter which makes it easier to implement the exception handling strategy.</li>
</ul>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4C300A3DD33 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (55, 13, N'Singleton Pattern', N'<p><span style="color:#FF0000"><strong>Singleton Pattern</strong></span></p>

<p>Ensure a class has only one instance and provide a global point of access to it.</p>

<p><strong>Participants</strong></p>

<p>The classes and objects participating in this pattern are:</p>

<ul>
	<li><span style="color:#FF0000"><strong>Singleton &nbsp; (LoadBalancer)</strong></span>

	<ul>
		<li>defines an Instance operation that lets clients access its unique instance.</li>
		<li>responsible for creating and maintaining its own unique instance.</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
</ul>

<p>Structural code in C#</p>

<p>This structural code demonstrates the Singleton pattern which assures only a single instance (the singleton) of the class can be created.</p>

<p><strong>public class Singleton<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; private static Singleton _instance;</strong></p>

<p><strong>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; // Constructor is &#39;protected&#39;<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; protected Singleton()<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; }</strong></p>

<p><strong>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; public static Singleton Instance()<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; // Uses lazy initialization.<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; // Note: this is not thread safe.<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; if (_instance == null)<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; _instance = new Singleton();<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; }</strong></p>

<p><strong>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; return _instance;<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; }<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; }</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><span style="color:#FF0000"><strong>static void Main(string[] args)<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; // Constructor is protected -- cannot use new<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Singleton s1 = Singleton.Instance();<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Singleton s2 = Singleton.Instance();</strong></span></p>

<p><span style="color:#FF0000"><strong>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; // Test for same instance<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; if (s1 == s2)<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Console.WriteLine(&quot;Objects are the same instance&quot;);<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; }</strong></span></p>

<p><span style="color:#FF0000"><strong>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; // Wait for user<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Console.ReadKey();<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; }</strong></span></p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4C300A7E609 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (56, 13, N'Abstract Factory', N'<p><strong>Abstract Factory</strong></p>

<p><span style="font-family:helvetica neue,helvetica,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Provide an interface for creating families of related or dependent objects without specifying their concrete classes.</span></p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4C3012DE90E AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (57, 7, N'Computed Columns', N'<p><strong>Computed Columns</strong></p>

<p>A computed column is a virtual column that is not physically stored in the table, unless the column is marked PERSISTED. A computed column expression can use data from other columns to calculate a value for the column to which it belongs.</p>

<ul>
	<li>A computed column cannot be used as a DEFAULT or FOREIGN KEY constraint definition or with a NOT NULL constraint definition. However, if the computed column value is defined by a deterministic expression and the data type of the result is allowed in index columns, a computed column can be used as a key column in an index or as part of any PRIMARY KEY or UNIQUE constraint. For example, if the table has integer columns a and b, the computed column a + b may be indexed, but computed column a + DATEPART(dd, GETDATE()) cannot be indexed, because the value might change in subsequent invocations.</li>
	<li>A computed column cannot be the target of an INSERT or UPDATE statement.</li>
</ul>

<pre>
CREATE TABLE dbo.Products 
(
    ProductID int IDENTITY (1,1) NOT NULL
  , QtyAvailable smallint
  , UnitPrice money
  , InventoryValue AS QtyAvailable * UnitPrice
);

-- Insert values into the table.
INSERT INTO dbo.Products (QtyAvailable, UnitPrice)
VALUES (25, 2.00), (10, 1.5);

-- Display the rows in the table.
SELECT ProductID, QtyAvailable, UnitPrice, InventoryValue
FROM dbo.Products;</pre>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<ol style="margin-left:2px">
	<li style="text-align:justify">
	<p>The virtual keyword is used to modify a method, property, indexer, or event declared in the base class and allow it to be overridden in the derived class.</p>
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
	<p>The override keyword is used to extend or modify a virtual/abstract method, property, indexer, or event of base class into derived class.</p>
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
	<p>The new keyword is used to hide a method, property, indexer, or event of base class into derived class.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<h3>Q1. What is jQuery?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: jQuery is&nbsp;</span><strong>fast, lightweight and feature-rich&nbsp;</strong><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">client side JavaScript Library/Framework which helps in to traverse HTML DOM, make animations, add Ajax interaction, manipulate the page content, change the style and provide cool UI effect. It is one of the most popular client side library and as per a survey it runs on every second website.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q2. Why do we use jQuery?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: Due to following advantages.</span></p>

<ul>
	<li>Easy to use and learn.</li>
	<li>Easily expandable.</li>
	<li>Cross-browser support (IE 6.0+, FF 1.5+, Safari 2.0+, Opera 9.0+)</li>
	<li>Easy to use for DOM manipulation and traversal.</li>
	<li>Large pool of built in methods.</li>
	<li>AJAX Capabilities.</li>
	<li>Methods for changing or applying CSS, creating animations.</li>
	<li>Event detection and handling.</li>
	<li>Tons of plug-ins for all kind of needs.</li>
</ul>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q3. How JavaScript and jQuery are different?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: JavaScript is a language While jQuery is a library built in the JavaScript language that helps to use the JavaScript language.</span><br />

<h3>Q4. Is jQuery replacement of Java Script?</h3>

<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q14. Is there any difference between body onload() and document.ready() function?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans:&nbsp;</span><code>document.ready()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;function is different from body&nbsp;</span><code>onload()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;function for 2 reasons.</span></p>

<ol>
	<li>We can have more than one&nbsp;<code>document.ready()</code>&nbsp;function in a page where we can have only one body<code>onload</code>&nbsp;function.</li>
	<li><code>document.ready()</code>&nbsp;function is called as soon as DOM is loaded where&nbsp;<code>body.onload()</code>&nbsp;function is called when everything gets loaded on the page that includes DOM, images and all associated resources of the page.</li>
</ol>

The deployment version is also known as minified version. So .min.js is basically the minified version of jQuery library file. Both the files are same as far as functionality is concerned. but .min.js is quite small in size so it loads quickly and saves bandwidth.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q16. Why there are two different version of jQuery library?</h3>

	<li>Production/Deployment</li>
</ol>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">The development version is quite useful at development time as jQuery is open source and if you want to change something then you can make those changes in development&nbsp;version. But the deployment version is minified version or compressed version so it is impossible to make changes in it. Because it is compressed, so its size is very less than the production version which affects the page load time.</span><br />

	<li>Attribute Selector: Select elements based on its attribute value.</li>

<h3>Q41. What is the difference between .empty(), .remove() and .detach() methods in jQuery?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: All these methods&nbsp;</span><code>.empty()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">,&nbsp;</span><code>.remove()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span><code>.detach()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;are used for removing elements from DOM but they all are different.</span><br />
<br />
<code>.empty()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">: This method removes all the child element of the matched element where remove() method removes set of matched elements from DOM.</span><br />
<br />
<code>.remove()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">: Use&nbsp;</span><code>.remove()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;when you want to remove the element itself, as well as everything inside it. In addition to the elements themselves, all bound events and jQuery data associated with the elements are removed.</span><br />
<br />
<code>.detach()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">: This method is the same as&nbsp;</span><code>.remove()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">, except that&nbsp;</span><code>.detach()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;keeps all jQuery data associated with the removed elements. This method is useful when removed elements are to be reinserted into the DOM at a later time.</span><br />
<br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Find out more&nbsp;</span><a href="http://jquerybyexample.blogspot.com/2012/05/empty-vs-remove-vs-detach-jquery.html" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: normal;"><strong>here</strong></a><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q42. Explain .bind() vs .live() vs .delegate() vs .on()</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: All these 4 jQuery methods are used for attaching events to selectors or elements. But they all are different from each other.</span><br />
<br />
<code><a href="http://jquerybyexample.blogspot.com/2010/06/jquery-bind-function-exampledemo.html" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple;">.bind()</a></code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">: This is the easiest and quick method to bind events. But the issue with bind() is that it doesn&#39;t work for elements added dynamically that matches the same selector.&nbsp;</span><code>bind()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;only attach events to the current elements not future element. Above that it also has performance issues when dealing with a large selection.</span><br />
<br />
<code><a href="http://jquerybyexample.blogspot.com/2010/06/jquery-live-function-exampledemo.html" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple;">.live()</a></code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">: This method overcomes the disadvantage of&nbsp;</span><code>bind()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">. It works for dynamically added elements or future elements. Because of its poor performance on large pages, this method is deprecated as of jQuery 1.7 and you should stop using it. Chaining is not properly supported using this method.</span><br />
<br />
<code><a href="http://jquerybyexample.blogspot.com/2010/08/jquery-delegate-function-exampledemo.html" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple;">.delegate()</a></code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">: The .delegate() method behaves in a similar fashion to the .live() method, but instead of attaching the selector/event information to the document, you can choose where it is anchored and it also supports chaining.</span><br />
<br />
<code>.on()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">: Since live was deprecated with 1.7, so new method was introduced named &quot;.on()&quot;. This method provides all the goodness of previous 3 methods and it brings uniformity for attaching event handlers.</span><br />
<br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Find out more&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.elijahmanor.com/2012/02/differences-between-jquery-bind-vs-live.html" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: normal;"><strong>here</strong></a><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q43. What is wrong with this code line &quot;$(&#39;#myid.3&#39;).text(&#39;blah blah!!!&#39;);&quot;</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: The problem with above statement is that the selectors is having meta characters and to use any of the meta-characters ( such as !&quot;#$%&amp;&#39;()*+,./:;&lt;=&gt;?@[\]^`{|}~ ) as a literal part of a name, it must be escaped with with two backslashes: \\. For example, an element with id=&quot;foo.bar&quot;, can use the selector $(&quot;#foo\\.bar&quot;).</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">So the correct syntax is,</span></p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain691814" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
$(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">#myid\\.3&#39;</span>).text(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">blah blah!!!&#39;</span>);
</pre>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q44. How to create clone of any object using jQuery?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: jQuery provides&nbsp;</span><code>clone()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;method which performs a deep copy of the set of matched elements, meaning that it copies the matched elements as well as all of their descendant elements and text nodes.</span></p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain234606" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
$(document).ready(function(){
  $(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">#btnClone&#39;</span>).click(function(){
     $(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">#dvText&#39;</span>).clone().appendTo(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">body&#39;</span>);
     <span style="color:blue">return</span> <span style="color:blue">false</span>;
  });
});
</pre>

<h3>Q45. Does events are also copied when you clone any element in jQuery?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: As explained in previous question, using&nbsp;</span><code>clone()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;method, we can create clone of any element but the default implementation of the&nbsp;</span><code>clone()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;method doesn&#39;t copy events unless you tell the&nbsp;</span><code>clone()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;method to copy the events. The&nbsp;</span><code>clone()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;method takes a parameter, if you pass true then it will copy the events as well.</span></p>

     $(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">#dvClickme&#39;</span>).clone(<span style="color:blue">true</span>).appendTo(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">body&#39;</span>);

<h3>Q46. What is difference between prop and attr?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans:&nbsp;</span><code>attr()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">: Get the value of an attribute for the first element in the set of matched elements. Whereas,</span><code>.prop()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">: (Introduced in jQuery 1.6) Get the value of a property for the first element in the set of matched elements.</span><br />
<br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Attributes carry additional information about an HTML element and come in name=&quot;value&quot; pairs. Where Property is a representation of an attribute in the HTML DOM tree. once the browser parse your HTML code ,corresponding DOM node will be created which is an object thus having properties.</span><br />
<br />
<code>attr()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;gives you the value of element as it was defines in the html on page load. It is always recommended to use&nbsp;</span><code>prop()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;to get values of elements which is modified via javascript/jquery , as it gives you the original value of an element&#39;s current state. Find out more&nbsp;</span><a href="http://techbrij.com/jquery-attr-vs-prop-difference" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: normal;">here</a><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q47. What is event.PreventDefault?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: The&nbsp;</span><code>event.preventDefault()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;method stops the default action of an element from happening. For example, Prevents a link from following the URL.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q48. What is the difference between event.PreventDefault and event.stopPropagation?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans:&nbsp;</span><code>event.preventDefault()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">: Stops the default action of an element from happening.</span><br />
<code>event.stopPropagation()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">: Prevents the event from bubbling up the DOM tree, preventing any parent handlers from being notified of the event. For example, if there is a link with a click method attached inside of a DIV or FORM that also has a click method attached, it will prevent the DIV or FORM click method from firing.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q49. What is the difference between event.PreventDefault and &quot;return false&quot;?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans:&nbsp;</span><code>e.preventDefault()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;will prevent the default event from occurring,&nbsp;</span><code>e.stopPropagation()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;will prevent the event from bubbling up and return false will do both.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q50. What is the difference between event.stopPropagation and event.stopImmediatePropagation?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans:&nbsp;</span><code>event.stopPropagation()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;allows other handlers on the same element to be executed, while</span><code>event.stopImmediatePropagation()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;prevents every event from running. For example, see below jQuery code block.</span></p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain636732" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
$(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">p&quot;</span>).click(function(<span style="color:blue">event</span>){
  <span style="color:blue">event</span>.stopImmediatePropagation();
});
$(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">p&quot;</span>).click(function(<span style="color:blue">event</span>){
  <em>//</em><em> This function won&#39;t be executed
</em>  $(<span style="color:blue">this</span>).css(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">background-color&quot;</span>, <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">#f00&quot;</span>);
}); 
</pre>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">If&nbsp;</span><code>event.stopPropagation</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;was used in previous example, then the next click event on p element which changes the css will fire, but in case&nbsp;</span><code>event.stopImmediatePropagation()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">, the next p click event will not fire.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

This attaches a handler to an event for the element. The handler is executed at most once per element. In simple terms, the attached function will be called only once.</span></p>

<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Below code shows how to include multiple version of jQuery.</span></p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain977548" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
<span style="color:blue">&lt;</span><span style="color:maroon">script</span> <span style="color:red">type</span><span style="color:blue">=&#39;</span><span style="color:blue">text/javascript&#39;</span> <span style="color:red">src</span><span style="color:blue">=&#39;</span><span style="color:blue">js/jquery_1.9.1.min.js&#39;</span><span style="color:blue">&gt;</span><span style="color:blue">&lt;/</span><span style="color:maroon">script</span><span style="color:blue">&gt;</span>

<span style="color:blue">&lt;</span><span style="color:maroon">script</span> <span style="color:red">type</span><span style="color:blue">=&#39;</span><span style="color:blue">text/javascript&#39;</span><span style="color:blue">&gt;</span>
 <span style="color:blue">var</span> $jq = jQuery.noConflict();
<span style="color:blue">&lt;/</span><span style="color:maroon">script</span><span style="color:blue">&gt;</span>

<span style="color:blue">&lt;</span><span style="color:maroon">script</span> <span style="color:red">type</span><span style="color:blue">=&#39;</span><span style="color:blue">text/javascript&#39;</span> <span style="color:red">src</span><span style="color:blue">=&#39;</span><span style="color:blue">js/jquery_1.7.2.min.js&#39;</span><span style="color:blue">&gt;</span><span style="color:blue">&lt;/</span><span style="color:maroon">script</span><span style="color:blue">&gt;</span>
</pre>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">By this way, for your own jQuery code use &quot;$jq&quot;, instead of &quot;$&quot; as &quot;$jq&quot; refers to jQuery 1.9.1, where &quot;$&quot; refers to 1.7.2.</span><br />

<h3>Q56. Is it possible to hold or delay document.ready execution for sometime?</h3>

With Release of jQuery 1.6, a new method &quot;</span><code>jQuery.holdReady(hold)</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&quot; was introduced. This method allows to delay the execution of&nbsp;</span><code>document.ready()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;event.&nbsp;</span><code>document.ready()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;event is called as soon as your DOM is ready but sometimes there is a situation when you want to load additional JavaScript or some plugins which you have referenced.</span></p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain47476" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>
