<h3>Q57. What is chaining in jQuery?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: Chaining is one of the most powerful feature of jQuery. In jQuery, Chaining means to connect multiple functions, events on selectors. It makes your code short and easy to manage and it gives better performance. The chain starts from left to right. So left most will be called first and so on.</span></p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain154721" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
$(document).ready(function(){
    $(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">#dvContent&#39;</span>).addClass(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">dummy&#39;</span>);
    $(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">#dvContent&#39;</span>).css(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">color&#39;</span>, <span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">red&#39;</span>);
    $(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">#dvContent&#39;</span>).fadeIn(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">slow&#39;</span>);
});</pre>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">The above jQuery code sample can be re-written using chaining. See below.</span></p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain413861" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
$(document).ready(function(){
    $(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">#dvContent&#39;</span>).addClass(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">dummy&#39;</span>)
          .css(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">color&#39;</span>, <span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">red&#39;</span>)
          .fadeIn(<span style="color:purple">&#39;</span><span style="color:purple">slow&#39;</span>);     
});</pre>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Not only functions or methods, chaining also works with events in jQuery. Find out more&nbsp;</span><a href="http://jquerybyexample.blogspot.com/2012/06/what-is-chaining-in-jquery.html" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: normal;"><strong>here</strong></a><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q58. How does caching helps and how to use caching in jQuery?&nbsp;</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: Caching is an area which can give you awesome performance, if used properly and at the right place. While using jQuery, you should also think about caching. For example, if you are using any element in jQuery more than one time, then you must cache it. See below code.</span></p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain737817" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
$(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">#myID&quot;</span>).css(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">color&quot;</span>, <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">red&quot;</span>);
<em>//</em><em>Doing some other stuff......
</em>$(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">#myID&quot;</span>).text(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">Error occurred!&quot;</span>);
</pre>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Now in above jQuery code, the element with&nbsp;</span><code>#myID</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;is used twice but without caching. So both the times jQuery had to traverse through DOM and get the element. But if you have saved this in a variable then you just need to reference the variable. So the better way would be,</span></p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain796190" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
var $myElement = $(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">#myID&quot;</span>).css(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">color&quot;</span>, <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">red&quot;</span>);
<em>//</em><em>Doing some other stuff......
</em>$myElement.text(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">Error occurred!&quot;</span>);
</pre>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">So now in this case, jQuery won&#39;t need to traverse through the whole DOM tree when it is used second time. So in jQuery, Caching is like saving the jQuery selector in a variable. And using the variable reference when required instead of searching through DOM again.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q59. You get &quot;jquery is not defined&quot; or &quot;$ is not defined&quot; error. What could be the reason?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: There could be many reasons for this.</span></p>

<ul>

	<li>You have include the reference of the jQuery file, but it is after your jQuery code.</li>

</ul>

<h3>Q61. Can we use jQuery to make ajax request?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: Yes. jQuery can be used for making ajax request.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q62. What are various methods to make ajax request in jQuery?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: Using below jQuery methods, you can make ajax calls.</span></p>

<ul>
	<li><code>load()</code>&nbsp;: Load a piece of html into a container DOM</li>
	<li><code>$.getJSON()</code>: Load JSON with GET method.</li>
	<li><code>$.getScript()</code>: Load a JavaScript file.</li>
	<li><code>$.get()</code>: Use to make a GET call and play extensively with the response.</li>
	<li><code>$.post()</code>: Use to make a POST call and don&#39;t want to load the response to some container DOM.</li>
	<li><code>$.ajax()</code>: Use this to do something on XHR failures, or to specify ajax options (e.g. cache: true) on the fly.</li>
</ul>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Find out more&nbsp;</span><a href="http://net.tutsplus.com/tutorials/javascript-ajax/5-ways-to-make-ajax-calls-with-jquery/" rel="nofollow" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: normal;"><strong>here</strong></a><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q63. Is there any advantage of using $.ajax() for ajax call against $.get() or $.post()?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: By using jQuery&nbsp;</span><code>post()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">/ jQuery&nbsp;</span><code>get()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">, you always trust the response from the server and you believe it is going to be successful all the time. Well, it is certainly not a good idea to trust the response. As there can be n number of reason which may lead to failure of response.</span><br />
<br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Where&nbsp;</span><code>jQuery.ajax()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;is jQuery&#39;s low-level AJAX implementation.&nbsp;</span><code>$.get</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span><code>$.post</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;are higher-level abstractions that are often easier to understand and use, but don&#39;t offer as much functionality (such as error callbacks). Find out more&nbsp;</span><strong><a href="http://jquerybyexample.blogspot.com/2011/11/avoid-jquerypost-use-jqueryajax.html" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple;">here</a></strong><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q64. What are deferred and promise object in jQuery?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: Deferred and promise are part of jQuery since version 1.5 and they help in handling asynchronous functions like Ajax. Find out more&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.bitstorm.org/weblog/2012-1/Deferred_and_promise_in_jQuery.html" rel="nofollow" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: normal;"><strong>here</strong></a><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q65. Can we execute/run multiple Ajax request simultaneously in jQuery? If yes, then how?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: Yes, it is possible to execute multiple Ajax request simultaneously or in parallel. Instead of waiting for first ajax request to complete and then issue the second request is time consuming. The better approach to speed up things would be to execute multiple ajax request simultaneously.</span><br />
<br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Using jQuery&nbsp;</span><code>.when()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;method which provides a way to execute callback functions based on one or more objects, usually Deferred objects that represent asynchronous events. Find out more&nbsp;</span><strong><a href="http://jquerybyexample.blogspot.com/2013/05/jquery-execute-multiple-ajax-request-simultaneously-in-parallel.html" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple;">here</a></strong><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q66. Can you call C# code-behind method using jQuery? If yes,then how?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: Yes. We can call C# code-behind function via $.ajax. But for do that it is compulsory to mark the method as WebMethod.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q67. Which is the latest version of jQuery library?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: The latest version (when this post is written) of jQuery is 1.10.2 or 2.0.3. jQuery 2.x has the same API as jQuery 1.x, but does not support Internet Explorer 6, 7, or 8.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q68. Does jQuery 2.0 supports IE?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: No. jQuery 2.0 has no support for IE 6, IE 7 and IE 8.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q69. What are source maps in jQuery?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: In case of jQuery, Source Map is nothing but mapping of minified version of jQuery against the un-minified version. Source map allows to debug minified version of jQuery library. Source map feature was release with jQuery 1.9. Find out more&nbsp;</span><strong><a href="http://jquerybyexample.blogspot.com/2013/01/all-you-need-to-know-about-jquery-source-maps.html" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple;">here</a></strong><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q70. How to use migrate jQuery plugin?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: with release of 1.9 version of jQuery, many deprecated methods were discarded and they are no longer available. But there are many sites in production which are still using these deprecated features and it&#39;s not possible to replace them overnight. So jQuery team provided with jQuery Migrate plugin that makes code written prior to 1.9 work with it.</span><br />
<br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">So to use old/deprecated features, all you need to do is to provide reference of jQuery Migrate Plugin. Find out more&nbsp;</span><a href="http://jquerybyexample.blogspot.com/2013/01/migrate-older-jquery-code-to-jquery1-9.html" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: normal;"><strong>here</strong></a><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q71. Is it possible to get value of multiple CSS properties in single statement?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: Well, before jQuery 1.9 release it was not possible but one of the new feature of jQuery 1.9 was&nbsp;</span><code>.css()</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">multi-property getter.</span></p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain479012" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
var propCollection = $(<span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">#dvBox&quot;</span>).css([ <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">width&quot;</span>, <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">height&quot;</span>, <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">backgroundColor&quot;</span> ]);
</pre>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">In this case, the&nbsp;</span><code>propCollection</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;will be an array and it will look something like this.</span></p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain659471" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
{ 
  width: <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">100px&quot;</span>, 
  height: <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">200px&quot;</span>, 
  backgroundColor: <span style="color:purple">&quot;</span><span style="color:purple">#FF00FF&quot;</span> 
}
</pre>

<h3>Q72. How do you stop the currently-running animation, remove all queued animations, and complete all animations for the matched elements?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: It can be done via calling&nbsp;</span><code>.stop([clearQueue ] [, jumpToEnd ])</code><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;method and by passing both the parameters as true.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q73. What is finish method in jQuery?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: The .finish() method stops all queued animations and places the element(s) in their final state. This method was introduced in jQuery 1.9.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q74. What is the difference between calling stop(true,true) and finish method?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: The .finish() method is similar to .stop(true, true) in that it clears the queue and the current animation jumps to its end value. It differs, however, in that .finish() also causes the CSS property of all queued animations to jump to their end values, as well.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q75. Consider a scenario where things can be done easily with javascript, would you still prefer jQuery?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: No. If things can be done easily via CSS or JavaScript then You should not think about jQuery. Remember, jQuery library always comes with xx kilobyte size and there is no point of wasting bandwidth.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q76. Can we use protocol less URL while referencing jQuery from CDNs?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: Yes. Below code is completely valid.</span></p>

<div class="pre-action-link" id="premain368745" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 11px; text-align: right; color: rgb(153, 153, 153); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; line-height: normal; width: 700px;">Hide&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copy Code</div>

<pre>
<span style="color:blue">&lt;</span><span style="color:maroon">script</span> <span style="color:red">type</span><span style="color:blue">=&quot;</span><span style="color:blue">text/javascript&quot;</span> <span style="color:red">src</span><span style="color:blue">=&quot;</span><span style="color:blue">//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.9.1/jquery.min.js&quot;</span><span style="color:blue">&gt;</span><span style="color:blue">&lt;/</span><span style="color:maroon">script</span><span style="color:blue">&gt;</span>
</pre>

<h3>Q77. What is the advantage of using protocol less URL while referencing jQuery from CDNs?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: It is quite useful when you are moving from HTTP to HTTPS url. You need to make sure that correct protocol is used for referencing jQuery library as pages served via SSL should contain no references to content served through unencrypted connections.</span><br />
<br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&quot;protocol-less&quot; URL is the best way to reference third party content that&rsquo;s available via both HTTP and HTTPS. When a URL&rsquo;s protocol is omitted, the browser uses the underlying document&rsquo;s protocol instead. Find out more</span><a href="http://jquerybyexample.blogspot.com/2013/06/use-protocol-less-url-referencing-jquery.html" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: normal;"><strong>here</strong></a><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q78. What is jQuery plugin and what is the advantage of using plugin?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: A plug-in is piece of code written in a standard JavaScript file. These files provide useful jQuery methods which can be used along with jQuery library methods. jQuery plugins are quite useful as its piece of code which is already written by someone and re-usable, which saves your development time.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q79. What is jQuery UI?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: jQuery UI is a curated set of user interface interactions, effects, widgets, and themes built on top of the jQuery JavaScript Library that can be used to build interactive web applications.</span><br />
<span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;</span></p>

<h3>Q80. What is the difference between jQuery and jQuery UI?</h3>

<p><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">Ans: jQuery is the core library. jQueryUI is built on top of it. If you use jQueryUI, you must also include jQuery.</span><br />
<br />
<strong>Note</strong><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">: If you have any questions to add to this list then please put it comments. We will be glad to add them in this list. We will be keep on updating this list with new questions and share the updates on our&nbsp;</span><a href="http://www.facebook.com/jQueryByExample" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: normal;"><strong>Facebook</strong></a><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;or</span><a href="https://twitter.com/jquerybyexample" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: purple; font-family: ''Segoe UI'', Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: normal;"><strong>Twitter</strong></a><span style="color:rgb(17, 17, 17); font-family:segoe ui,arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px">&nbsp;channel. If you are not following us then request you to please follow and stay updated.</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4C4005C0F3F AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (60, 3, N'How can we maintain sessions in MVC?', N'<p><strong>How can we maintain sessions in MVC??</strong></p>

<p>Sessions can be maintained in MVC by three ways: tempdata, viewdata, and viewbag.</p>

<p><strong>What is the difference between tempdata, viewdata, and viewbag?</strong></p>

<p><strong>Temp data</strong> - Helps to maintain data when you move from one controller to another controller or from one action to another action. In other words when you redirect, tempdata helps to maintain data between those redirects. It internally uses session variables.</p>

<p><strong>View data</strong> - Helps to maintain data when you move from controller to view.</p>

<p><strong>View Bag</strong> - It&rsquo;s a dynamic wrapper around view data. When you use Viewbag type, casting is not required. It uses the dynamic keyword internally.</p>

<p><strong>Session Variables:&nbsp;</strong>By using session variables we can maintain data from any entity to any entity.</p>

<p><strong>Hidden fields and HTML controls</strong>:</p>

<p>Helps to maintain data from UI to controller only. So you can send data from HTML controls or hidden fields to the controller using POST or GET HTTP methods.</p>

<p>Below is a summary table which shows the different mechanisms for persistence.</p>

<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td style="width:164px">
			<p><strong>Maintains data between</strong></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:171px">
			<p><strong>ViewData/ViewBag</strong></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:100px">
			<p><strong>TempData</strong></p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p><strong>Hidden fields</strong></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:77px">
			<p><strong>Session</strong></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width:164px">
			<p><strong>Controller to Controller</strong></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:171px">
			<p>No</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:100px">
			<p>Yes</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>No</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:77px">
			<p>Yes</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width:164px">
			<p><strong>Controller to View</strong></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:171px">
			<p>Yes</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:100px">
			<p>No</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>No</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:77px">
			<p>Yes</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width:164px">
			<p><strong>View to Controller</strong></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:171px">
			<p>No</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:100px">
			<p>No</p>
			</td>
			<td>
			<p>Yes</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:77px">
			<p>Yes</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Does &ldquo;TempData&rdquo; preserve data in the next request also?</strong></p>

<p>&ldquo;TempData&rdquo; is available through out for the current request and in the subsequent request it&rsquo;s available depending on whether &ldquo;TempData&rdquo; is read or not. So if &ldquo;TempData&rdquo; is once read it will not be available in the subsequent request.</p>

<p><strong>What is the use of Keep and Peek in &ldquo;TempData&rdquo;?</strong></p>

<p>Once &ldquo;TempData&rdquo; is read in the current request it&rsquo;s not available in the subsequent request. If we want &ldquo;TempData&rdquo; to be read and also available in the subsequent request then after reading we need to call &ldquo;Keep&rdquo; method as shown in the code below.</p>

<p><strong>@TempData[&ldquo;MyData&rdquo;];</strong></p>

<p><strong>TempData.Keep(&ldquo;MyData&rdquo;);</strong></p>

<p>The more shortcut way of achieving the same is by using &ldquo;Peek&rdquo;. This function helps to read as well advices MVC to maintain &ldquo;TempData&rdquo; for the subsequent request.</p>

<p>string str = TempData.Peek(&quot;Td&quot;).ToString();</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A4C4008133CC AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (61, 3, N'ASP.NET MVC Routing', N'<p><span style="color:rgb(80, 80, 80); font-family:segoe ui,tahoma,arial,helvetica,sans-serif; font-size:13.008px">The ASP.NET Routing module is responsible for mapping incoming browser requests to particular MVC controller actions.</span></p>

<h2>Using the Default Route Table</h2>

<p>When you create a new ASP.NET MVC application, the application is already configured to use ASP.NET Routing. ASP.NET Routing is setup in two places.</p>

<p>First, ASP.NET Routing is enabled in your application&#39;s Web configuration file (Web.config file). There are four sections in the configuration file that are relevant to routing: the system.web.httpModules section, the system.web.httpHandlers section, the system.webserver.modules section, and the system.webserver.handlers section. Be careful not to delete these sections because without these sections routing will no longer work.</p>

<p>Second, and more importantly, a route table is created in the application&#39;s Global.asax file. The Global.asax file is a special file that contains event handlers for ASP.NET application lifecycle events. The route table is created during the Application Start event.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<pre>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>When an MVC application first starts, the Application_Start() method is called. This method, in turn, calls the RegisterRoutes() method. The RegisterRoutes() method creates the route table.</p>

<p>The default route table contains a single route (named Default). The Default route maps the first segment of a URL to a controller name, the second segment of a URL to a controller action, and the third segment to a parameter named&nbsp;<strong>id</strong>.</p>

<p>Imagine that you enter the following URL into your web browser&#39;s address bar:</p>

<p>/Home/Index/3</p>

<p>The Default route maps this URL to the following parameters:</p>

<p>controller = Home</p>

<ul>
</ul>

<p>action = Index</p>

<ul>
</ul>

<p>id = 3</p>

<ul>
</ul>

<p>When you request the URL /Home/Index/3, the following code is executed:</p>

<p>HomeController.Index(3)</p>

<p>The Default route includes defaults for all three parameters. If you don&#39;t supply a controller, then the controller parameter defaults to the value<strong>Home</strong>. If you don&#39;t supply an action, the action parameter defaults to the value&nbsp;<strong>Index</strong>. Finally, if you don&#39;t supply an id, the id parameter defaults to an empty string.</p>

<p>Let&#39;s look at a few examples of how the Default route maps URLs to controller actions. Imagine that you enter the following URL into your browser address bar:</p>

<p>/Home</p>

<p>Because of the Default route parameter defaults, entering this URL will cause the Index() method of the HomeController class in Listing 2 to be called.</p>

<p>In Listing 2, the HomeController class includes a method named Index() that accepts a single parameter named Id. The URL /Home causes the Index() method to be called with an empty string as the value of the Id parameter.</p>

<p>Because of the way that the MVC framework invokes controller actions, the URL /Home also matches the Index() method of the HomeController class in Listing 3.</p>

</span></pre>

<p>In Listing 4, the Index() method has one Integer parameter. Because the parameter is a nullable parameter (can have the value Null), the Index() can be called without raising an error.</p>

<p>Finally, invoking the Index() method in Listing 5 with the URL /Home causes an exception since the Id parameter&nbsp;<em>is not</em>&nbsp;a nullable parameter. If you attempt to invoke the Index() method then you get the error displayed in Figure 1.</p>

INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (62, 12, N'ObjectContext VS DBContext', N'<p><strong>Introduction</strong><br />
<br />
ObjectContext and DbContext have the capability to query and work with data as objects. Additionally Dbcontext can be represented as a combination of the Unit of Work and Repository patterns. Conceptually DbContext is the same as ObjectContext.<br />
<br />
<strong>ObjectContext</strong><br />
<br />
ObjectContext is a class that manages all the database operations, like database connection, and manages various entities of the Entity Model. We can say that ObjectContext is the primary class for accessing or working together with entities that are defined in the conceptual model.<br />
<br />
ObjectContext is responsible for:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Database connection</li>
	<li>It provides builtin Add, Update and Delete functions</li>
	<li>Object Set of every entity</li>
	<li>Provide State of pending changes</li>
	<li>It holds the changes done in entities</li>
</ul>

<p>ObjectContext also encapsulates a&nbsp;few of things; they are:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Connection to the Data Store or Database</li>
	<li>Metadata in the Entity Data Model&nbsp;(EDM)</li>
	<li>ObjectStateManager to track changes to the objects</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>DbContext</strong><br />
<br />
DbContext is conceptually similar to ObjectContext. DbContext is nothing but a ObjectContext wrapper, we can say it is a lightweight alternative to the ObjectContext. DbContext can be used for DataBase first, code first and model first development. DbContext mainly contains a set of APIs that&nbsp;are very easy to use. The API is exposed by ObjectContext. These APIs also allow us to use a Code First approach that ObjectContext does not allow.&nbsp;<br />
<br />
<strong>ObjectContext VS DbContext</strong></p>

<table border="1" cellspacing="1" style="line-height:21px; width:80%">
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td style="width:319px">
			<p><strong>ObjectContext</strong></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:634px">
			<p><strong>DbContext</strong></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width:319px">
			<p>ObjectContext class is part of the core Entity Framework API, that allows us to perform queries, change and track updates of the Database by using strongly typed entity classes.</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:634px">
			<p>The DbContext class can be described as a wrapper of ObjectContext. It exposes the most commonly used features of ObjectContext.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width:319px">
			<p>ObjectContext supports Compiled Queries.</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:634px">
			<p>DbContext does not support Compiled Queries.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width:319px">
			<p>ObjectContext supports self-tracking of Entities</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:634px">
			<p>DbContext does not support self-tracking of Entities.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width:319px">
			<p>ObjectContext is only useful in Model First and Database First approaches</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:634px">
			<p>DbContext is useful in Model First, Database First approach as well as Code First approach.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width:319px">
			<p>ObjectContext can be used by Entity Framework 4.0 and below.</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:634px">
			<p>DBContext can be used by Entity Framework 4.1 and above.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width:319px">
			<p>The ObjectContext class is not thread-safe.</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width:634px">
			<p>Any public static (C#) or Shared (Visual Basic) members of DbContext are thread-safe. Any instance members are not guaranteed to be thread safe.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p>There are also many methods in common in both ObjectContext and DbContext. For example ObjectContext has a direct method to execute&nbsp;a query against a database whereas the DbContext.DataBase class contains the SQLQuery method to&nbsp;obtain the same result.<br />
<br />
<strong>Example</strong></p>

<p>// using ObjectContext (EF4.0)<br />
using&nbsp;(Entities&nbsp;context =&nbsp;new&nbsp;Entities())<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IEnumerable&lt;EmployeeDetails&gt; empDetails &nbsp;= &nbsp;context.ExecuteStoreQuery&lt;EmployeeDetails&gt; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; (&quot;exec GetEmployeeData&quot;).ToList();<br />
}</p>

<p>// using DBContext (EF 4.1 and above)<br />
using&nbsp;(Entities&nbsp;context =&nbsp;new&nbsp;Entities())<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;IEnumerable&lt;EmployeeDetails&gt; empDetails &nbsp;= &nbsp;context. Database.SqlQuery<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &lt;&nbsp;EmployeeDetails&nbsp;&gt;(&quot;exec&nbsp;GetEmployeeData&nbsp;&quot;, null).ToList();<br />
}<br />
<br />
DbContext also has some sets of methods that are not available with ObjectContext, like Dbset.Find, DbSet.Local etcetera.<br />
<br />
Some of the ObjectContext methods are also renamed. For example ObjectContext has methods like AddObject, DeleteObject And Attech on ObjectSet&lt;T&gt;, in DbContext, they are named Add, Remove and Attach on DbSet&lt;TEntity&gt;.<br />
<br />
<strong>Conclusion</strong><br />
<br />
Dbcontext can be defined as a lightweight version of the ObjectContext or we can say Dbcontext is a wrapper of ObjectContext and exposes only the common features that are really required in programming.<br />
We can also get&nbsp;a reference to the ObjectContext from then DbContext to use those features that are only supported in ObjectContext.<br />
<br />
The following code could help to get an ObjectContext Object from an existing DbContext Object.<br />
<br />
public&nbsp;class&nbsp;EntityDBContext:&nbsp;DbContext,&nbsp;IObjectContextAdapter<br />
{<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ObjectContext IObjectContextAdapter.ObjectContext<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; {<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;get&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; {&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;var&nbsp;objectContext = (this&nbsp;as&nbsp;IObjectContextAdapter)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;if(objectContext !=&nbsp;null)<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;return&nbsp;(this&nbsp;as&nbsp;IObjectContextAdapter).ObjectContext;&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;else&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; return null;<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; }<br />
&nbsp;&nbsp; }<br />
}<br />
<br />
Finally, DbContext is not a replacement of ObjectContext, but it is a simple alternative that builds on ObjectContext.<br />
<br />
Hope this will help to understand the differences between ObjectContext and DbContext.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A58601635A94 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (63, 4, N'Why does C# doesn''t support multiple inheritance', N'<p>C# doesn&#39;t support multiple inheritance due to diamond problem.</p>

<p><strong>Diamond Problem:&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p>The diamond problem is an ambiguity that arises when two classes B and C inherit from A, and class D inherits from both B and C. If a method in D calls a method defined in A (and does not override the method), and B and C have overridden that method differently, then from which class does it inherit: B, or C?</p>

<p><strong>Example:</strong></p>

<p>I have a class Shape1</p>

<p>It has CalcualteArea method<br />
Class Shape1<br />
{<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;public void CalculateArea()<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;//<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</p>

<p>There is another class shape2 that one also has same method&nbsp;<br />
Class Shape2<br />
{<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;public void CalculateArea()<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;{<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;//<br />
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;}<br />
}</p>

<p>Now i have a child class Circle, it derives from both SHape1 and shape2;</p>

<p>public class Circle: Shape1,Shape2<br />
{<br />
}</p>

<p><br />
Now when i create object for Circle, and call the method, system doesnt know which calculate area method to be called.. Both has same signatures. So compiler will get confuse .thats why multiple inheritances are not allowed.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A5890114D00B AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (64, 4, N'C# - Data Types', N'<p style="text-align:justify">The varibles in C#, are categorized into the following types:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Value types</li>
	<li>Reference types</li>
	<li>Pointer types</li>
</ul>

<h2>Value Type</h2>

<p style="text-align:justify">Value type variables can be assigned a value directly. They are derived from the class&nbsp;<strong>System.ValueType</strong>.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">The value types directly contain data. Some examples are&nbsp;<strong>int, char, and float</strong>, which stores numbers, alphabets, and floating point numbers, respectively. When you declare an&nbsp;<strong>int</strong>&nbsp;type, the system allocates memory to store the value.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">The following table lists the available value types in C# 2010:</p>

<table class="table table-bordered" style="background-color:transparent; border-collapse:collapse; border-spacing:0px; border:1px solid rgb(221, 221, 221); box-sizing:border-box; color:rgb(49, 49, 49); font-family:verdana,geneva,tahoma,arial,helvetica,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:22px; margin-bottom:20px; max-width:100%; width:604px">
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<th style="vertical-align:top; width:71px">Type</th>
			<th style="vertical-align:top; width:193px">Represents</th>
			<th style="vertical-align:top; width:265px">Range</th>
			<th style="vertical-align:top; width:74px">Default Value</th>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">bool</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Boolean value</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">True or False</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">False</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">byte</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">8-bit unsigned integer</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0 to 255</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">char</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">16-bit Unicode character</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">U +0000 to U +ffff</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">&#39;\0&#39;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">decimal</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">128-bit precise decimal values with 28-29 significant digits</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">(-7.9 x 10<sup>28</sup>&nbsp;to 7.9 x 10<sup>28</sup>) / 10<sup>0 to 28</sup></td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0.0M</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">double</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">64-bit double-precision floating point type</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">(+/-)5.0 x 10<sup>-324</sup>&nbsp;to (+/-)1.7 x 10<sup>308</sup></td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0.0D</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">float</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">32-bit single-precision floating point type</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">-3.4 x 10<sup>38</sup>&nbsp;to + 3.4 x 10<sup>38</sup></td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0.0F</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">int</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">32-bit signed integer type</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">-2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">long</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">64-bit signed integer type</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">-9,223,372,036,854,775,808 to 9,223,372,036,854,775,807</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0L</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">sbyte</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">8-bit signed integer type</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">-128 to 127</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">short</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">16-bit signed integer type</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">-32,768 to 32,767</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">uint</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">32-bit unsigned integer type</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0 to 4,294,967,295</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">ulong</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">64-bit unsigned integer type</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0 to 18,446,744,073,709,551,615</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">ushort</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">16-bit unsigned integer type</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0 to 65,535</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">0</td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p style="text-align:justify">To get the exact size of a type or a variable on a particular platform, you can use the&nbsp;<strong>sizeof</strong>&nbsp;method. The expression&nbsp;<em>sizeof(type)</em>&nbsp;yields the storage size of the object or type in bytes. Following is an example to get the size of&nbsp;<em>int</em>&nbsp;type on any machine:</p>

<pre>
<span style="color:rgb(0, 0, 136)">using</span> <span style="color:rgb(127, 0, 85)">System</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">;</span>
<span style="color:rgb(0, 0, 136)">namespace</span> <span style="color:rgb(127, 0, 85)">DataTypeApplication</span>
<span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">{</span>
   <span style="color:rgb(0, 0, 136)">class</span> <span style="color:rgb(127, 0, 85)">Program</span> 
   <span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">{</span>
      <span style="color:rgb(0, 0, 136)">static</span> <span style="color:rgb(0, 0, 136)">void</span> <span style="color:rgb(127, 0, 85)">Main</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">(</span><span style="color:rgb(0, 0, 136)">string</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">[]</span> args<span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">)</span>
      <span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">{</span>
         <span style="color:rgb(127, 0, 85)">Console</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">.</span><span style="color:rgb(127, 0, 85)">WriteLine</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">(</span><span style="color:rgb(0, 136, 0)">&quot;Size of int: {0}&quot;</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">,</span> <span style="color:rgb(0, 0, 136)">sizeof</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">(</span><span style="color:rgb(0, 0, 136)">int</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">));</span>
         <span style="color:rgb(127, 0, 85)">Console</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">.</span><span style="color:rgb(127, 0, 85)">ReadLine</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">();</span>
      <span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">}</span>
   <span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">}</span>
<span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">}</span></pre>

<p style="text-align:justify">When the above code is compiled and executed, it produces the following result:</p>

<pre>
Size of int: 4
</pre>

<h2>Reference Type</h2>

<p style="text-align:justify">The reference types do not contain the actual data stored in a variable, but they contain a reference to the variables.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">In other words, they refer to a memory location. Using multiple variables, the reference types can refer to a memory location. If the data in the memory location is changed by one of the variables, the other variable automatically reflects this change in value. Example of&nbsp;<strong>built-in</strong>&nbsp;reference types are:&nbsp;<strong>object</strong>,<strong>dynamic,</strong>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<strong>string</strong>.</p>

<h3>Object Type</h3>

<p style="text-align:justify">The&nbsp;<strong>Object Type</strong>&nbsp;is the ultimate base class for all data types in C# Common Type System (CTS). Object is an alias for System.Object class. The object types can be assigned values of any other types, value types, reference types, predefined or user-defined types. However, before assigning values, it needs type conversion.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">When a value type is converted to object type, it is called&nbsp;<strong>boxing</strong>&nbsp;and on the other hand, when an object type is converted to a value type, it is called<strong>unboxing</strong>.</p>

<pre>
<span style="color:rgb(0, 0, 136)">object</span> obj<span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">;</span>
obj <span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">=</span> <span style="color:rgb(0, 102, 102)">100</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">;</span> <span style="color:rgb(136, 0, 0)">// this is boxing</span></pre>

<h3>Dynamic Type</h3>

<p style="text-align:justify">You can store any type of value in the dynamic data type variable. Type checking for these types of variables takes place at run-time.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Syntax for declaring a dynamic type is:</p>

<pre>
<span style="color:rgb(0, 0, 136)">dynamic</span> <span style="color:rgb(0, 136, 0)">&lt;variable_name&gt;</span> <span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">=</span> value<span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">;</span></pre>

<p style="text-align:justify">For example,</p>

<pre>
<span style="color:rgb(0, 0, 136)">dynamic</span> d <span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">=</span> <span style="color:rgb(0, 102, 102)">20</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">;</span></pre>

<p style="text-align:justify">Dynamic types are similar to object types except that type checking for object type variables takes place at compile time, whereas that for the dynamic type variables takes place at run time.</p>

<h3>String Type</h3>

<p style="text-align:justify">The&nbsp;<strong>String Type</strong>&nbsp;allows you to assign any string values to a variable. The string type is an alias for the System.String class. It is derived from object type. The value for a string type can be assigned using string literals in two forms: quoted and @quoted.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">For example,</p>

<pre>
<span style="color:rgb(127, 0, 85)">String</span> str <span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">=</span> <span style="color:rgb(0, 136, 0)">&quot;Tutorials Point&quot;</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">;</span></pre>

<p style="text-align:justify">A @quoted string literal looks as follows:</p>

<pre>
<span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">@</span><span style="color:rgb(0, 136, 0)">&quot;Tutorials Point&quot;</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">;</span></pre>

<p style="text-align:justify">The user-defined reference types are: class, interface, or delegate. We will discuss these types in later chapter.</p>

<h2>Pointer Type</h2>

<p style="text-align:justify">Pointer type variables store the memory address of another type. Pointers in C# have the same capabilities as the pointers in C or C++.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Syntax for declaring a pointer type is:</p>

<pre>
type<span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">*</span> identifier<span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">;</span></pre>

<p style="text-align:justify">For example,</p>

<pre>
<span style="color:rgb(0, 0, 136)">char</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">*</span> cptr<span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">;</span>
<span style="color:rgb(0, 0, 136)">int</span><span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">*</span> iptr<span style="color:rgb(102, 102, 0)">;</span></pre>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A5890119B8AD AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (65, 4, N'Boxing and Unboxing', N'<p>Boxing is the process of converting a&nbsp;<a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/s1ax56ch.aspx" style="text-decoration: none; color: rgb(0, 112, 159);">value type</a>&nbsp;to the type&nbsp;<strong>object</strong>&nbsp;or to any interface type implemented by this value type. When the CLR boxes a value type, it wraps the value inside a System.Object and stores it on the managed heap. Unboxing extracts the value type from the object. Boxing is implicit; unboxing is explicit. The concept of boxing and unboxing underlies the C# unified view of the type system in which a value of any type can be treated as an object.</p>

<p>In the following example, the integer variable&nbsp;<span style="color:rgb(0, 100, 0); font-family:consolas,courier,monospace">i</span>&nbsp;is&nbsp;<em>boxed</em>&nbsp;and assigned to object&nbsp;<span style="color:rgb(0, 100, 0); font-family:consolas,courier,monospace">o</span>.</p>

<div class="codeSnippetContainer" id="code-snippet-1" style="min-width: 0px; clear: both; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', ''Lucida Grande'', Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 17.55px;">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerTabs" style="vertical-align: middle; height: 23px; position: relative; z-index: 1;">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerTabSingle" dir="ltr" style="line-height: 17px; height: 23px; float: left; width: auto; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(112, 112, 112); position: relative; border-width: 1px; border-style: solid; border-color: rgb(147, 147, 147) rgb(147, 147, 147) rgb(255, 255, 255); border-top-left-radius: 4px; border-top-right-radius: 4px;">C#</div>
</div>

<div class="codeSnippetContainerCodeContainer" style="border: 1px solid rgb(147, 147, 147); clear: both; margin-bottom: 12px; position: relative; top: -1px;">
<div class="codeSnippetToolBar" style="width: auto; height: auto;">
<div class="codeSnippetToolBarText" style="float: right; top: -8px; position: relative; width: auto; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0px; height: 0px; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</div>
</div>

<div class="codeSnippetContainerCode" dir="ltr" id="CodeSnippetContainerCode_91420e79-1d02-419c-82a6-141fa460c3aa" style="width: auto; margin: 0px; padding: 10px 21px;">
<div style="padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
<pre>
<span style="color:blue">int</span> i = 123;
<span style="color:green">// The following line boxes i.</span>
<span style="color:blue">object</span> o = i;  
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<p>The object&nbsp;<span style="color:rgb(0, 100, 0); font-family:consolas,courier,monospace">o&nbsp;</span>can then be unboxed and assigned to integer variable&nbsp;<span style="color:rgb(0, 100, 0); font-family:consolas,courier,monospace">i</span>:</p>

<div class="codeSnippetContainer" id="code-snippet-2" style="min-width: 0px; clear: both; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: ''Segoe UI'', ''Lucida Grande'', Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 17.55px;">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerTabs" style="vertical-align: middle; height: 23px; position: relative; z-index: 1;">
<div class="codeSnippetContainerTabSingle" dir="ltr" style="line-height: 17px; height: 23px; float: left; width: auto; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(112, 112, 112); position: relative; border-width: 1px; border-style: solid; border-color: rgb(147, 147, 147) rgb(147, 147, 147) rgb(255, 255, 255); border-top-left-radius: 4px; border-top-right-radius: 4px;">C#</div>
</div>

<div class="codeSnippetContainerCodeContainer" style="border: 1px solid rgb(147, 147, 147); clear: both; margin-bottom: 12px; position: relative; top: -1px;">
<div class="codeSnippetToolBar" style="width: auto; height: auto;">
<div class="codeSnippetToolBarText" style="float: right; top: -8px; position: relative; width: auto; padding-left: 0px; padding-right: 0px; height: 0px; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</div>
</div>

<div class="codeSnippetContainerCode" dir="ltr" id="CodeSnippetContainerCode_680321e3-7f22-47aa-a981-049c763ae306" style="width: auto; margin: 0px; padding: 10px 21px;">
<div style="padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
<pre>
o = 123;
i = (<span style="color:blue">int</span>)o;  <span style="color:green">// unboxing</span>
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A589011B5EEB AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (66, 4, N'Difference between a Value Type and a Reference Type', N'<p>The Types in .NET Framework are either treated by Value Type or by Reference Type. A Value Type holds the data within its own memory allocation and a Reference Type contains a pointer to another memory location that holds the real data. Reference Type variables are stored in the heap while Value Type variables are stored in the stack.</p>

<p><img alt="difference between value type and reference type" src="http://net-informations.com/faq/general/img/reference-type.png" style="height:208px; width:462px" /></p>

<p><strong>Value Type:</strong></p>

<p>A Value Type stores its contents in memory allocated on the stack. When you created a Value Type, a single space in memory is allocated to store the value and that variable directly holds a value. If you assign it to another variable, the value is copied directly and both variables work independently. Predefined datatypes, structures, enums are also value types, and work in the same way. Value types can be created at compile time and Stored in stack memory, because of this, Garbage collector can&#39;t access the stack.</p>

<p>e.g.</p>

<div style="font-family: verdana; font-size: medium; line-height: normal; width: 580px; height: auto; color: rgb(0, 0, 255); overflow-x: auto; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">int x = 10;</div>

<p>Here the value 10 is stored in an area of memory called the stack.</p>

<p><strong>Reference Type:</strong></p>

<p>Reference Types are used by a reference which holds a reference (address) to the object but not the object itself. Because reference types represent the address of the variable rather than the data itself, assigning a reference variable to another doesn&#39;t copy the data. Instead it creates a second copy of the reference, which refers to the same location of the heap as the original value. Reference Type variables are stored in a different area of memory called the heap. This means that when a reference type variable is no longer used, it can be marked for garbage collection. Examples of reference types are Classes, Objects, Arrays, Indexers, Interfaces etc.</p>

<p>e.g.</p>

<div style="font-family: verdana; font-size: medium; line-height: normal; width: 580px; height: auto; color: rgb(0, 0, 255); overflow-x: auto; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">int[] iArray = new int[20];</div>

<p>In the above code the space required for the 20 integers that make up the array is allocated on the heap.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A589011D8BA0 AS DateTime))
INSERT [dbo].[Post] ([Id], [CategoryId], [Title], [Details], [IsPublished], [PostedBy], [PostedOn]) VALUES (67, 4, N'Differences between Stack and Heap', N'<p>Stack is used for static memory allocation and Heap for dynamic memory allocation, both stored in the computer&#39;s RAM .</p>

<p>Variables allocated on the stack are stored directly to the memory and access to this memory is very fast, and it&#39;s allocation is dealt with when the program is compiled. When a function or a method calls another function which in turns calls another function etc., the execution of all those functions remains suspended until the very last function returns its value. The stack is always reserved in a LIFO order, the most recently reserved block is always the next block to be freed. This makes it really simple to keep track of the stack, freeing a block from the stack is nothing more than adjusting one pointer.</p>

<p>Variables allocated on the heap have their memory allocated at run time and accessing this memory is a bit slower, but the heap size is only limited by the size of virtual memory . Element of the heap have no dependencies with each other and can always be accessed randomly at any time. You can allocate a block at any time and free it at any time. This makes it much more complex to keep track of which parts of the heap are allocated or free at any given time.</p>

<p><img alt="stack-heap" src="http://net-informations.com/faq/net/img/stack-heap.png" style="height:247px; width:471px" /></p>

<p>You can use the stack if you know exactly how much data you need to allocate before compile time and it is not too big. You can use heap if you don&#39;t know exactly how much data you will need at runtime or if you need to allocate a lot of data.</p>

<p>In a multi-threaded situation each thread will have its own completely independent stack but they will share the heap. Stack is thread specific and Heap is application specific. The stack is important to consider in exception handling and thread executions.</p>
', 1, 1, CAST(0x0000A58901204A42 AS DateTime))
